column2: Not so Achilles, whom thy lying tongue / would feign thy father; like a foeman brave, / he scorned a suppliant's rights and trust to wrong, / and sent me home in safety, – ay, and gave / my Hector's lifeless body to the grave.
column4: At non ille, satum quo te mentiris, Achilles / talis in hoste fuit Priamo, sed jura fidemque / supplicis erubuit, corpusque exsangue sepulcro / reddidit Hectorem, meque in mea regna remisit.

column2: The old man spoke and, with a feeble throw, / at Pyrrhus with a harmless dart he drave. / The jarring metal blunts it, and below / the shield-boss, down it hangs, and foils the purposed blow.
column4: Sic fatus senior, telumque imbelle sine ictu / conjecit, rauco quod protinus aere repulsum / et summo clipei nequidquam umbone pependit.

column2: Go then, cries Pyrrhus, "with thy tale of woe / to dead Pelides, and thy plaints outpour. / To him, my father, in the shades below, / these deeds of his degenerate son deplore."
column4: Cui Pyrrhus: "Referes ergo hæc et nuntius ibis / Pelidæ genitori; illi mea tristia facta / degeneremque Neoptolemum narrare memento."

column2: Now die! – So speaking, to the shrine he tore / the aged Priam, trembling with affright, / and feebly sliding in his son's warm gore. / The left hand twists his hoary locks; the right / deep in his side drives home the falchion, bared and bright.
column4: Nunc morere. Hoc dicens, altaria ad ipsa trementem / traxit et in multo lapsantem sanguine nati, / implicuitque comam læva, dextraque coruscum / extulit ac lateri capulo tenus abdidit ensem.

column2: Such close had Priam's fortunes; so his days / were finished, such the bitter end he found, / now doomed by Fate with dying eyes to gaze / on Troy in flames and ruin all around, / and Pergamus laid level with the ground. / Lo, he to whom once Asia bowed the knee, / proud lord of many peoples, far-renowned, / now left to welter by the rolling sea, / a huge and headless trunk, a nameless corpse is he.
column4: Hæc finis Priami fatorum; hic exitus illum / sorte tulit, Trojam incensam et prolapsa videntem / Pergama, tot quondam populis terrisque superbum / regnatorem Asiæ. Jacet ingens litore truncus, / avulsumque humeris caput et sine nomine corpus.

column2: Is anyone going to eat that?
There's a book lying open on the desk.
column4: Liber apertus super mensam scriptoriam est.

column2: Grim horror seized me, and aghast I stood.
column4: At me tum primum sævus circumstetit horror.

column2: Uprose the image of my father dear, / as there I see the monarch, bathed in blood, / like him in prowess and in age his peer. / Uprose Creusa, desolate and drear, / Iulus' peril, and a plundered home.
column4: Obstupui; subiit cari genitoris imago, / ut regem æquævum crudeli vulnere vidi / vitam exhalantem; subiit deserta Creusa / et direpta domus et parvi casus Iuli.

column2: I look around for comrades; none are near. / Some o'er the battlements leapt headlong, some / sank fainting in the flames; the final hour was come.
column4: Respicio et, quæ sit me circum copia, lustro. / Desuere omnes defessi, et corpora saltu / ad terram misere aut ignibus ægra dedere.

column2: I stood alone, when lo, in Vesta's fane / I see Tyndarean Helen, crouching down. / Bright shone the blaze around me, as in vain / I tracked my comrades through the burning town.
column4: Jamque adeo super unus eram, cum limina Vestæ / servantem et tacitam secreta in sede latentem / Tyndarida adspicio: dant clara incendia lucem / erranti passimque oculos per cuncta ferenti.

column2: There, mute, and, as the traitress deemed, unknown, / dreading the Danaan's vengeance, and the sword / of Trojans, wroth for Pergamus o'erthrown, / dreading the anger of her injured lord, / sat Troy's and Argos' fiend, twice hateful and abhorred.
column4: Illa sibi infestos eversa ob Pergama Teucros, / et pœnas Danaum et deserti conjugis iras / præmetuens, Trojæ et patriæ communis Erinys, / abdiderat sese atque aris invisa sedebat.

column2: Then, fired with passion and revenge, I burn / to quit Troy's downfall and exact the fee / such crimes deserve.
column4: Exarsere ignes animo, subit ira cadentem / ulcisci patriam et sceleratas sumere pœnas.

column2: Sooth, then, shall she return / to Sparta and Mycenae, ay, and see / home, husband, sons and parents, safe and free, / with Ilian wives and Phrygians in her train, / a queen, in pride of triumph? Shall this be, / and Troy have blazed and Priam's self been slain, / and Trojan blood so oft have soaked the Dardan plain?
column4: Scilicet hæc Spartam incolumis patriasque Mycenas / adspiciet, partoque ibit regina triumpho, / conjugiumque domumque patres natosque videbit, / Iliadum turba et Phrygiis comitata ministris? / Occiderit ferro Priamus, Troja arserit igni, / Dardanium toties sudarit sanguine litus?

column2: Not so; though glory wait not on the act; / though poor the praise, and barren be the gain, / vengeance on feeble woman to exact, / yet praised hereafter shall his name remain, / who purges earth of such a monstrous stain. / Sweet is the passion of vindictive joy, / sweet is the punishment, where just the pain, / sweet the fierce ardour of revenge to cloy, / and slake with Dardan blood the funeral flames of Troy.
column4: Non ita; namque etsi nullum memorabile nomen / feminea in pœna est, nec habet victoria laudem, / exstinxisse nefas tamen et sumpsisse merentis / laudabor pœnas, animumque explesse juvabit / ultricis flammæ et cineres satiasse meorum.

column2: So mused I, blind with anger, when in light / apparent, never so refulgent seen, / my mother dawned irradiate on the night, / confessed a Goddess, such her form, and mien / and starry stature of celestial sheen. / With her right hand she grasped me from above, / and thus with roseate lips:
column4: Talia jactabam et furiata mente ferebar, / cum mi se, non ante oculis tam clara, videndam / obtulit et pura per noctem in luce refulsit / alma parens, confessa deam, qualisque videri / cœlicolis et quanta solet, dextraque prehensum / continuit, roseoque hæc insuper addidit ore:

column2: O son, what mean / these transports? Say, what bitter grief doth move / thy soul to rage untamed? Where vanished is thy love?
column4: Nate, quis indomitas tantus dolor excitat iras? / Quid furis, aut quonam nostri tibi cura recessit?

column2: Wilt thou not see, if yet thy sire survive, / worn out with age, amid the war's alarms? / And if thy wife Creusa be alive, / and young Ascanius? for around thee swarms / the foe, and but for my protecting arms, / fierce sword or flame had swept them all away.
column4: Non prius adspicies, ubi fessum ætate parentem / liqueris Anchisen, superet conjuxne Creusa / Ascaniusque puer, quos omnes undique Graiæ / circum errant acies, et, ni mea cura resistat, / jam flammæ tulerint inimicus et hauserit ensis.

column2: Tom has not had an easy life.
Not oft-blamed Paris, nor the hateful charms / of Helen; Heaven, unpitying Heaven to-day / hath razed the Trojan towers and reft the Dardan sway.
column4: Non tibi Tyndaridis facies invisa Lacænæ / culpatusve Paris, divum inclementia, divum, / has evertit opes sternitque a culmine Trojam.

column2: Look now, for I will clear the mists that shroud / thy mortal gaze, and from the visual ray / purge the gross covering of this circling cloud. / Thou heed, and fear not, whatsoe'er I say, / nor scorn thy mother's counsels to obey.
column4: Adspice, namque omnem, quæ nunc obducta tuenti / mortales hebebat visus tibi et humida circum / caligat, nubem eripiam: tu ne qua parentis / jussa time, neu præceptis parere recusa!

column2: Here, where thou seest the riven piles o'erthrown, / mixt dust and smoke, rock torn from rock away, / great Neptune's trident shakes the bulwarks down, / and from its lowest base uproots the trembling town.
column4: Hic ubi disjectas moles avulsaque saxis / saxa vides mistoque undantem pulvere fumum, / Neptunus muros magnoque emota tridenti / fundamenta quatit, totamque a sedibus urbem / eruit.

column2: Here, girt with steel, the foremost in the fight, / fierce Juno stands, the Scaean gates before, / and, mad with fury and malignant spite, / calls up her federate forces from the shore.
column4: Hic Juno Scæas sævissima portas / prima tenet, sociumque furens a navibus agmen / ferro accincta vocat.

column2: See, on the citadel, all grim with gore, / red-robed, and with the Gorgon shield aglow, / Tritonian Pallas bids the conflict roar.
column4: Jam summas arces Tritonia, respice, Pallas / insedit, nimbo effulgens et Gorgone sæva.

column2: French is a very beautiful language.
'"E'en Jove with strength reanimates the foe, / and stirs the powers of heaven to work the Dardan's woe."
column4: Ipse pater Danais animos viresque secundas / sufficit, ipse deos in Dardana suscitat arma.

column2: Haste, son, and fly; the fruitless toil give o'er. / I will not leave thee, but assist thy flight, / and set thee safely at thy father's door.
column4: Eripe, nate, fugam, finemque impone labori. / Nusquam abero, et tutum patrio te limine sistam.

column2: She spake, and vanished in the gloom of night.
column4: Dixerat, et spissis noctis se condidit umbris.

column2: Dread shapes and forms terrific loomed in sight, / and hostile deities, whose faces frowned / destruction.
column4: Apparent diræ facies inimicaque Trojæ / numina magna deum.

column2: Then, amid the lurid light, / I see Troy sinking in the flames around, / and mighty Neptune's walls laid level with the ground.
column4: Tum vero omne mihi visum considere in ignes / Ilium et ex imo verti Neptunia Troja.

column2: There are islands in the sea.

So, when an aged ash on mountain tall / stout woodmen strive, with many a rival blow, / to rend from earth; awhile it threats to fall, / with quivering locks and nodding head; now slow / it sinks and, with a dying groan lies low, / and spreads its ruin on the mountain side.
column4: Ac veluti summis antiquam in montibus ornum / cum ferro accisam crebrisque bipennibus instant / eruere agricolæ certatim; illa usque minatur / et tremefacta comam concusso vertice nutat, / vulneribus donec paulatim evicta supremum / congemuit traxitque jugis avulsa ruinam.

column2: Down from the citadel I haste below, / through foe, through fire, the goddes for my guide. / Harmless the darts give way, the sloping flames divide.
column4: Descendo, ac ducente deo flammam inter et hostes / expedior: dant tela locum, flammæque recedunt.

column2: But when Anchises' ancient home I gain, / my father, he, whom first, with loving care, / I sought and, heedful of my mother, fain / in safety to the neighbouring hills would bear, / disdains Troy's ashes to outlive and wear / his days in banishment.
column4: Atque ubi jam patriæ perventum ad limina sedis / antiquasque domos, genitor, quem tollere in altos / optabam primum montes primumque petebam, / abnegat excisa vitam producere Troja / exsiliumque pati.

column2: Fly ye, who may, / whom age hath chilled not, nor the years impair.
column4: Vos o, quibus integer ævi / sanguis, ait, solidæque suo stant robore vires, / vos agitate fugam.

column2: For me, had Heaven decreed a longer day, / Heaven too had spared these walls, nor left my home a prey.
column4: Me si cœlicolæ voluissent ducere vitam, / has mihi servassent sedes.

column2: Enough and more, to live when Ilion fell, / and once to see Troy captured.
column4: Satis una superque / vidimus excidia et captæ superavimus urbi.

column2: Leave me, pray, / and bid me, as a shrouded corpse, farewell. / For death, this hand will find for me the way, / or foes who spoil will pity me and slay. / Light is the loss of sepulchre or pyre.
column4: Sic o, sic positum affati discedit corpus. / Ipse manu mortem inveniam; miserebitur hostis / exuviasque petet. Facilis jactura sepulcri.

column2: Loathed have I lived and useless, since the day / when man's great monarch and the God's dread sire / breathed his avenging blast and scathed me with his fire.
column4: Jam pridem invisus divis et inutilis annos / demoror, ex quo me divum pater atque hominum rex / fulminis afflavit ventis et contigit igni.

column2: So spake he, on his purpose firmly bent. / We – wife, child, family and I – with prayer / and tears entreat the father to relent, / nor doom us all the common wreck to share, / and urge the ruin that the Fates prepare.
column4: Talia perstabat memorans, fixusque manebat. / Nos contra effusi lacrimis, conjuxque Creusa / Ascaniusque, omnisque domus, ne vertere secum / cuncta pater, fatoque urgenti incumbere, vellet.
Abnegat, inceptoque et sedibus hæret in isdem.

column2: Then again I fly / to arms – to arms, in frenzy of despair, / and long in utter misery to die. / What other choice was left, what other chance to try?
column4: Rursus in arma feror, mortemque miserrimus opto. / Nam quod consilium aut quæ jam fortuna dabatur?

column2: What, I to leave thee helpless, and to flee? / O father! could'st thou fancy it? Could e'er / a parent speak of such a crime to me?
column4: Mene efferre pedem, genitor, te posse relicto / sperasti, tantumque nefas patrio excidit ore?

column2: If Heaven of such a city naught should spare, / and thou be pleased that thou and thine should share / the common wreck, that way to death is plain. / Wide stands the door; soon Pyrrhus will be there, / red with the blood of Priam; he hath slain / the son before his sire, the father in the fane.
column4: Si nihil ex tanta superis placet urbe relinqui, / et sedet hoc animo, perituræque addere Trojæ / teque tuosque juvat; patet isti janua leto, / jamque aderit multo Priami de sanguine Pyrrhus, / natum ante ora patris, patrem qui obtruncat ad aras.

column2: I'd like to go to London.
Tom hasn't had an easy life.
I've already given Tom permission to do that.
He was accused of being a spy.
Tom is aware of his own faults.
column4: Thomas conscius de culpis suis est.

column2: Dost thou for this, dear mother, me through fire / and foeman safely to my home restore; / to see Creusa, and my son and sire / each foully butchered in the other's gore, / and Danaans dealing slaughter at the door?
column4: Hoc erat, alma parens, quod me per tela, per ignes / eripis, ut mediis hostem in penetralibus, utque / Ascanium patremque meum juxtaque Creusam, / alterum in alterius mactatos sanguine cernam?

column2: Arms – bring me arms! Troy's dying moments call / the vanquished. Give me to the Greeks. Once more / let me revive the battle; ne'er shall all / die unrevenged this day, nor tamely meet their fall.
column4: Arma, viri, ferte arma: vocat lux ultima victos! / Reddite me Danais! Sinite instaurata revisam / prœlia! Numquam omnes hodie moriemur inulti.

column2: Once more I girt me with the sword and shield, / and forth had soon into the battle hied, / when lo, Creusa at the doorway kneeled, / and reached Iulus to his sire and cried:
column4: Hinc ferro accingor rursus, clipeoque sinistram / insertabam aptans meque extra tecta ferebam; / ecce autem complexa pedes in limine conjux / hærebat, parvumque patri tendebat Iulum.

column2: I shouldn't have lost my temper.

If death thou seekest, take me at thy side / thy death to share, but if, expert in strife, / thou hop'st in arms, here guard us and abide. / To whom dost thou expose Iulus' life, / thy father's, yea, and mine, once called, alas! thy wife?
column4: Si periturus abis, et nos rape in omnia tecum; / sin aliquam expertus sumptis spem ponis in armis, / hanc primum tutare domum. Cui parvus Iulus, / cui pater et conjux quondam tua dicta relinquor?

column2: So wailed Creusa, and in wild despair / filled all the palace with her sobs and cries, / when lo! a portent, wondrous to declare. / For while, 'twixt sorrowing parents' hands and eyes, / stood young Iulus, wildered with surprise, / up from the summit of his fair, young head / a tuft was seen of flickering flame to rise. / Gently and harmless to the touch it spread / around his tender brows, and on his temples fed.
column4: Talia vociferans gemitu tectum omne replebat, / cum subitum dictuque oritur mirabile monstrum. / Namque manus inter mæstorumque ora parentum / ecce levis summo de vertice visus Iuli / fundere lumen apex, tactuque innoxia molles / lambere flamma comas et circum tempora pasci.

column2: In haste we strive to quench the flame divine, / shaking the tresses of his burning hair.
column4: Nos pavidi trepidare metu, crinemque flagrantem / excutere et sanctos restinguere fontibus ignes.

column2: But gladly sire Anchises hails the sign, / and gazing upward through the starlit air, / his hands and voice together lifts in prayer: / "O Jove omnipotent, dread power benign, / if aught our piety deserve, if e'er / a suppliant move thee, hearken and incline / this once, and aid us now and ratify thy sign."
column4: At pater Anchises oculos ad sidera lætus / extulit, et cœlo palmas cum voce tetendit : / "Jupiter omnipotens, precibus si flecteris ullis, / adspice nos: hoc tantum; et, si pietate meremur, / da deinde auxilium, pater, atque hæc omina firma."

column2: You must be more careful from now on.
column4: Post hoc oportet te diligentius agere.

column2: Mary has a flower in her hair.
column4: Maria florem in capillis suis habet.

column2: Scarce spake the sire when lo, to leftward crashed / a peal of thunder, and amid the night / a sky-dropt star athwart the darkness flashed, / trailing its torchfire with a stream of light.
column4: Vix ea fatus erat senior, subitoque fragore / intonuit lævum, et de cœlo lapsa per umbras / stella facem ducens multa cum luce cucurrit.

column2: We mark the dazzling meteor in its flight / glide o'er the roof, till, vanished from our eyes, / it hides in Ida's forest, shining bright / and furrowing out a pathway through the skies, / and round us far and wide the sulphurous fumes arise.
column4: Illam, summa super labentem culmina tecti, / cernimus Idæa claram se condere silva, / signantemque vias; tum longo limite sulcus / dat lucem, et late circum loca sulfure fumant.

column2: Up rose my sire, submissive to the sign, / and briefly to the Gods addressed his prayer, / and bowed adoring to the star divine.
column4: Hic vero victus genitor se tollit ad auras, / affaturque deos et sanctum sidus adorat.

column2: Now, now, he cries, "no tarrying; wheresoe'er / ye point the path, I follow and am there. / Gods of my fathers! O preserve to-day / my home, preserve my grandchild; for your care / is Troy, and yours this omen. I obey; / lead on, my son, I yield and follow on thy way."
column4: Jam jam nulla mora est; sequor et, qua ducitis, adsum. / Di patrii, servate domum, servate nepotem! / Vestrum hoc augurium,vestroque in numine Troja est. / Cedo equidem nec, nate, tibi comes ire recuso.

column2: He spake, and nearer through the city came / the roar, the crackle and the fiery glow / of conflagration, rolling floods of flame.
column4: Dixerat ille, et jam per mœnia clarior ignis / auditur, propiusque æstus incendia volvunt.

column2: Quick, father, mount my shoulders, let us go. / That toil shall never tire me.
column4: Ergo age, care pater, cervici imponere nostræ; / ipse subibo humeris, nec me labor iste gravabit.

column2: Come whatso / the Fates shall bring us, both alike shall share / one common welfare or one common woe.
column4: Quo res cumque cadent, unum et commune periclum, / una salus ambobus erit.

column2: Let young Iulus at my side repair; / keep thou, my wife, aloof, and follow as we fare.
column4: Mihi parvus Iulus / sit comes, et longe servet vestigia conjux.

column2: Ye too, my servants, hearken my commands. / Outside the city is a mound, where, dear / to Ceres once, but now deserted, stands / a temple, and an aged cypress near, / for ages hallowed with religious fear.
column4: Vos, famuli, quæ dicam, animis advertite vestris. / Est urbe egressis tumulus templumque vetustum / desertæ Cereris, juxtaque antiqua cupressus / religione patrum multos servata per annos.
Hanc ex diverso sedem veniemus in unam.

column2: Father, in thy charge remain / Troy's gods; for me, red-handed with the smear / of blood, and fresh from slaughter, 'twere profane / to touch them, ere the stream hath cleansed me of the stain.
column4: Tu, genitor, cape sacra manu patriosque Penates; / me bello e tanto digressum et cæde recenti / attrectare nefas, donec me flumine vivo / abluero.

column2: So saying, my neck and shoulders I incline, / and round them fling a lion's tawny hide, / then lift the load.
column4: Hæc fatus, latos humeros subjectaque colla / veste super fulvique insternor pelle leonis, / succedoque oneri.

column2: His little hand in mine, / Iulus totters at his father's side; / behind me comes Creusa.
column4: Dextræ se parvus Iulus / implicuit sequiturque patrem non passibus æquis; / pone subit conjux.

column2: On we stride / through shadowy ways; and I who rushing spear / and thronging foes but lately had defied, / now fear each sound, each whisper of the air, / trembling for him I lead, and for the charge I bear.
column4: Ferimur per opaca locorum; / et me, quem dudum non ulla injecta movebant / tela neque adverso glomerati ex agmine Graii, / nunc omnes terrent auræ, sonus excitat omnis / suspensum et pariter comitique onerique timentem.

column2: And now I neared the gates, and thought my flight / achieved, when suddenly a noise we hear / of trampling feet, and, peering through the night, / my father cries, "Fly, son, the Greeks are near; / they come, I see the glint of shield and spear, / fierce foes in front and flashing arms behind."
column4: Jamque propinquabam portis omnemque videbar / evasisse viam, subito cum creber ad aures / visus adesse pedum sonitus, genitorque per umbram / prospiciens "Nate", exclamat, "fuge, nate, propinquant. / Ardentes clipeos atque æra micantia cerno."

column2: Does Tom have to be present?
I'm eating dinner with my husband.

Then trembling seized me and, amidst my fear, / what power I know not, but some power unkind / confused my wandering wits, and robbed me of my mind. / For while, the byways following, I left / the beaten track, ah! woe and well away! / my wife Creusa lost me – whether reft / by Fate, or faint or wandering astray, / I know not.
column4: Hic mihi nescio quod trepido male numen amicum / confusam eripuit mentem: namque avia cursu / dum sequor et nota excedo regione viarum, / heu, misero conjux fatone erepta Creusa / subsistit, erravitne via, seu lassa resedit, / incertum.

column2: Nor have seen her since that day, / nor sought, nor missed her, till in Ceres' fane / we met at length, and mustered our array. / There she alone was wanting of our train, / and husband, son and friends all looked for her in vain!
column4: Nec post oculis est reddita nostris. / Nec prius amissam respexi animumve reflexi, / quam tumulum antiquæ Cereris sedemque sacratam / venimus: hic demum collectis omnibus una / defuit, et comites natumque virumque fefellit.

column2: Rome was attacked by many enemies.
column4: Roma a multis hostibus oppugnata est.

column2: The snake swallowed the whole cow.
Whom then did I upbraid not, wild with woe, / of gods or men? What sadder sight elsewhere / had Troy, now whelmed in utter wreck, to show?
column4: Quem non incusavi amens hominumque deorumque, / aut quid in eversa vidi crudelius urbe?

column2: He who wants wisdom should first have patience.
column4: Qui sapientiam vult, patientiam habeat primam.

column2: The cat easily killed the mouse.
The lions are much stronger than the deer.
column4: Leones multo fortiores quam cervi sunt.

column2: Troy's gods commending to my comrades' care, / with old Anchises and my infant heir, / I hide them in a winding vale from view.
column4: Ascanium Anchisenque patrem Teucrosque Penates / commendo sociis, et curva valle recondo.

column2: Then, sheathed again in shining arms, prepare / once more to scour the city through and through, / resolved to brave all risks, all ventures to renew.
column4: Ipse urbem repeto, et cingor fulgentibus armis. / Stat casus renovare omnes, omnemque reverti / per Trojam, et rursus caput objectare periclis.

column2: Tom is a very clever man.
Where did you buy the shoes?
I'm eating lunch with my parents today.
I believe that dreams are not always deceptive.
column4: Credo somnia non semper falsa esse.

column2: Why can't you go with us?
The cat lashed out at the dog.
This tree produces a lot of big fruit in spring.
column4: Haec arbor vere multos magnosque fructus edit.

column2: I reach the ramparts and the shadowy gates / whence first I issued, backward through the night / my studied steps retracing. Horror waits / around; the very silence breeds affright.
column4: Principio muros obscuraque limina portæ, / qua gressum extuleram, repeto, et vestigia retro / observata sequor per noctem et lumine lustro: / horror ubique animos, simul ipsa silentia terrent.

column2: Then homeward turn, if haply in her flight, / if, haply, thither she had strayed; but ere / I came, behold, the Danaans, loud in fight, / swarmed through the halls.
column4: Inde domum, si forte pedem, si forte, tulisset, / me refero: irruerant Danai et tectum omne tenebant.

column2: Roof-high the fiery glare, / fanned by the wind, mounts up; the loud blast roars in air.
column4: Ilicet ignis edax summa ad fastigia vento / volvitur; exsuperant flammæ, furit æstus ad auras.

column2: Tom is my husband's best friend.
column4: Thomas est amicus optimus mariti mei.

column2: There's no need to call a doctor.
I want to keep my kids safe.
Tom has done a wonderful job.
Again to Priam's palace, and again / up to the citadel I speed my way.
column4: Procedo et Priami sedes arcemque reviso.

Armed, in the vacant courts, by Juno's fane, / Phoenix and curst Ulysses watched the prey.

column2: Scarce stand the vessels hauled upon the beach, / and bent on marriages the young men vie / to till new settlements, while I to each / due law dispense and dwelling place supply, / when from a tainted quarter of the sky / rank vapours, gathering, on my comrades seize, / and a foul pestilence creeps down from high / on mortal limbs and standing crops and trees, / a season black with death, and pregnant with disease.
column4: Jamque fere sicco subductæ litore puppes, / connubiis arvisque novis operata juventus; / jura domosque dabam: subito cum tabida membris, / corrupto cœli tractu, miserandaque venit / arboribusque satisque lues et letifer annus.

column2: Sweet life from mortals fled; they drooped and died. / Fierce Sirius scorched the fields, and herbs and grain / were parched, and food the wasting crops denied.
column4: Linquebant dulces animas, aut ægra trahebant / corpora; tum steriles exurere Sirius agros; / arebant herbæ et victum seges ægra negabat.

column2: Once more Anchises bids us cross the main / and seek Ortygia, and the god constrain / by prayer to pardon and advise, what end / of evils to expect? what woes remain? / What fate hereafter shall our steps attend? / What rest for toil-worn men, and whitherward to wend?
column4: Rursus ad oraclum Ortygiæ Phœbumque remenso / hortatur pater ire mari, veniamque precari, / quam fessis finem rebus ferat, unde laborum / tentare auxilium jubeat, quo vertere cursus.

column2: 'Twas night; on earth all creatures were asleep, / when lo! the figures of our gods, the same / whom erst from falling Ilion o'er the deep / I brought, scarce rescued from the midmost flame, / before me, sleepless for my country's shame, / stood plain, in plenteousness of light confessed, / where streaming through the sunken lattice came / the moon's full splendour, and their speech addressed, / and I in heart took comfort, hearing their behest.
column4: Nox erat et terris animalia somnus habebat: / effigies sacræ divum Phrygiique Penates, / quos mecum a Troja mediisque ex ignibus urbis / extuleram, visi ante oculos adstare jacentis / in somnis, multo manifesti lumine, qua se / plena per insertas fundebat luna fenestras; / tum sic affari et curas his demere dictis:

column4: Nos te, Dardania incensa, tuaque arma secuti, / nos tumidum sub te permensi classibus æquor, / idem venturos tollemus in astra nepotes, / imperiumque urbi dabimus: tu mœnia magnis / magna para longumque fugæ ne linque laborem.

Far off there lies, across the rolling wave, / an ancient land, which Greeks Hesperia name; / her soil is fruitful and her people brave. / Th' OEnotrians held it once, by later fame / the name Italia from their chief they claim.
column4: Est locus, Hesperiam Graii cognomine dicunt, / terra antiqua, potens armis atque ubere glebæ; / Oenotri coluere viri; nunc fama minores / Italiam dixisse ducis de nomine gentem.

column2: Thence sprang great Dardanus; there lies thy seat; / thence sire Iasius and theTrojans came.

column2: Rise, and thy parent with these tidings greet, / to seek Ausonian shores, for Jove denies thee Crete.

column2: Awed by the vision and the voice divine / ('twas no mere dream; their very looks I knew, / I saw the fillets round their temples twine, / and clammy sweat did all my limbs bedew) / forthwith, upstarting, from the couch I flew, / and hands and voice together raised in prayer, / and wine unmixt upon the altars threw. / This done, to old Anchises I repair, / pleased with the rites fulfilled, and all the tale declare.
column4: Talibus attonitus visis ac voce deorum / (nec sopor illud erat, sed coram agnoscere vultus / velatasque comas præsentiaque ora videbar, / tum gelidus toto manabat corpore sudor), / corripio e stratis corpus, tendoque supinas / ad cœlum cum voce manus, et munera libo / intemerata focis. Perfecto lætus honore / Anchisen facio certum, remque ordine pando.

column2: Ah! who listened or obeyed? / Who dreamed that Teucrians should Hesperia gain? / Yield we to Phoebus now, nor wisdom's words disdain.

column2: All hail the speech. We quit this other home, / and leaving here a handful on the shore, / spread sail and scour with hollow keel the foam.

column2: The fleet was on mid ocean; land no more / was visible, naught else above, before / but sky and sea, when overhead did loom / a storm-cloud, black as heaven itself, that bore / dark night and wintry tempest in its womb, / and all the waves grew rough and shuddered with the gloom.
column4: Postquam altum tenuere rates, nec jam amplius ullæ / apparent terræ, cœlum undique et undique pontus, / tum mihi cæruleus supra caput adstitit imber / noctem hiememque ferens, et inhorruit unda tenebris.

column2: Winds roll the waters, and the great seas rise. / Dispersed we welter on the gulfs. Damp night / has snatched with rain the heaven from our eyes, / and storm-mists in a mantle wrapt the light. / Flash after flash, and for a moment bright, / quick lightnings rend the welkin. Driven astray / we wander, robbed of reckoning, reft of sight. / No difference now between the night and day / e'en Palinurus sees, nor recollects the way.
column4: Continuo venti volvunt mare magnaque surgunt / æquora: dispersi jactamur gurgite vasto. / Involvere diem nimbi, et nox humida cœlum / abstulit; ingeminant abruptis nubibus ignes. / Excutimur cursu, et cæcis erramus in undis. / Ipse diem noctemque negat discernere cœlo, / nec meminisse viæ media Palinurus in unda.

column2: Three days, made doubtful by the blinding gloom, / as many nights, when not a star is seen, / we wander on, uncertain of our doom.
column4: Tres adeo incertos cæca caligine soles / erramus pelago, totidem sine sidere noctes.

column2: At last the fourth glad daybreak clears the scene, / and rising land, and opening uplands green, / and rolling smoke at distance greet the view.

column2: These lands, 'tis said, one continent of yore / (such change can ages work) an earthquake tore / asunder; in with havoc rushed the main, / and far Sicilia from Hesperia bore, / and now, where leapt the parted land in twain, / the narrow tide pours through, 'twixt severed town and plain.

column2: The heavens rotate and encompass the earth, which stands in the middle. The sun, wherever it is, shines perpetually, however dark clouds may take it away from us; it creates by its rays light, and the light of day. On the other side is darkness, and therefore night.

column2: In the night, the moon shines and stars glisten and twinkle. In the evening is twilight: in the morning the break of day and the dawn.

column2: Fire glows, burns and consumes to ashes. A spark of it struck from a flint (or firestone) by means of a steel, and taken by tinder in a tinder box, lights a match, and after that a candle, or a stick, and causes a flame, or blaze, which catches hold of houses.
column4: Ignis ardet, urit, cremat. Scintilla ejus elisa e Silice (Pyrite), Ope Chalybis et excepta a Fomite in Suscitabulo, accendit Sulphuratum, et inde Candelam, vel Lignum, et excitat Flammam, vel Incendium, quod corripit Aedificia.

column2: There, when at Cumae landing from the main, / Avernus' lakes and sounding woods ye gain, / thyself shalt see, within her rock-hewn shrine, / the frenzied prophetess, whose mystic strain / expounds the Fates, to leaves of trees consign / the notes and names that mark the oracles divine.
column4: Huc ubi delatus Cumæam accesseris urbem / divinosque lacus et Averna sonantia silvis; / insanam vatem adspicies, quæ rupe sub ima / fata canit, foliisque notas et nomina mandat.

column2: There rest they, nor their sequence change, nor place, / save when, by chance, on grating hinge the door / swings open, and a light breath sweeps the floor, / or rougher blasts the tender leaves disperse. / Loose then they flutter, for she recks no more / to call them back, and rearrange the verse; / untaught the votaries leave, the Sibyl's cave to curse.
column4: Illa manent immota locis, neque ab ordine cedunt. / Verum eadem, verso tenuis cum cardine ventus / impulit et teneras turbavit janua frondes, / nunquam deinde cavo volitantia prendere saxo, / nec revocare situs aut jungere carmina curat: / inconsulti abeunt, sedemque odere Sibyllæ.

Then to Anchises, as he bids us spread / the sails, with reverence speaks Apollo's seer, / "Far-famed Anchises, honoured with the bed / of haughty Venus, Heaven's peculiar care, / Twice saved from Troy! behold Ausonia there, / steer towards her coasts, yet skirt them; far away / that region lies, which Phoebus doth prepare. / Blest in thy son's devotion, take thy way. / Why should more words of mine the rising South delay?"
column4: Interea classem velis aptare jubebat / Anchises, fieret vento mora ne qua ferenti. / Quem Phœbi interpres multo compellat honore: / "Conjugio Anchisa Veneris dignate superbo, / cura deum, bis Pergameis erepte ruinis, / ecce tibi Ausoniæ tellus: hanc arripe velis. / Et tamen hanc pelago præterlabare necesse est. / Ausoniæ pars illa procul, quam pandit Apollo. / Vade, ait, o felix nati pietate! Quid ultra / provehor, et fando surgentes demoror austros?"

column2: Nor less Andromache, sore grieved to part, / rich raiment fetches, wrought with golden thread, / and Phrygian scarf, and still with bounteous heart / loads him with broideries. "Take these", she said, / "sole image of Astyanax now dead. / Thy kin's last gifts, my handiwork, to show / how Hector's widow loved the son she bred. / Such eyes had he, such very looks as thou, / such hands, and oh! like thine his age were ripening now!"
column4: Nec minus Andromache, digressu mæsta supremo, / fert picturatas auri subtemine vestes / et Phrygiam Ascanio chlamydem, nec cedit honori, / textilibusque onerat donis, ac talia fatur: / "Accipe et hæc, manuum tibi quæ monumenta mearum / sint, puer, et longum Andromachae testentur amorem, / conjugis Hectoræ; cape dona extrema tuorum, / o mihi sola mei super Astyanactis imago. / Sic oculos, sic ille manus, sic ora ferebat, / et nunc æquali tecum pubesceret ævo."

column2: With gushing tears I bid the pair farewell. / "Live happy ye, whose destinies are o'er; / we still must wander where the Fates compel."
column4: Hos ego digrediens lacrimis affabar obortis: / "Vivite felices, quibus est fortuna peracta / jam sua! Nos alia ex aliis in fata vocamur."

Ye still can see a Xanthus and a Troy, / reared by your hands, old Ilion to restore, / and brighter auspices than ours enjoy, / nor tempt, like ours, the Greeks to ravage and destroy.

column2: If ever Tiber and the fields I see / washed by her waves, ere mingling with the brine, / and build the city which the Fates decree, / then kindred towns and neighbouring folk shall join, / yours in Epirus, in Hesperia mine, / and linked thenceforth in sorrow and in joy, / with Dardanus the founder of each line, / so let posterity its pains employ, / two nations, one in heart, shall make another Troy.
column4: Si quando Thybrim vicinaque Thybridis arva / intraro, gentique meæ data mœnia cernam, / cognatas urbes olim populosque propinquos, / Epiro, Hesperia, quibus idem Dardanus auctor / atque idem casus, unam faciemus utramque / Trojam animis: maneat nostros ea cura nepotes.

column2: We traveled through the whole land.
On fly the barks o'er ocean. Near us frown / Ceraunia's rocks, whence shortest lies the way / to Italy. And now the sun gows down, / and darkness gathers on the mountains grey.
column4: Provehimur pelago vicina Ceraunia juxta, / unde iter Italiam cursusque brevissimus undis. / Sol ruit interea et montes umbrantur opaci.

column2: Close by the water, in a sheltered bay, / a few guardians of the oars we choose, / then stretched at random on the beach we lay / our limbs to rest, and on the toil-worn crews / sleep steals in silence down, and sheds her kindly dews.
column4: Sternimur optatæ gremio telluris ad undam, / sortiti remos, passimque in litore sicco / corpora curamus; fessos sopor irrigat artus.

column2: We travelled all over the country.

Nor yet had Night climbed heaven, when up from sleep / starts Palinurus, and with listening ear / catches the breeze. He marks the stars, that keep / their courses, gliding through the silent sphere, / Arcturus, rainy Hyads and each Bear, / and, girt with gold, Orion.
column4: Necdum orbem medium nox horis acta subibat: / haud segnis strato surgit Palinurus, et omnes / explorat ventos, atque auribus aéra captat; / sidera cuncta notat tacito labentia cœlo, / Arcturum pluviasque Hyadas geminosque Triones, / armatumque auro circumspicit Oriona.

column2: Far away / he sees the firmament all calm and clear, / and from the stern gives signal. We obey, / and shifting camp, set sail and tempt the doubtful way.
column4: Postquam cuncta videt cœlo constare sereno, / dat clarum e puppi signum; nos castra movemus, / tentamusque viam et velorum pandimus alas.

column2: The stars were chased, and blushing rose the day. / Dimly, at distance through the misty shroud / Italia's hills and lowlands we survey, / "Italia," first Achates shouts aloud: / "Italia," echoes from the joyful crowd.

Then sire Anchises hastened to entwine / a massive goblet with a wreath, and vowed / libations to the gods, and poured the wine / and on the lofty stern invoked the powers divine: / "Great gods, whom Earth and Sea and Storms obey, / breathe fair, and waft us smoothly o'er the main."
column4: Tum pater Anchises magnum cratera corona / induit implevitque mero, divosque vocavit / stans celsa in puppi: / "Di, maris et terræ tempestatumque potentes, / ferte viam vento facilem, et spirate secundi."

column2: Land has hill, woods, fields, animals and men.

column2: Thus, the greatest bodies of the world, the four elements, are full of their own inhabitants.
column4: Ita, sunt plena Habitatoribus suis, quatuor Elementa, Mundi maxima Corpora.

column2: The Heaven is wheeled about and encompasses the Earth, standing in the middle.
column4: Caelum rotatur, et ambit Terram stantem in medio.

column2: The Sun, whereever it is, always shines, however dark it is. Clouds may take it away from us; by its rays it makes light and light makes day.
column4: Sol, ubi ubi est, fulget perpetuo, ut ut. Nubila eum a nobis eripiant; facitque suis Radiis Lucem; Lux diem.

column2: In the night the moon shines and the stars glitter and twinkle.
column4: Nocte splendet Luna et Stellae micant, scintillant.

column2: In the evening is twilight; in the morning the breaking and dawning of the day.
column4: Vesperi est Crespuculum, manē Aurora et Diluculum.

column2: Water springs out of a fountain, flows downwards in a brook, runs in a beck, stands in a pond, glides in the stream, is whirled about in a whirlpool and causes fens.
column4: Aquā scatet ē fonte, defluit in terrente, manat in rivo, stat in stagno, fluit in flumine, gyratur in vertice, facit paludes.

column2: The sea makes shores, bays, capes, islands, peninsulas, necks of land, straights, and has rocks in it.
column4: Mare facit littora, Sinus, promontoria, insulas, peninsulas, isthmos, freta et habet scopulos.

column2: “What are you doing?” “I am repeating by myself.”
“What are you repeating?” “The task which the Master set us today.”
column4: “Quid repetis?” “Pensum quod praeceptor praescripsit nobis hodie.”

column2: “Do you hold it in memory?” “So I think.”

column4: Non decet nos otiari aut garrire hic dum praeceptor expectatur.

column2: Vapour ascends from water. From it is formed a cloud, and mist near the Earth.
column4: Ex aquā ascendit vapor. Inde sit nubes et propē terram nebula.

column2: Rain and a small shower form out of a cloud, drop by drop. Which makes, when frozen, hail, half-frozen, snow, when warm, mildew.
column4: E nube guttatim stillat pluvia et imber. Quae, gelata, grando, semigelata, nix, calefacta, rubigo est.

column2: By a rain cloud, the sun against it, appears a rainbow.
column4: In nube pluviosa, soli opposita, apparet iris.

column2: A drop, falling into water, makes a bubble; many bubbles make froth.
column4: Gutta, incidens in aquam, facit bullam, multae bullae faciunt spuman.

column2: Frozen water is called ice; dew congealed is called frost.
column4: Aqua congelata glacies, ros congelatus pruina dicitur.

column2: Thunder is made from a sulphurous vapour, breaking out of a cloud with lightning, thundering and striking with lightning.
column4: Ex vapore suphureo sit Tonitru, quod, erumpens e nube cum fulgure, tonat et fulminat.

column2: On the earth are high mountains, deep valleys, rising hills, hollow caves and shady woods.
column4: In terra sunt montes alti, valles profundae, colles elevati, speluncae cavae, sylvae opacae.

column2: A meadow yields grass, with flowers and herbs, which being cut, make hay.
column4: Pratum fert gramina, cum floribus et herbis, quae desecta fiunt foenum.

column2: A field yields corn and vegetables.
Mushrooms, strawberries, myrtle trees and so on come from the woods.
column4: In sylvis proveniunt fungi, fraga, myrtilli et cetera.

column2: Metals, stones and minerals arise from under the earth.
column4: Sub terra nascuntur metalla, lapides, mineralia.

column2: They are the fruits of the earth.
Lead is soft and heavy. Iron is hard and steel harder.
column4: Plumbum est molle et grave. Ferrum est durum et durior calybs.

column2: From tin, tankards are made; from copper, kettles; from lattin, candlesticks; from silver, dollars; from gold, Ducats and Crown pieces.
column4: E stanno, faciunt cantbaros, e cupro ahena; ex orichalco, Candelabro; ex Argento, Thaleros; ex Aure, Scutates (Ducatos) et Coronatos.
Argentum vivam, semper liquet et metella corrodit.

column2: Sand and gravel are stone broken into bits. A whetstone, flint, marble etcetera are ordinary stones.
column4: Arena et sabulam est comminutus lapis. Saxum est pars petrea (cautis). Cos, silex, marmor et cetera sunt lapides obscuri.

column2: Jewels are clear stones, as: the white diamond, blue sapphire, green emerald, yellow Jacinth and so on; and glitter when cut.
column4: Gemmae, sunt lapilli pellucidi, ut: adamas candidus, ribinus rubeus, sapphirim caeruleus, smaragdus viridis, hyacinthus luteus, et cetera; et micant angulati.

column2: Pearls and unions grow in shellfish; corals in a sea shrub. Amber is gathered from the sea.
column4: Margaritae et Uniones crescunt in conchis. Coralia in Marinā arbuscula. Succinum colligitur ē mari.

column2: A shoot grows from a seed. A shoot transforms to a sapling, a sapling to a tree. The root sustains the tree.
column4: E semine procrescis planta, planta abit in fruticem. Frutex in arborem. Arborem sustentat radix.

column2: From the root rises the stem. The stem divides itself into boughs and green branches made from leaves.
column4: E radice surgit stirps (stemma). Stirps se dividit in ramos et frondes, factas ex foliis.

column2: Bird lime accumulates on the boughs, which also seep gum, resin, pitch etcetera.
column4: Viscum ramis adnascitur: qui etiam gummi, resinam, vicem et cetera sudant.

column2: Fruits are picked from fruit-bearing trees. The apple is round. The pear and the fig are somewhat long.
column4: Poma ab arboribus fructiferis decerpuntur. Malum est rotundum. Pyrum et ficus sunt oblonga.

column2: The cherry hangs by a long stalk, the plum and peach's are shorter. The mulberry’s stalk is very short.
column4: Cerasum pendet longo pediolo; prunum et persicium breviori. Morum brevissimo.

column2: The walnut, hazelnut and chestnut are wrapped in a husk and a shell.
column4: Nux juglans, avellana et castanea involuta sunt cortici et putamini.

column2: Barren trees are the fir, elder, birch, cypress, beech, ivy, sallow, linden and so on, but most of them afford shade.
column4: Steriles arbores sunt abies, alnus, betula, cupressus, fagus, fraximus, salix, tilia et cetera; sed pleraque umbriserae.

column2: But the juniper and bay tree yield berries; the pine, pine cones, the oak acorns and Galls.
column4: At Juniperus et Lauras ferunt baccae; pinus strobiles, Quercus glandes et gallas.

column2: Among the most notable flowers, at the start of Spring, are the Violet, the Crow-tree, the Daffodil, then the Lilies, white and yellow, and blue; and Clove-gillow flowers, and so on.

column2: The Tulip is a graceful flower but has no scent.

column2: Of these Garlands and Nosegays are tied round with twigs. There are also sweet herbs added such as Marjoram, Flowergentle, Rue, Lavender, Rosemary, Hysop, Spike, Basil, Sage, Mints and so on.
column4: Ex his vientur Serta et Servia. Adduntur etiam Herba odoratae ut, Amaranthus, Ruta, Lavendula, Rosmarinus (Libanotis), Hyssopus, Nardus, Ocymum, Salvia, Menta et cetera.

column2: Among field flowers the most noted are the May Lily, the Ground Ivy, the Bluebottle, Camomile and so on; and among herbs, Trefoil, Wormwood, Sorrel, the Nettle and so forth.
column4: Inter campestres notissimi sunt flores: Lilium convallium, Chamaedrys, Cyanus, Chamaemelum, et cetera; et Herbae: Cytifus (Trifolium), Absinthium, Acetosa, Urtica, et cetera.

column2: Pot herbs grow in gardens, such as lettuce, cabbage, onions, garlic, gourd, parsnip, turnip, radish, horse radish, parsley, cucumbers and pumpkin.
column4: In hortis nascuntur Olera, ut Lactuca, Brassica, Cepa, Allium, Cucurbita, Siser, Rapa, Rhaphanus minor, Raphanus Major, Petroselinum, Cucumeres, Pepones.

The bird, (this Kingfisher, nesting in the Sea) is covered with feathers, wings, flies with two wings, has two pinions, and as many pedida, a tail, and a bill. The Female, in a nest, lays eggs, and incubating those, hatches chicks.
column4: Avis, (hic Halcyon, in mari nidulans) tegitur Plumis, volat Pennis, habet duas Alas, todidem Pedides, Candam, et Rostrum. Faemella, in nido ponit Ova, iisque incubans, excludi Pullos.

column2: The Swallow, the Sparrow, the Jay, the Jackdaw and the Bat (Flittermouse) fly around the house.
column4: Hirundo, Passer, Pica, Monedula et Vespertilio (Mus alatus) volitant circa Domus.

column2: The Stork nests on the roof.
The beautiful Peacock, proud of its feathers.
The Cock (which crows in the morning) has a comb and spurs; when castrated, is called a capon and is crammed in a Coop.
column4: Gallus (qui manē canet) habet Cristam et Calcaria; castratus dicitur Capo, et saginatur in Ornithotrophio.

column2: The Hen scrapes the dunghill and picks up grains, as does the Pigeon, (which are brought into the Pidgeonhouse) and the Turkey, with its Turkey-hen.
column4: Gallina, ruspatur simetum, et colligit grana: sicut et Colombae, (quae educantur in Colombario) et Gallopavus, cum suā Meleagride.

column2: The egg is covered with shell, under which is the white and within this the egg yolk.
column4: Ovum tegitur Testa, sub quā Albumen in hoc vitellus.

column2: Tom and Mary have helped me a lot.

column2: The Nightingal singeth the sweetliest of all.
The Nightingale sings the sweetest of all.

The Lark sings as it flies in the air, the Quail sitting on the ground; others, on the boughs of trees, such as: the Canary, the Chaffinch, the Goldfinch, the Siskin, the Linner, the little Titmouse, the Woodwall, the Robin Redbreast, the Hedge Sparrow and so on.
column4: Alanda cantillat volitans in aere; Conturnix humi sedens; caeterae in ramis arborum, ut: Luteola peregrina, Fringilla, Carduelis, Acanthis, Linaria, parvus Parus, Galgulas, Rubecula, Curruca et cetera.

column2: The many coloured Parrot, the Blackbird, the Starling, with the Magpie and the Jay, learn to form men's words. A great many are put in cages.
column4: Psittacus discolor, Merula, Sturnus, cum Picā et Monedulā, discunt humanas voces formare. Pleraque solent includi cavis.

column2: The Ostrich is the largest bird, the Wren the smallest; the Owl is the most despicable; the Hoopoe the most dirty (as it eats dung); the Bird of Paradise is most rare.
column4: Struthio est ales maximus; Regulus minimus; Noctua despicatissimus; Upapa sordissimus, rescitur enim stercorinibus); Manucodiata rarissimus.

column2: I am learning English with the idea of going to America.

column2: He met me when I came.

Those mountains are molehills, if compared with the waves of the sea. As often as we were lifted up high, one might have touched the moon with a finger. As often as we were let down, we seemed to descend directly into hell, the earth gaping.
column4: Ille montes sunt verrucae, si conserantur ad undas moris. Quoties tollebamur in altum, licuisset contingere lunam digito. Quoties demittabur, videbamur ire recta in tartara, terra debiscente.

column2: It was a moonlit night, and one of the sailors stood upon the round top; as I think they call it; he looked around to see if he could see any land.
column4: Erat sublustris nox, et quidam e nautis stabat in galea; nam sic vocant, opinor; circumspectans, si videret quam terram.

column2: One there combs his bead, another wipes off sweat, another cleans his winter shoes or boots, another belches up garlick.
column4: Alius ibi pectit caput, alius abstergit sudorem, alius repurgat perones aut ocreas, alius eructat allium.

column2: There is no less confusion there of tongues and persons, than formerly in the tower of Babel.

column2: A: When now it is far in the evening, and no more are expeċted to come, an old servant comes out with a hoary beard, shorn head, grim look, mean cloaths. B: It behoved such to be cup-bearers to the Roman cardinals.
column4: A: Ubi jam eft multa vespera, nec plures expectantur venturi, senex famulus prodit cana barba, tonso capite, torvo vultu, sordido vestitu. B. Oportebat tales esse a poculis Romanis cardinalibus.

column2: At length one pleased me more than the rest. He approves of my judgment, swearing that that horse had been desired frequently by many.
column4: Tandem unus arridebat plus caeteris. Ille probat meum judicium, dejerans eum equum ex petitum esse frequenter a multis.

column2: Lo, here, first omen offered to our eyes, / four snow-white steeds are grazing on the plain.

column2: 'Tis war thou bringest us, Anchises cries, / strange land! For war the mettled steed they train, / and war these threaten. Yet in time again / these beasts are wont in harness to obey, / and bear the yoke, as guided by the rein. / Peace yet is hopeful."
column4: Et pater Anchises: "Bellum, o terra hospita, portas; / bello armantur equi, bellum hæc armenta minantur. / Sed tamen idem olim curru succedere sueti / quadrupedes, et frena jugo concordia ferre; / spes et pacis," ait.

column2: My parents are loved by me.

column4: Tum numina sancta precamur / Palladis armisonæ, quæ prima accepit ovantes.

column2: Veiled at her shrines in Phrygian hood we stand, / and chief to Juno, mindful of the seer, / burnt-offerings pay, as pious rites demand.
column4: Et capita ante aras Phrygio velamur amictu; / præceptisque Heleni, dederat quæ maxima, rite / Junoni Argivæ jussos adolemus honores.

column2: It seems to me that it's pigs, not people, living here with me.

Far off is seen, above the billowy mere, / Trinacrian AEtna, and the distant roar / of ocean and the beaten rocks we hear, / and the loud burst of breakers on the shore; / high from the shallows leap the surges hoar, / and surf and sand mix eddying.
column4: Tum procul e fluctu Trinacria cernitur Aetna, / et gemitum ingentem pelagi pulsataque saxa / audimus longe, fractasque ad litora voces, / exsultantque vada, atque æstu miscentur arenæ.

column2: Behold / Charybdis! cries Anchises, "'tis the shore, / the dreaded rocks that Helenus foretold. / Row, comrades, for dear life, and let the oars catch hold."

column2: Maccus praised the stockings, praised the shoes.

column4: Hic Maccus inquit, dic mihi bona fide, nusquamne usu venit tibi, ut quem armasses sic ocreis et calceis ad cursum, quemadmodum nunc armasti me, abierit non numerato pretio?

column2: Now Maccus says: tell me in good faith, did it never happen to you, that someone you had equipped like this with leather stockings and shoes, as if for a race, as you’ve just equipped me, then left without paying the bill?

column4: Eusebius: Itane, venabaris religionem in bello? Quo quid potest esse sceleratius? Pampirus: Erat sancta militia. Eu: Fortassis Turcas? Pa: Imo quoddam sanctius, ut praedicabant tum. Eu: Quidnam? Pa: Julius secundus belligerabat adversus Gallos.

column2: It was a spacious harbour, sheltered deep / from access of the winds, but looming vast / with awful ravage, AEtna's neighbouring steep / thundered aloud, and, dark with clouds, upcast / smoke and red cinders in a whirlwind's blast. / Live balls of flame, with showers of sparks, upflew / and licked the stars, and in combustion massed, / torn rocks, her ragged entrails, molten new, / the rumbling mount belched forth from out the boiling stew.
column4: Portus ab accessu ventorum immotus et ingens / ipse; sed horrificis juxta tonat Aetna ruinis, / interdumque atram prorumpit ad æthera nubem, / turbine fumantem piceo et candente favilla, / attollitque globos flammarum et sidera lambit, / interdum scopulos avulsaque viscera montis / erigit eructans, liquefactaque saxa sub auras / cum gemitu glomerat, fundoque exæstuat imo.

column2: But I saw thee lately throw six Carthusians into the dirt, so that they came out black instead of white. Thou in the mean time didst laugh, as if the thing had been well done.

column2: Henricus: But these old fellows are good. Hugitio: How knowest thou? Hen: Because I drank with them thrice by the road extraordinary good ale. Hug: Ha, ha, hae, so they are good with thee.
column4: Henricus: Sed hi seniculi sunt boni. Hugitio: Qui scis? Hen: Quia bibi per eos ter per viam insigniter bonam cerevisiam. Hug: Ha, ha, hae. Sic sunt boni tibi.

column4: Ibi experti sumus incredibilem humanitatem gentis, suppeditantis, nobis omnia, mira alacritate; hospitium, ignem, cibum, vestes, viaticum.

column2: Have you memorised it? "Not well enough perhaps."

column2: You start then, as you challenged me.

column2: Don't I recall it correctly? "Not well enough yet, read it again, again and again." "I'll do that."

column2: One, two, three, four, five, six, seven, eight, nine, and ten are numbers.

column2: Where have you come from? "I come from below." "What business did you have there?" "I went for a pee."

column2: I will not press you, nor can I really, but at least lend me your book. "Take it, use it as you please, but do not abuse it." "There’s nothing to worry about here."

column4: Causam itaque pulcherrimam hac certâ fiduciâ lati aggrediamur ; illinc fraudem, fallaeciam, ignorantiam, atque; barbariem; hinc lucem, veritatem, rationem, et seculorum ommium optimorum studia, atque; doctrinam nobiscum stare.

column2: The origin of Kings, you say, is as ancient as that of the sun.

column2: A king may easily make himself neither a father nor a king.

column2: But relating to the nature of the act, I say to you: our king was neither good, nor just, nor merciful, nor devout, nor godly, nor peacable, but an enemy who has been such for ten years, nor was he a father of his country, but a destroyer of it.
column4: Quod si de facti qualitate, tibi dici: nos regem neque bonum neque justum, neque clementem, neque religiosum, neque pium, neque pacificum; sed hostem prope decennalem nec parentem patriae, sed vastatoré de medio sustulisse.

column2: Has he given you money? "As he often does." "How much?" "Nothing to you."

column4: Quid dixit tibi? "Monuit me multis verbis, ut studerem diligenter." "Utinam facias sic." "Faciam, Deo juvante."

column2: It would be better to die a thousand times than suffer such infamy.

column4: Vide praeceptorem, qui jam ingreditur scholam. "Eamus auditum prælectionem."

column2: I am truly glad, for your sake and his, that he has returned from his travels safely. "You do as a friend should; but we will talk more tomorrow."
column4: Equidem plurimum gaudeo, tua causa et ejus, quod redieret peregre salvus. "Facis ut decet amicum; sed colloquemur cras pluribus verbis."

column2: You do well to hear others' opinions, who value your time. But how is your father? "Well, thanks be to God."
column4: Consulis bene tibi, qui habeas rationem temporis. Sed valetne pater? "Recte, Dei beneficio."

column2: Tom wants to learn how to ride a bicycle.
Tom wants to learn how to drive.
Learn that while I live, vile death comes.
column4: Discite, dum vivo mors inimica venis.

column2: It is better to dismiss than to request.
It is better to envy than to pity.
It is better to plead than to perish.
Out of the frying pan, into the fire.
Out of sight out of mind.
There's no feud like a family feud.
He's a slippery character, watch that he does not get out of your grasp.
I thought you had balls, it seems I was wrong.
You are teaching your grandmother to suck eggs.
You are the talk of the whole town.
While the pot boils, friendship lasts.
You will go and return not die in battle.
column4: Ibis redibis non morieris in bello.

column2: You will go and not return but die in battle.
column4: Ibis redibis non morieris in bello.
Nullum magnum ingenium sine mixtura dementiae.

column2: It never rains but it pours.
A pirate is an enemy to all mankind.
Laughter abounds in the mouths of fools.
If the cap fits, wear it.

I wish we could consider the kindnesses of God towards us as we do those of men. "May He allow us to exercise that thought more often and more diligently." "That really is necessary if we are going to experience His kindness more often."
column4: Utinam expenderemus tam beneficia Dei erga nos, quam solemus hominum. "Ille faxit, ut exerceamus nos in ea cogitatione, et sæpius, et diligentius." "Illud profecto est necessarium, si volumus experiri ejus benignitatem sæpius erga nos."

column2: It is not a small kindness, which has come from very good inclinations.
column4: Non est parvum beneficium, quod profectum est ab optima voluntate.

column2: I believe in very little, but you have often surprised me with your kindnesses. "They were nothing worth speaking about."
column4: Credo paucissimos, tamen tu provocasti me sæpe beneficiis. "Illa fuerunt adeo parva, ut non sint digna commemoratione."

column2: I got money from my father today, if you happen to need any. "I don't right now, but thanks a lot. You offer to do me a favour out of your own generosity and how many would do that?"
column4: Accepi pecuniam a patre hodie, si forte tibi est opus. "Mihi nihil opus est nunc, sed tamen ago tibi gratias maximas, quod pro tua liberalitate ultro offers mihi beneficium; nam quotusquisque facit id?"

column2: Extreme evil needs an extreme remedy.
Lend me tuppence. "It's not easy for me to make loans right now."
column4: Da mutuo mihi duos asses. "Nunc non est facile mihi dare mutuo."

column2: What's the problem? I know you were given money yesterday. "I did indeed, but I have to buy books and other things I need."
column4: Quid obstat? Scio te accepisse pecuniam hesterno die. "Accepi quidem, sed libri sunt emendi, et alia necessaria mihi."

column2: I don't wish to make things inconvenient. "When I have bought the things I need, if I have anything left, I will lend it to you."
column4: Nolo remorari tuum commodum. "Ubi emero quæ sunt opus mihi, si quid supersit, dabo mutuo."

column2: I admit it, but what then will you do with that money? "I will buy paper and other things I need."
column4: Fateor; sed tamen quid facies ista pecunia? "Emam chartam, et alia, quæ sunt opus mihi."

column2: What if you lose it? "I will put up with it patiently."
column4: Quid si amiseris? "Ferendum erit æquo animo."

column2: What if I happen to need something, will you give me a loan? "I will gladly lend something to you." "Thank you."
column4: Quid si forte eguero, dabisne mutuo? "Dabo mutuo, et libenter quidem." "Ago tibi gratias."

column2: Where is your father now? "I believe he is in Lyons."
column4: Ubi est tuus pater nunc? "Puto eum esse Lugduni."

column2: What is he doing there? "Trading." "Since when?" "Since the start of the fair."
column4: Quid agit illic? "Negotiatur." "E quo tempore?" "Ab ipso initio mercatus."

column2: I'm very surprised how long he dares to stay there, with such a great plague in that city. "It is not so surprising."
column4: Miror valde, qui audeat commorari illic tamdiu, cum sit tanta pestilentia in ea urbe. "Non est adeo mirandum."

column2: Does it seem so to you? "Yes, because he has been in greater danger many times, but the Lord God has always protected him."
column4: Itane videtur tibi? "Ita, profecto, nam fuit alias in majore periculo, sed Dominus Deus custodivit eum semper."

column2: I believe it indeed, and will guard him still. But when is he returning? "I don't know, we expect him every hour."
column4: Credo equidem, et custodiet eum adhuc. Sed quando est reversurus? "Nescio, expectamus in horas."

column2: God speed his return. "So I pray."
Where are you going now? "Straight home: farewell." "Farewell to you too."
column4: Quonam abis nunc? "Recta domum, vale." "Vale tu quoque."

column2: Why are you so happy? "Because my father has just arrived."
column4: Quid es ita laetus? "Quia pater meus modo venit."

column2: You don't say, where's he come from? "London."
When did he return? "Just now, as I just told you."
column4: Quando advenit? "Modo; ut dixi tibi jam."

column2: Have you already greeted him? "I will greet him as soon as he's got off his horse."
column4: Jamne salutavisti? "Salutavi quum descenderit ex equo."

column2: Birds of a feather flock together.
Without food and wine, love soon dies.
column4: Sine Cerere et Baccho friget Venus.

column2: All that glitters is not gold.
Plutus with his riches is full of fears.
Faint heart never won fair lady.
All the world's a stage, and all the men and women merely players.
Where there are friends, there is money.
What were you reading? "Something from the sacred scriptures."
How will it be done? "If you keep in mind that we are so dependent on God that we can do nothing without His help."
column4: Quomodo id fiet? "Si cogites sæpe, nos sic pendere a Deo ut possimus facere nihil sine ejus auxilio."

column2: Why are you laughing alone? "What business is it of yours?"
Thank you; give your father my greetings when he returns. "I'll do that; take care." "You take care as well."
column4: Ago tibi gratias; saluta patrem, ubi redierit, meo nomine. "Faciam ita; vale." "Vale tu quoque."

column2: Because maybe you're laughing at me. "Where does that suspicion come from?" "Because you're mean." "We are all mean, but I'm no worse than you. Then does no one laugh, unless he is laughing at someone?"
column4: Quia fortasse rides me. "Unde oritur ista suspicio?" "Quia es malus." "Omnes sumus mali quidem, at ego non sum pejor te. Nemo ridet igitur, nisi irrideat aliquem?"

column2: When do you expect your father to return? "Eight days from now."
column4: Quando expectas reditum patris?" "Ad octavum diem hinc."

column2: Where is your brother? "He just went home." "What's he doing there?" "Getting food for us."
column4: Ubi est tuus frater? "Ivit domum modo." "Quid eo?" "Petitum nobis opsonium."

column2: Why do you need food now? "It's for a late lunch."
column4: Quid opus est vobis opsonio nunc? "In merendam."

column2: Don't you have any in your box? "No." "Why not?" "Because my mother doesn't usually give us food, except for the present time."
column4: An non habetis in arca vestra? "Non." "Quid non?" "Quia mater non solet dare nobis opsonium, nisi in præsens tempus."

column2: Sure, because she knows you're gluttons. "How are we gluttons?" "Maybe because you devour at one meal what had been meant for three."
column4: Nempe, quia novit vos esse gulosos. "Quomodo sumus gulosi?" "Quia fortasse devoratis uno convictu, quod datum fuerat in tres."

column2: Shut up, I'm going to tell the teacher that you called us gluttons. "You shut up, I'm going to tell the teacher that your brother runs around all the time."
column4: Tace, ego dicam præceptori, te vocare nos gulosos. "Tace, ego dicam præceptori, fratrem tuum discurrere perpetuo."

column2: But he doesn't usually run around without the teacher's permission. "But he's deceiving the teacher." "How is he deceiving him?" "Well, it's not the teacher's intention for him to run around three times a day."
column4: Atqui non solet prodire, nisi cum bona venia præceptoris. "Atqui fallit præceptorem." "Quomodo fallit eum?" "Nam non est mens præceptoris, ut prodiat ter quotidie."

column2: Let him come; you will see what he answers. "No, let him see what he should answer to the teacher."
column4: Sine illum venire; videbis quid respondeat. "Imo, videat quid respondeat præceptori."

column2: How do you know the day? "My father wrote to me himself."
column4: Qui scis diem? "Pater ipse scripsit ad me."

column2: No words were able to admonish him.
Mary can't do that, can she?

column4: Qua de causa Thomas se occidit.

column2: How is it going? "Out of the frying pan, into the fire."
Out of the frying pan and into the fire.
What job did you do for her? "I often read to her."
column4: Quid officium præstabas illi? "Legebam ei sæpius."

column2: What do you mean by being absent for the whole week? "I had to stay at home." "What for?" "To be with my mother, who was sick."
column4: Quid sibi vult, quod abfueris hac tota hebdomade? "Oportuit me manere domi." "Quamobrem?" "Ut adessem matri, quæ ægrotabat."

column2: That was a holy and laudable service; if only everyone studied the word of God in this way. But what, did you do nothing else? "As often as necessary, I attended her with the maid."
column4: Istud fuit sanctum et laudabile ministerium; utinam omnes sic studerent verbo Dei. Sed quid! agebas nihil aliud? "Quoties erat opus, ministrabam illi cum ancilla."

column2: Take it, please, but where will you get it from in order to return it so soon? "After supper I will go home, and ask my mother." "What if she won't give it to you?" "She won't delay when I show her the book."
column4: Accipe, sed quæso, unde reddes tam cito? "A cœna ibo domum, ut petam a matre." "Quid, si nolit dare tibi?" "Non cunctabitur, cum ostendero illi librum."

column2: I don't mean that, but someone who laughs alone, I've often heard, is either a fool or up to some mischief.
column4: Non intelligo sic; sed qui ridet solus, ut audivi sæpe, aut est stultus, aut cogitat aliquid mali.

column2: There won't be any need, I hope. "But you don't know what will happen."
column4: Nihil opus erit, ut spero. "At nescis quid possit accidere."

column2: How? "I will lend you money in turn."
Will you give me the loan back then? "Don't doubt it, but if you need more, I will not only pay it back, but return the favour."
column4: Reddes mihi mutuum tunc? "Ne dubites, quin si tibi opus erit amplius, non modo reddam mutuum, sed etiam gratiam."

column2: His arrival, I hope, will make you richer. "I shall be richer than Croesus, if he comes with plenty of money."
column4: Adventus ejus, ut spero, ditabit te. "Ero ditior Crœso, si venerit bene nummatus."

column2: I wonder why you didn't stay at home given that he is coming. "He wouldn't have allowed it, nor would I want to, as the lesson is to be heard."
column4: Miror te non mansisse domi propter ejus adventum. "Nec ille permississet, nec ego vellem, præsertim nunc, cum prælectio est audienda."

column2: What else did you do for him? "I pulled off his boots and greaves."
column4: Quid amplius fecisti illi? "Detraxi calcaria et ocreas."

column2: How money do you have? "A penny and a half; how much do you have?" "Not as much." "How much then?" "One penny."
column4: Quantum pecuniæ habes? "Assem cum semisse; quantum habes tu?" "Non tantum." "Quantum igitur?" "Unicum assem."

column2: Will you lend it to me? "I need it?" "For what?" "To buy paper."
column4: Vis dare mutuo mihi? "Est mihi opus." "In quem usum?" "Ad emendam chartam."

column2: I will give it back today. "You should have added, 'with God's help'."
column4: Reddam tibi hodie. "Addendum fuit, Deo juvante."

column2: So the master teaches from God's words, but I can't get used to it. "Get used to it."
column4: Sic præceptor docet ex verbo Dei, sed non possum assuescere. "Fac assuescas."

column2: You give me good advice. "As you would give me."
column4: Das mihi bonum consilium. "Quale velim dari mihi."

column2: But coming back to the point, will you lend me that penny? "I do wonder about you asking to borrow from me, given that you have more than me."
column4: Sed ut redeamus ad propositum, dabis mutuo mihi istum assem? "Miror te petere mutuo a me, qui habes plus quam ego."

column2: There is a scholar passing this way who is offering a book for sale. "So what then?" "I wanted to buy it, because he's offering it cheaper than our bookseller."
column4: Est quidam scholasticus transiens hac, qui ostentat librum venalem. "Quid tum?" "Cupio emere, quia indicat vilius quam noster bibliopola."

column2: How much money do you have?
However much you have, you will want more.
The fear of God is the start of wisdom.
Once said, a word cannot be taken back.
Why are you laughing at me?
But wait! Didn't you do anything else?
What do you mean by being absent the whole week?
column4: Quid sibi vult, quod abfueris hac tota hebdomade?

column2: I got money from my father today if you happen to need any.
column4: Accepi pecuniam a patre hodie, si forte tibi est opus.

column2: What if she won't give it to you?
He has gone to the library.
How big is your dog? Mine is small.
column4: Quam magnus est canis tuus? Meus parvus est.

column2: Will you give it to me?
Tom wanted me to give you this.
column4: Thomas voluit ut tibi hoc darem.

column2: Didn't you walk her to the door?
column4: Nonne eam ad ianuam comitatus es?

column2: Tom is caught between a rock and a hard place.
Between a rock and a hard place.
He is reputed the best lawyer in this city.
column4: Is optimum advocatum urbis huius esse putatur.

column2: I'll buy paper, and other things that I need.
column4: Emam chartam, et alia quae sunt opus mihi.

column2: Can I have a second helping?
The roof of my house is red.
I want to see you tomorrow.
My brother lives in a small village.
column4: Frater meus in parvo vico habitat.

column2: It's true that the earth is round.
Tom has to tell the truth.
My mother can't drive a car.
column4: Mater mea raedam gubernare non potest.

column2: I have to get my watch repaired.
Seeing Brutus, Caesar said, "You also, Brutus, my son!"
column4: Videns Brutum Cæsar dixit: Tu quoque, Brute, fili mi!

column2: Herod, seeing that he had been tricked by the wise men, was so enraged that he sent and killed all the boys who were in Bethlehem, and in all the region around it, two years old and under, according to the time which he had ascertained from the wise men.
column4: Herodes, videns se a magis illusum esse, adeo iratus est, ut miserit interfectum pueros, quotquot Bethlehemae, et in toto eius territorio erant, infra bimatum, pro tempore quod a magis perquisierat.

column2: What's the highest mountain in the world?
Are you studying or are you working?
He went to London a month ago.
He went to London two years ago.
column4: AD LONDONIUM VENIVIT ANTE ANNO DUO

column2: Tom is a very good friend.
There is a dog in this room.
I want to improve my Spanish.
Are you sure you know what you're doing?
column4: Num certus es te scire quod facias?

column2: He went back to the hotel.
Don't you ever leave me on my own.
She killed him with a knife.
Even a child can read this.
Even a child can do it.
I'm not your enemy. I'm your friend.
I know that I'm a good teacher.
I know I'm a good teacher.
My name is Tom and I'm an alcoholic.
column4: Nomen mihi Thomas est. Ebriosus sum.

column2: You can choose whichever color you like.
column4: Aliquem colorem tibi placet, licet tibi eligere.

column2: Bats usually fly in the dark.
column4: Vespertiliones de more in tenebris volant.

column2: Despite all his faults, everybody likes him.
column4: Plurimis defectibus non obstantibus, omnes eum amant.

column2: I don't know what Tom's last name is.
And when the sun was going down, a deep sleep fell upon Abram; and, lo, an horror of great darkness fell upon him.
column4: Cumque sol occumberet, sopor irruit super Abram, et ecce horror magnus et tenebrosus invasit eum.

column2: How many cats are there in this house?
column4: Quot feles sunt in hoc domo?

column2: How do you like your eggs done?
Are you pleased with your new house?
I can't believe Tom and Mary are dead.
column4: Non possum credere Thomam Mariamque mortuos esse.

column2: We have three dogs, one white and two black.
column4: Tres canes nobis sunt, unus albus et duo nigri.

column2: The problem is difficult to solve.
I've lived here for thirty years.
If you don't eat, you die.
The magazine comes out once a week.
column4: Semel in hebdomade commentarii periodici eduntur.

column2: It seems to me that you're wrong.
This book was written by many people.
column4: Hic liber a multis hominibus scriptus est.

column2: The rabbit is known for its long ears.
I went to see my uncle, but he wasn't home.
The table is made of wood.
Have you been to Brazil? "I went there two or three times."
column4: Ivitne in Brasiliam? "Bis vel ter illuc iter fecit."

column2: I'm not allowed to go outside.
He set out on a long journey.
Next year he will be six years old.
column4: Proximo anno sex annos natus erit.

column2: Paul went back with his father.
Tom left Rome, the city he had lived in since he was a boy.
column4: Thomas Roma abiit, qua in urbe a puero habitaverat.

column2: This book was written by two people.
column4: Hic liber a duobus hominibus scriptus est.

column2: Which university are you studying at?
Which university are you studying at?
Tom didn't come to school today.
column4: Hodie Thomas ad ludum non venit.

column2: The wind calmed down in the evening.
What do you see in this image?
And the earth was of one tongue, and of the same speech.
column4: Erat autem terra labii unius, et sermonum eorumdem.

column2: And when they removed from the east, they found a plain in the land of Sennaar, and dwelt in it.
column4: Cumque proficiscerentur de oriente, invenerunt campum in terra Sennaar et habitaverunt in eo.

column2: And each one said to his neighbour: Come, let us make brick, and bake them with fire. And they had brick instead of stones, and slime instead of mortar.
column4: Dixitque alter ad proximum suum: Venite, faciamus lateres et coquamus eos igni. Habueruntque lateres pro saxis et bitumen pro cæmento.

column2: And they said: Come, let us make a city and a tower, the top whereof may reach to heaven; and let us make our name famous before we be scattered abroad into all lands.
column4: Et dixerunt: Venite, faciamus nobis civitatem et turrim, cuius culmen pertingat ad cælum, et celebremus nomen nostrum, ne dividamur super faciem universæ terræ.

column2: And the Lord came down to see the city and the tower which the children of Adam were building.
column4: Descendit autem Dominus, ut videret civitatem et turrim, quam ædificaverunt filii hominum.

column2: And he said: Behold, it is one people, and all have one tongue: and they have begun to do this, neither will they leave off from their designs till they accomplish them in deed.
column4: Et dixit Dominus: Ecce unus est populus et unum labium omnibus; et hoc est initium operationis eorum, nec eis erit deinceps difficile, quidquid cogitaverint facere.

column2: Come ye, therefore, let us go down and there confound their tongue, that they may not understand one another's speech.
column4: Venite igitur, descendamus et confundamus ibi linguam eorum, ut non intellegat unusquisque vocem proximi sui.

column2: And so the Lord scattered them from that place into all lands, and they ceased to build the city.
column4: Atque ita divisit eos Dominus ex illo loco super faciem universæ terræ, et cessaverunt ædificare civitatem.

column2: And therefore the name thereof was called Babel, because there the language of the whole earth was confounded: and from thence the Lord scattered them abroad upon the face of all countries.
column4: Et idcirco vocatum est nomen eius Babel, quia ibi confusum est labium universæ terræ, et inde dispersit eos Dominus super faciem universæ terræ.

column2: And the Lord said to Abram: Go forth out of thy country, and from thy kindred, and out of thy father's house, and come into the land which I shall shew thee.
column4: Dixit autem Dominus ad Abram: Egredere de terra tua et de cognatione tua et de domo patris tui in terram, quam monstrabo tibi.

column2: And I will make of thee a great nation, and I will bless thee, and magnify thy name, and thou shalt be blessed.
column4: Faciamque te in gentem magnam et benedicam tibi et magnificabo nomen tuum, erisque in benedictionem.

column2: I will bless them that bless thee, and curse them that curse thee, and in thee shall all the kindreds of the earth be blessed.
column4: Benedicam benedicentibus tibi et maledicentibus tibi maledicam, atque in te benedicentur universæ cognationes terræ.

column2: So Abram went out as the Lord had commanded him, and Lot went with him: Abram was seventy five years old when he went forth from Haran.
column4: Egressus est itaque Abram, sicut præceperat ei Dominus, et ivit cum eo Lot. Septuaginta quinque annorum erat Abram cum egrederetur de Charran.

column2: Abram passed through the country unto the place of Sichem, as far as the noble vale: now the Canaanite was at that time in the land.
column4: Pertransivit Abram terram usque ad locum Sichem, usque ad Quercum Moreh. Chananæus autem tunc erat in terra.

column2: And the Lord appeared to Abram and said to him: To thy seed will I give this land. And he built there an altar to the Lord, who had appeared to him.
column4: Apparuit autem Dominus Abram et dixit ei: "Semini tuo dabo terram hanc." Qui ædificavit ibi altare Domino, qui apparuerat ei.

column2: And passing on from thence to a mountain that was on the east side of Bethel, he there pitched his tent, having Bethel on the west and Hai on the east: he built there also an altar to the Lord, and called upon his name.
