column4: Et inde transgrediens ad montem, qui erat contra orientem Bethel, tetendit ibi tabernaculum suum ab occidente habens Bethel et ab oriente Hai; ædificavit quoque ibi altare Domino et invocavit nomen Domini.

column2: And Abram went forward, going and proceeding on to the south.
column4: Porrexitque Abram de mansione in mansionem usque ad Nageb.

column2: And there came a famine in the country: and Abram went down into Egypt, to sojourn there: for the famine was very grievous in the land.
column4: Facta est autem fames in terra; descenditque Abram in Aegyptum, ut peregrinaretur ibi; prævaluerat enim fames in terra.

column2: And Rachel seeing herself without children, envied her sister, and said to her husband: Give me children, otherwise I shall die.
column4: Cernens autem Rachel quod infecunda esset, invidit sorori et ait marito suo: Da mihi liberos, alioquin moriar.

column2: And Jacob being angry with her, answered: Am I as God, who hath deprived thee of the fruit of thy womb?
column4: Cui iratus respondit Iacob: Num pro Deo ego sum, qui privavit te fructu ventris?

column2: But she said: I have here my servant Bala: go in unto her, that she may bear upon my knees, and I may have children by her.
column4: At illa: Ecce, inquit, famula mea Bilha; ingredere ad illam, ut pariat super genua mea, et habeam ex illa et ego filios.

column2: And she gave him Bala in marriage: who, when her husband had gone in unto her, conceived and bore a son.
column4: Deditque illi Bilham famulam suam in coniugium. Quæ, ingresso ad se Iacob, concepit et peperit filium.

column2: And Rachel said: The Lord hath judged for me, and hath heard my voice, giving me a son; and therefore she called his name Dan.
column4: Dixitque Rachel: “Iudicavit mihi Deus et exaudivit vocem quoque meam dans mihi filium”; et idcirco appellavit nomen illius Dan.

column2: And again Bala conceived, and bore another, for whom Rachel said: God hath compared me with my sister, and I have prevailed: and she called him Nephthali.
column4: Rursumque Bilha famula Rachel concepit et peperit Iacob alterum filium, et ait Rachel: "Certamina Dei certavi cum sorore mea et invalui”; vocavitque eum Nephthali.

column2: Lia perceiving that she had left of bearing, gave Zelpha, her handmaid, to her husband. And when she had conceived, and brought forth a son, she said: Happily. And therefore called his name Gad.
column4: Sentiens Lia quod parere desisset, sumpsit Zelpham ancillam suam et tradidit eam Iacob in uxorem. Quæ peperit Iacob filium. Dixitque Lia: “Feliciter!”; et idcirco vocavit nomen eius Gad.
Peperit quoque Zelpha ancilla Liæ Iacob alterum filium.

column2: And Lia said: This is for my happiness: for women will call me blessed. Therefore she called him Aser.
column4: Dixitque Lia: “Pro beatitudine mea! Beatam quippe me dicent mulieres”; propterea appellavit eum Aser.

column2: And Ruben going out in the time of the wheat harvest into the field, found mandrakes, which he brought to his mother Lia. And Rachel said: Give me part of thy son's mandrakes.
column4: Egressus autem Ruben tempore messis triticeæ, repperit in agro mandragoras, quas Liæ matri suæ detulit. Dixitque Rachel: Da mihi partem de mandragoris filii tui.

column2: She answered: Dost thou think it a small matter, that thou hast taken my husband from me, unless thou take also my son's mandrakes? Rachel said: He shall sleep with thee this night, for thy son's mandrakes.
column4: Illa respondit: “Parumne tibi videtur, quod præripueris maritum mihi, ut etiam mandragoras filii mei auferas?” Ait Rachel: “Dormiat ergo tecum hac nocte pro mandragoris filii tui”.

column2: And when he was near to enter into Egypt, he said to Sarai his wife: I know that thou art a beautiful woman, and that when the Egyptians shall see thee, they will say: She is his wife, and they will kill me and keep thee.
column4: Cumque prope esset, ut ingrederetur Aegyptum, dixit Sarai uxori suæ: Novi quod pulchra sis mulier et quod, cum viderint te Aegyptii, dicturi sunt: "Uxor ipsius est"; et interficient me et te reservabunt.

column2: Say, therefore, I pray thee, that thou art my sister, that I may be well used for thee, and that my soul may live for thy sake.
column4: Dic ergo, obsecro te, quod soror mea sis, ut bene sit mihi propter te, et vivat anima mea ob gratiam tui.

column2: And when Abram was come into Egypt, the Egyptians saw the woman that she was very beautiful.
column4: Cum itaque ingressus esset Abram Aegyptum, viderunt Aegyptii mulierem quod esset pulchra nimis.

column2: And the princes told Pharaoh, and praised her before him, and the woman was taken into the house of Pharaoh.
column4: Et viderunt eam principes pharaonis et laudaverunt eam apud illum; et sublata est mulier in domum pharaonis.

column2: And they used Abram well for her sake. And he had sheep and oxen and he-asses, and men servants, and maid servants, and she-asses, and camels.
column4: Abram vero bene usus est propter illam; fueruntque ei oves et boves et asini et servi et famulæ et asinæ et cameli.

column2: But the Lord scourged Pharaoh and his house with most grievous stripes for Sarai, Abram's wife.
column4: Flagellavit autem Dominus pharaonem plagis maximis et domum eius propter Sarai uxorem Abram.

column2: And Pharaoh called Abram, and said to him: What is this that thou hast done to me? Why didst thou not tell me that she was thy wife?
column4: Vocavitque pharao Abram et dixit ei: Quidnam est hoc quod fecisti mihi? Quare non indicasti mihi quod uxor tua esset?

column2: For what cause didst thou say, she was thy sister, that I might take her to my wife? Now therefore there is thy wife, take her, and go thy way.
column4: Quam ob causam dixisti esse sororem tuam, ut tollerem eam mihi in uxorem? Nunc igitur, ecce coniux tua: accipe eam, et vade!

column2: And Pharaoh gave his men orders concerning Abram, and they led him away and his wife, and all that he had.
column4: Præcepitque pharao super Abram viris; et deduxerunt eum et uxorem illius et omnia, quæ habebat.

column2: And when Jacob returned at even from the field, Lia went out to meet him, and said: Thou shalt come in unto me because I have hired thee for my son's mandrakes. And he slept with her that night.
column4: Redeuntique ad vesperam Iacob de agro egressa est in occursum eius Lia et: “Ad me, inquit, intrabis, quia mercede conduxi te pro mandragoris filii mei”. Dormivitque cum ea nocte illa.

column2: And God heard her prayers; and she conceived: and bore a fifth son. And said: God hath given me a reward, because I gave my handmaid to my husband. And she called his name Issachar.
column4: Et exaudivit Deus Liam, concepitque et peperit Iacob filium quintum et ait: “Dedit Deus mercedem mihi, quia dedi ancillam meam viro meo”; appellavitque nomen illius Issachar.

column2: And Lia conceived again, and bore the sixth son. And said: God hath endowed me with a good dowry; this turn also my husband will be with me, because I have borne him six sons: and therefore she called his name Zabulon.
column4: Rursum Lia concepit et peperit Iacob sextum filium et ait: “Donavit me Deus dono bono; hac vice honorabit me maritus meus, eo quod genuerim ei sex filios”; et idcirco appellavit nomen eius Zabulon.

column2: After whom she bore a daughter, named Dina.
column4: Post quem peperit filiam nomine Dinam.

column2: The Lord, also remembering Rachel, heard her and opened her womb.
column4: Recordatus quoque Deus Rachelis exaudivit eam Deus et aperuit vulvam illius.

column2: And she conceived, and bore a son, saying: God hath taken away my reproach. And she called his name Joseph, saying: The Lord give me also another son.
column4: Quæ concepit et peperit filium dicens: “Abstulit Deus opprobrium meum”; et vocavit nomen illius Ioseph dicens: “Addat mihi Dominus filium alterum!”

column2: And when Joseph was born, Jacob said to his father-in-law: Send me away, that I may return into my country, and to my land.
column4: Nato autem Ioseph, dixit Iacob ad Laban: Dimitte me, ut revertar in patriam et ad terram meam.

column2: Give me my wives, and my children, for whom I have served thee, that I may depart: thou knowest the service that I have rendered thee.
column4: Da mihi uxores et liberos meos, pro quibus servivi tibi, ut abeam; tu nosti servitutem, qua servivi tibi.

column2: Laban said to him: Let me find favour in thy sight. I have learned, by experience, that God hath blessed me for thy sake.
column4: Ait illi Laban: Inveniam gratiam in conspectu tuo; augurio didici, quia benedixerit mihi Deus propter te.

column2: Appoint thy wages which I shall give thee.
column4: Constitue mercedem tuam, quam dem tibi.

column2: But he answered: Thou knowest how I have served thee, and how great thy possession hath been in my hands.
column4: At ille respondit: Tu nosti quomodo servierim tibi et quanti in manibus meis facti sint greges tui.

column2: Thou hadst but little before I came to thee, and now thou art become rich, and the Lord hath blessed thee at my coming. It is reasonable, therefore, that I should now provide also for my oun house.
column4: Modicum habuisti, antequam venirem ad te, et nunc multiplicatum est vehementer, benedixitque tibi Dominus ad introitum meum. Nunc autem quando providebo etiam domui meæ?

column2: And Laban said: What shall I give thee? But he said: I require nothing, but if thou wilt do what I demand, I will feed and keep thy sheep again.
column4: Dixitque Laban: “Quid tibi dabo?” At ille ait: “Nihil mihi dabis; si feceris, quod postulo, iterum pascam et custodiam pecora tua".

column2: Go round through all thy flocks, and separate all the sheep of divers colours, and speckled; and all that is brown and spotted, and of divers colours, as well among the sheep as among the goats, shall be my wages.
column4: Gyrabo omnes greges tuos hodie; separa cuncta pecora varia et maculosa et, quodcumque furvum in ovibus et maculosum variumque in capris fuerit, erit merces mea.

column2: And my justice shall answer for me tomorrow before thee, when the time of the bargain shall come; and all that is not of divers colours, and spotted, and brown, as well among the sheep as among the goats, shall accuse me of theft.
column4: Respondebitque mihi cras iustitia mea; quando veneris, ut inspicias mercedem meam, omnia, quæ non fuerint varia et maculosa in capris et furva in ovibus, furti me arguent.

column2: And Laban said: I like well what thou demandest.
column4: Dixit Laban: Gratum habeo, quod petis!

column2: And he separated the same day the she-goats, and the sheep, and the he-goats, and the rams of divers colours, and spotted; and all the flock of one colour, that is, of white and black fleece, he delivered into the hands of his sons.
column4: Et separavit in die illo hircos striatos atque maculosos et omnes capras varias et maculosas, omne, in quo album erat, et omne furvum in ovibus, et tradidit in manu filiorum suorum.

column2: And he set the space of three days journey betwixt himself and his son-in-law, who fed the rest of his flock.
column4: Et posuit spatium itineris trium dierum inter se et Iacob, qui pascebat reliquos greges Laban.

column2: And Jacob took green rods of poplar, and of almond, and of plane-trees, and pilled them in part; so when the bark was taken off, in the parts that were pilled, there appeared whiteness; but the parts that were whole remained green; and by this means the colour was divers.
column4: Tollens ergo Iacob virgas virides populeas et amygdalinas et ex platanis, ex parte ita decorticavit eas, ut in his, quæ spoliata fuerant, candor appareret.

column2: And he put them in the troughs, where the water was poured out; that when the flocks should come to drink, they might have the rods before their eyes, and in the sight of them might conceive.
column4: Posuitque virgas, quas ex parte decorticaverat, in canalibus, ubi effundebatur aqua, ut, cum venissent greges ad bibendum, ante oculos haberent virgas et in aspectu earum conciperent.

column2: And it came to pass, that in the very heat of coition, the sheep beheld the rods, and brought forth spotted, and of divers coulours, and speckled.
column4: Factumque est ut in ipso calore coitus greges intuerentur virgas et parerent striata et varia et maculosa.

column2: And Jacob separated the flock, and put the rods in the troughs before the eyes of the rams; and all the white and the black were Laban's, and the rest were Jacob's, when the flocks were separated one from the other.
column4: Agnos autem segregavit Iacob et posuit gregem ex adverso striatorum et omnium furvorum in grege Laban et constituit sibi greges seorsum neque statuit eos cum grege Laban.

column2: So when the ewes went first to ram, Jacob put the rods in the troughs of water before the eyes of the rams, and of the ewes, that they might conceive while they were looking upon them.
column4: Quotiescumque igitur calefiebant pecora robusta, ponebat Iacob virgas in canalibus aquarum ante oculos pecorum, ut in earum contemplatione conciperent.

column2: But when the later coming was, and the last conceiving, he did not put them. And those that were lateward became laban's; and they of the first time Jacob's. And the man was enriched exceedingly, and he had many flocks, maid-servants and men-servants, camels and asses.
column4: Quando vero pecora debilia erant, non ponebat eas. Factaque sunt debilia Laban et robusta Iacob; ditatusque est homo ultra modum et habuit greges multos, ancillas et servos, camelos et asinos.

column2: And Abram went up out of Egypt he and his wife, and all that he had, and Lot with him into the south.
column4: Ascendit ergo Abram de Aegypto ipse et uxor eius et omnia, quæ habebat, et Lot cum eo ad Nageb.

column2: And he was very rich in possession of gold and silver.
column4: Abram autem erat dives valde in pecoribus, argento et auro.

column2: And he returned by the way that he came from the south to Bethel, to the place where before he had pitched his tent between Bethel and Hai, in the place of the altar which he had made before, and there he called upon the name of the Lord.
column4: Et profectus est de mansione in mansionem a Nageb in Bethel usque ad locum, ubi prius fixerat tabernaculum inter Bethel et Hai, in loco altaris, quod fecerat prius, et invocavit ibi nomen Domini.

column2: But Lot also, who was with Abram, had flocks of sheep, and herds of beasts, and tents.
column4: Sed et Lot, qui erat cum Abram, fuerunt greges ovium et armenta et tabernacula.

column2: Neither was the land able to bear them, that they might dwell together: for their substance was great, and they could not dwell together.
column4: Nec poterat eos capere terra, ut habitarent simul: erat quippe substantia eorum multa, et nequibant habitare communiter.

column2: Whereupon also there arose a strife between the herdsmen of Abram and Lot. And at that time the Chanaanite and the Pherezite dwelled in that country.
column4: Unde et facta est rixa inter pastores gregum Abram et pastores gregum Lot. Eo autem tempore Chananæus et Pherezæus habitabant in terra illa.

column2: Abram therefore said to Lot: Let there be no quarrel, I beseech thee, between me and thee, and between my herdsmen and thy herdsmen: for we are brethren.
column4: Dixit ergo Abram ad Lot: Ne, quæso, sit iurgium inter me et te et inter pastores meos et pastores tuos: fratres enim sumus.

column2: Behold the whole land is before thee: depart from me, I pray thee: if thou wilt go to the left hand, I will take the right: if thou choose the right hand, I will pass to the left.
column4: Nonne universa terra coram te est? Recede a me, obsecro: si ad sinistram ieris, ego dexteram tenebo; si tu dexteram elegeris, ego ad sinistram pergam.

column2: And Lot lifting up his eyes saw all the country about the Jordan, which was watered throughout, before the Lord destroyed Sodom and Gomorrah, as the paradise of the Lord, and like Egypt as one comes to Segor.
column4: Elevatis itaque Lot oculis, vidit omnem circa regionem Iordanis, quæ universa irrigabatur, antequam subverteret Dominus Sodomam et Gomorram, sicut paradisus Domini et sicut Aegyptus usque in Segor.

column2: And Lot chose to himself the country about the Jordan, and he departed from the east: and they were separated one brother from the other.
column4: Elegitque sibi Lot regionem circa Iordanem et recessit ab oriente; divisique sunt alterutrum a fratre suo.

column2: Abram dwelt in the land of Canaan, and Lot abode in the towns that were about the Jordan, and dwelt in Sodom.
column4: Abram habitavit in terra Chanaan; Lot vero moratus est in oppidis, quæ erant circa Iordanem, et tabernacula movit usque ad Sodomam.

column2: And the men of Sodom were very wicked, and sinners before the face of the Lord beyond measure.
column4: Homines autem Sodomitæ pessimi erant et pecatores coram Domino nimis.

column2: And the Lord said to Abram, after Lot was separated from him: Lift up thy eyes, and look from the place wherein thou now art, to the north and to the south, to the east and to the west.
column4: Dixitque Dominus ad Abram, postquam divisus est Lot ab eo: Leva oculos tuos et vide a loco, in quo nunc es, ad aquilonem et meridiem, ad orientem et occidentem.

column2: All the land which thou seest, I will give to thee, and to thy seed for ever.
column4: Omnem terram, quam conspicis, tibi dabo et semini tuo usque in sempiternum.

column2: And I will make thy seed as the dust of the earth: if any man be able to number the dust of the earth, he shall be able to number thy seed also.
column4: Faciamque semen tuum sicut pulverem terræ: si quis potest hominum numerare pulverem terræ, semen quoque tuum numerare poterit.

column2: Arise and walk through the land in the length, and in the breadth thereof: for I will give it to thee.
column4: Surge et perambula terram in longitudine et in latitudine sua, quia tibi daturus sum eam.

column2: So Abram removing his tent came and dwelt by the vale of Mambre, which is in Hebron: and he built there an altar to the Lord.
column4: Movens igitur tabernaculum suum, Abram venit et habitavit iuxta Quercus Mambre, quæ sunt in Hebron, ædificavitque ibi altare Domino.

column2: But after that he had heard the words of the sons of Laban, saying: Jacob hath taken away all that was our father's, and being enriched by his substance is become great. And perceiving also, that Laban's countenance was not towards him as yesterday and the other day.
column4: Postquam autem audivit verba filiorum Laban dicentium: “Tulit Iacob omnia, quæ fuerunt patris nostri, et de patris nostri facultate acquisivit has divitias”, animadvertit quoque faciem Laban quod non esset erga se sicut heri et nudiustertius.

column2: Especially the Lord saying to him: Return into the land of thy fathers and to thy kindred, and I will be with thee.
column4: Et dixit Dominus ad Iacob: Revertere in terram patrum tuorum et ad cognationem tuam, eroque tecum.

column2: He sent, and called Rachel and Lia into the field, where he fed the flocks, and said to them: I see your father's countenance is not towards me as yesterday and the other day: but the God of my father hath been with me. And you know that I have served your father to the uttermost of my power.
column4: Misit Iacob et vocavit Rachel et Liam in agrum, ubi pascebat greges, dixitque eis: Video faciem patris vestri quod non sit erga me sicut heri et nudiustertius; Deus autem patris mei fuit mecum, et ipsæ nostis quod totis viribus meis servierim patri vestro.

column2: Yea your father hath also overreached me, and hath changed my wages ten times: and yet God hath not suffered him to hurt me.
column4: Sed pater vester circumvenit me et mutavit mercedem meam decem vicibus; et tamen non dimisit eum Deus, ut noceret mihi.

column2: If at any time he said: The speckled shall be thy wages, all the sheep brought forth speckled; but when he said on the contrary: Thou shalt take all the white one for thy wages, all the flocks brought forth white ones.
column4: Si quando dixit: "Variæ erunt mercedes tuæ", pariebant omnes oves varios fetus. Quando vero e contrario ait: "Striata quæque accipies pro mercede", omnes greges striata pepererunt.

column2: And God hath taken your father's substance, and given it to me.
column4: Tulitque Deus substantiam patris vestri et dedit mihi.

column2: For after the time came of the ewes conceiving, I lifted up my eyes and saw in my sleep that the males which leaped upon the females were of divers colours, and spotted, and speckled.
column4: Postquam enim conceptus gregis tempus advenerat, levavi oculos meos et vidi in somnis ascendentes mares super feminas, striatos et varios et respersos.

column2: And the angel of God said to me in my sleep: Jacob. And I answered: Here I am. And he said: Lift up thy eyes, and see that all the males leaping upon the females are of divers colours, spotted and speckled. For I have seen all that Laban hath done to thee.
column4: Dixitque angelus Dei ad me in somnis: "Iacob". Et ego respondi: "Adsum". Qui ait: "Leva oculos tuos et vide universos masculos ascendentes super feminas, striatos et varios atque respersos. Vidi enim omnia, quæ fecit tibi Laban".

column2: I am the God of Bethel, where thou didst anoint the stone, and make a vow to me. Now therefore arise, and go out of this land, and return into thy native country.
column4: Ego sum Deus Bethel, ubi unxisti lapidem et votum vovisti mihi. Nunc ergo surge et egredere de terra hac revertens in terram nativitatis tuæ.

column2: Hath he not counted us as strangers, and sold us, and eaten up the price of us?
column4: Nonne quasi alienas reputavit nos et vendidit nos comeditque pretium nostrum?

column2: But God hath taken our father's riches, and delivered them to us, and to our children: wherefore, do all that God hath commanded thee.
column4: Sed omnes opes, quas tulit Deus patri nostro, nobis abstulit ac filiis nostris; unde omnia, quæ præcepit tibi Deus, fac.

column2: Then Jacob rose up, and having set his children and wives upon camels, went his way.
column4: Surrexit itaque Iacob et imposuit liberos suos ac coniuges suas super camelos.

column2: And he took all his substance, and flocks, and whatsoever he had gotten in Mesopotamia, and went forward to Isaac, his father, to the land of Canaan.
column4: Tulitque omnes greges suos et omnem substantiam suam, quidquid in Paddanaram acquisierat, ut iret ad Isaac patrem suum in terram Chanaan.

column2: At that time Laban was gone to sheer his sheep, and Rachel stole away her father's idols.
column4: Eo tempore Laban ierat ad tondendas oves, et Rachel furata est theraphim patris sui.

column2: And Jacob would not confess to his father-in-law that he was flying away.
column4: Iacob autem decepit cor Laban, non indicans ei quod fugeret.

column2: And when he was gone, together with all that belonged to him, and having passed the river, was going on towards mount Galaad, it was told Laban on the third day, that Jacob fled.
column4: Cumque fugisset cum omnibus, quæ possidebat, et, amne transmisso, pergeret contra montem Galaad, nuntiatum est Laban die tertio quod fugisset Iacob.

column2: And he took his brethren with him, and pursued after him seven days; and overtook him in the mount of Galaad.
column4: Qui, assumptis fratribus suis, persecutus est eum diebus septem et comprehendit eum in monte Galaad.

column2: And he saw in a dream God, saying to him: Take heed thou speak not any thing harshly against Jacob.
column4: Venit autem Deus ad Laban Aramæum per somnium noctis dixitque ei: Cave, ne quidquam loquaris contra Iacob!

column2: Now Jacob had pitched his tent in the mountain; and when he, with his brethren, had overtaken him, he pitched his tent in the same mount of Galaad.
column4: Iamque Iacob extenderat in monte tabernaculum, cum Laban, consecutus eum cum fratribus suis, in eodem monte Galaad fixit tentorium.

column2: And he said to Jacob: Why hast thou done thus, to carry away, without my knowledge, my daughters as captives taken with the sword?
column4: Et dixit ad Iacob: Quare ita egisti et decepisti cor meum, abigens filias meas quasi captivas gladio?

column2: Why wouldst thou run away privately, and not acquaint me, that I might have brought thee on the way with joy, and with songs, and with timbrels, and with harps?
column4: Cur clam fugisti et decepisti me, non indicans mihi, ut prosequerer te cum gaudio et canticis et tympanis et citharis?

column2: Thou hast not suffered me to kiss my sons and daughters; thou hast done foolishly; and now indeed it is in my power to return thee evil; but the God of your father said to me yesterday: Take heed thou speak not any thing harshly against Jacob.
column4: Non es passus, ut oscularer filios meos ac filias; stulte operatus es. Et nunc valet quidem manus mea reddere tibi malum, sed Deus patris vestri heri dixit mihi: Cave, ne loquaris contra Iacob quidquam!

column2: Suppose thou didst desire to go to thy friends, and hadst a longing after thy father's house: why hast thou stolen away my gods?
column4: Esto, profectus es, quia desiderio tibi erat domus patris tui; cur furatus es deos meos?

column2: Jacob answered: That I departed unknown to thee, it was for fear lest thou wouldst take away thy daughters by force.
column4: Respondit Iacob: Quia timui. Dixi enim, ne forte violenter auferres filias tuas a me.

column2: But, whereas thou chargest me with theft, with whomsoever thou shalt find thy gods, let him be slain before our brethren. Search, and if thou find any of thy things with me, take them away. Now when he said this, he knew not that Rachel had stolen the idols.
column4: Apud quemcumque inveneris deos tuos, non vivat! Coram fratribus nostris scrutare, quidquid tuorum apud me inveneris, et aufer. Ignorabat enim Iacob quod Rachel furata esset theraphim.

column2: So Laban went into the tent of Jacob, and of Lia, and of both the handmaids, and found them not. An when he was entered into Rachel's tent, she, in haste, hid the idols under the camel's furniture, and sat upon them.
column4: Ingressus itaque Laban tabernacula Iacob et Liæ et utriusque famulæ, non invenit. Egressus de tentorio Liæ, intravit tentorium Rachelis. Illa autem absconderat theraphim in stramento cameli et sedit desuper.

column2: And when he had searched all the tent, and founding nothing, she said: Let not my lord be angry that I cannot rise up before thee, because it has now happened to me according to the custom of women. So his careful search was in vain.
column4: Scrutantique omne tentorium et nihil invenienti ait: “Ne irascatur dominus meus, quod coram te assurgere nequeo, quia iuxta consuetudinem feminarum nunc accidit mihi”. Quæsivit ergo et non invenit theraphim.

column2: And Jacob being angry said in a chiding manner: For what fault of mine, and for what offence on my part hast thou so hotly pursued me, and searched all my household stuff? What hast thou found of all the substance of thy house? lay it here before my brethren, and thy brethren, and let them judge between me and thee.
column4: Tumensque Iacob cum iurgio ait: Quam ob culpam meam et ob quod peccatum meum sic persecutus es me, quia scrutatus es omnem supellectilem meam? Quid invenisti de cuncta substantia domus tuæ? Pone hic coram fratribus meis et fratribus tuis, et iudicent inter me et te.

column2: Have I therefore been with thee twenty years? thy ewes and goats were not barren, the rams of thy flocks I did not eat; neither did I shew thee that which the beast had torn; I made good all the damage: whatsoever was lost by theft, thou didst exact it of me.
column4: Ecce, viginti annis fui tecum. Oves tuæ et capræ non abortiverunt, arietes gregis tui non comedi; nec dilaceratum a bestia ostendi tibi: ego damnum omne reddebam; quidquid die noctuque furto perierat, a me exigebas.

column2: Day and night was I parched with heat, and with frost, and sleep departed from my eyes.
column4: Die æstu consumebar et nocte gelu, fugiebatque somnus ab oculis meis.

column2: And in this manner have I served thee in thy house twenty years, fourteen for thy daughters, and six for thy flocks: thou hast changed also my wages ten times.
column4: Sic per viginti annos in domo tua servivi tibi: quattuordecim pro filiabus et sex pro gregibus tuis; immutasti quoque mercedem meam decem vicibus.

column2: Unless the God of my father, Abraham, and the fear of Isaac had stood by me, peradventure now thou hadst sent me away naked: God beheld my affliction and the labour of my hands, and rebuked thee yesterday.
column4: Nisi Deus patris mei, Deus Abraham et Timor Isaac, affuisset mihi, certemodo nudum me dimisisses; afflictionem meam et laborem manuum mearum respexit Deus et iudicavit heri.

column2: Laban answered him: The daughters are mine, and the children, and thy flocks, and all things that thou seest are mine: what can I do to my children, and grandchildren?
column4: Respondit ei Laban: Filiæ filiæ meæ et filii filii mei et greges greges mei et omnia, quæ cernis, mea sunt; et filiabus meis quid possum facere illis hodie et filiis earum, quos genuerunt?

column2: Come, therefore, let us enter into a league; that it may be for a testimony between me and thee.
column4: Veni ergo, et ineamus fœdus ego et tu, ut sit in testimonium inter me et te.

column2: And Jacob took a stone, and set it up for a title. And he said to his brethren: Bring hither stones. And they, gathering stones together, made a heap, and they ate upon it.
column4: Tulit itaque Iacob lapidem et erexit illum in titulum; dixitque fratribus suis: “Afferte lapides”. Qui congregantes fecerunt tumulum comederuntque ibi super eum.

column2: And Laban called it 'The witness heap'; and Jacob, 'The hillock of testimony': each of them according to the propriety of his language.
column4: Quem vocavit Laban Iegarsahadutha (id est Tumulus testimonii), et Iacob Galed (uterque iuxta proprietatem linguæ suæ).

column2: And Laban said: This heap shall be a witness between me and thee this day, and therefore the name thereof was called Galaad, that is, The witness heap. The Lord behold and judge between us, when we shall be gone one from the other.
column4: Dixitque Laban: “Tumulus iste testis erit inter me et te hodie”; et idcirco appellatum est nomen eius Galed (id est Tumulus testis) et etiam Maspha (id est Specula), quia dixit: “Speculetur Dominus inter me et te, quando absconditi erimus ab invicem".

column2: If thou afflict my daughters, and if thou bring in other wives over them: none is witness of our speech but God, who is present and beholdeth.
column4: Si afflixeris filias meas et si introduxeris uxores alias super eas, cum nemo nobiscum sit, vide, Deus est testis inter me et te.

column2: And he said again to Jacob: Behold this heap, and the stone which I have set up between me and thee, shall be a witness: this heap, I say, and the stone, be they for a testimony, if either I shall pass beyond it going towards thee, or thou shalt pass beyond it thinking harm to me.
column4: Dixitque Laban ad Iacob: En tumulus hic et lapis, quem erexi inter me et te. Testis erit tumulus iste et lapis quod ego non transibo tumulum hunc pergens ad te, neque tu transibis tumulum hunc et lapidem hunc ad malum.

column2: The God of Abraham, and the God of Nachor, the God of their father, judge between us. And Jacob swore by the fear of his father Isaac. And after he had offered sacrifices in the mountain, he called his brethren to eat bread. And when they had eaten, they lodged there.
column4: Deus Abraham et Deus Nachor iudicent inter nos. Iuravit Iacob per Timorem patris sui Isaac; immolatisque victimis in monte, vocavit fratres suos, ut ederent panem. Qui cum comedissent, pernoctaverunt in monte.

column2: But Laban arose in the night, and kissed his sons and daughters, and blessed them: and returned to his place.
column4: Laban vero de nocte consurgens osculatus est filios et filias suas et benedixit illis reversusque est in locum suum.

column2: Iacob also went on the journey he had begun: and the angels of God met him.
column4: Iacob quoque abiit itinere, quo cœperat, fueruntque ei obviam angeli Dei.

column2: And when he saw them, he said: These are the camps of God, and called the name of that place Mahanaim, that is, Camps.
column4: Quos cum vidisset, ait: "Castra Dei sunt hæc”; et appellavit nomen loci illius Mahanaim (id est Castra).

column2: And he sent messengers before him to Esau, his brother, to the land of Seir, to the country of Edom.
column4: Misit autem nuntios ante se ad Esau fratrem suum in terram Seir, in regionem Edom.

column2: And he commanded them, saying: Thus shall ye speak to my lord Esau: Thus saith thy brother Jacob: I have sojourned with Laban, and have been with him until this day. I have oxen, and asses, and sheep, and menservants, and womenservants: and now I send a message to my lord, that I may find favour in thy sight.
column4: Præcepitque eis dicens: Sic loquimini domino meo Esau: "Hæc dicit servus tuus Iacob: 'Apud Laban peregrinatus sum et fui usque in præesentem diem. Habeo boves et asinos, oves et servos atque ancillas; mittoque nunc legationem ad dominum meum, ut inveniam gratiam in conspectu tuo'".

column2: And the messengers returned to Jacob, saying: We came to Esau, thy brother, and behold he cometh with speed to meet thee with four hundred men.
column4: Reversique sunt nuntii ad Iacob dicentes: Venimus ad Esau fratrem tuum, et ecce properat in occursum tibi cum quadringentis viris.

column2: Then Jacob was greatly afraid; and in his fear divided the people that was with him, and the flocks, and the sheep, and the oxen, and the camels, into two companies, saying: If Esau come to one company, and destroy it, the other company that is left shall escape.
column4: Timuit Iacob valde et perterritus divisit populum, qui secum erat, greges quoque et oves et boves et camelos in duas turmas dicens: Si venerit Esau ad unam turmam et percusserit eam, alia turma, quæ reliqua est, salvabitur.

column2: And Jacob said: O God of my father Abraham, and God of my father Isaac: O Lord who saidst to me, Return to thy land, and to the place of thy birth, and I will do well for thee, I am not worthy of the least of all thy mercies, and of thy truth which thou hast fulfilled to thy servant.
column4: Dixitque Iacob: Deus patris mei Abraham et Deus patris mei Isaac, Domine, qui dixisti mihi: "Revertere in terram tuam et in locum nativitatis tuæ, et benefaciam tibi", minor sum cunctis miserationibus et cuncta veritate, quam explesti servo tuo.

column2: With my staff I passed over this Jordan; and now I return with two companies. Deliver me from the hand of my brother Esau, for I am greatly afraid of him; lest perhaps he come and kill the mother with the children.
column4: In baculo meo transivi Iordanem istum et nunc cum duabus turmis regredior. Erue me de manu fratris mei, de manu Esau, quia valde eum timeo; ne forte veniens percutiat matrem cum filiis.

column2: Thou didst say that thou wouldst do well by me, and multiply my seed like the sand of the sea, which cannot be numbered for multitude.
column4: Tu locutus es quod bene mihi faceres et dilatares semen meum sicut arenam maris, quæ præ multitudine numerari non potest.

column2: And when he had slept there that night, he set apart, of the things which he had, presents for his brother Esau: two hundred she-goats, twenty he-goats, two hundred ewes, and twenty rams, thirty milch camels with their colts, forty kine, and twenty bulls, twenty she-asses, and ten of their foals.
column4: Mansit ibi nocte illa et sumpsit de his, quæ habebat, munera Esau fratri suo: capras ducentas, hircos viginti, oves ducentas et arietes viginti, camelos fetas cum pullis suis triginta, vaccas quadraginta et tauros decem, asinas viginti et pullos earum decem.

column2: What do you have in your hand?
And he sent them by the hands of his servants, every drove by itself, and he said to his servants: Go before me, and let there be a space between drove and drove.
column4: Et misit per manus servorum suorum singulos seorsum greges dixitque pueris suis: “Antecedite me, et sit spatium inter gregem et gregem”.

column2: And he commanded the first, saying: If thou meet my brother Esau, and he ask thee: Whose art thou? or whither goest thou? or whose are these before thee? thou shalt answer: Thy servant Jacob's: he hath sent them as a present to my lord Esau; and he cometh after us.
column4: Et præcepit priori dicens: Si obvium habueris Esau fratrem meum, et interrogaverit te: "Cuius es?" et "Quo vadis?" et "Cuius sunt ista, quæ sequeris?", respondebis: "Servi tui Iacob; munera misit domino meo Esau. Ipse quoque post nos venit”.

column2: In like manner he commanded the second, and the third, and all that followed the droves, saying: Speak ye the same words to Esau, when ye find him. And ye shall add: Thy servant Jacob himself also followeth after us; for he said: I will appease him with the presents that go before, and afterwards I will see him, perhaps he will be gracious to me.
column4: Similiter mandata dedit secundo ac tertio et cunctis, qui sequebantur greges, dicens: "Iisdem verbis loquimini ad Esau, cum inveneritis eum, et addetis: Ipse quoque servus tuus Iacob iter nostrum insequitur". Dixit enim: Placabo illum muneribus, quæ præcedunt, et postea videbo faciem eius: forsitan propitiabitur mihi.

column2: So the presents went before him, but himself lodged that night in the camp.
column4: Præcesserunt itaque munera ante eum, ipse vero mansit nocte illa in castris.

column2: And rising early, he took his two wives and his two handmaids, with his eleven sons, and passed over the ford of Jaboc. And when all things were brought over that belonged to him, he remained alone; and behold, a man wrestled with him till morning.
column4: Cumque nocte surrexisset, tulit duas uxores suas et totidem famulas cum undecim filiis et transivit vadum Iaboc; sumptis ergo traductisque illis et omnibus, quæ ad se pertinebant, per torrentem, mansit solus. Et ecce vir luctabatur cum eo usque mane.

column2: And when he saw that he could not overcome him, he touched the sinew of his thigh, and forthwith it shrank.
column4: Qui cum videret quod eum superare non posset, tetigit acetabulum femoris eius, et statim luxatum est acetabulum femoris Iacob, cum luctaretur cum illo.

column2: And he said to him: Let me go, for it is break of day. He answered: I will not let thee go, except thou bless me.
column4: Dixitque: “Dimitte me, iam enim ascendit aurora”. Respondit: “Non dimittam te, nisi benedixeris mihi”.

column2: And he said: What is thy name? He answered: Jacob.
column4: Ait ad eum: “Quod nomen est tibi?” Respondit: “Iacob”.

column2: But he said: Thy name shall not be called Jacob, but Israel; for if thou hast been strong against God, how much more shalt thou prevail against men?
column4: At ille: “Nequaquam, inquit, Iacob amplius appellabitur nomen tuum, sed Israel: quoniam certasti cum Deo et cum hominibus et prævaluisti!”

column2: Jacob asked him: Tell me by what name art thou called? He answered: Why dost thou ask my name? And he blessed him in the same place.
column4: Interrogavit eum Iacob: “Dic mihi, quo appellaris nomine?” Respondit: “Cur quæris nomen meum?” Et benedixit ei in eodem loco.

column2: And Jacob called the name of the place Phanuel, saying: I have seen God face to face, and my soul has been saved.
column4: Vocavitque Iacob nomen loci illius Phanuel dicens: Vidi Deum facie ad faciem, et salva facta est anima mea.

column2: And immediately the sun rose upon him, after he was past Phanuel; but he halted on his foot.
column4: Ortusque est ei sol, cum transgrederetur Phanuel; ipse vero claudicabat propter femur.

column2: Therefore the children of Israel, unto this day, eat not the sinew, that shrank in Jacob's thigh: because he touched the sinew of his thigh and it shrank.
column4: Quam ob causam non comedunt filii Israel nervum, qui est in femore, usque in præsentem diem, eo quod tetigerit nervum femoris Iacob.

column2: And Jacob lifting up his eyes, saw Esau coming, and with him four hundred men: and he divided the children of Lia and of Rachel, and of the two handmaids.
column4: Elevans autem Iacob oculos suos vidit venientem Esau et cum eo quadringentos viros; divisitque filios Liæ et Rachel ambarumque famularum.

column2: And he put both the handmaids and their children foremost: and Lia and her children in the second place: and Rachel and Joseph last.
column4: Et posuit utramque ancillam et liberos earum in principio, Liam vero et filios eius in secundo loco, Rachel autem et Ioseph novissimos.

column2: And he went forward and bowed down with his face to the ground seven times, until his brother came near.
column4: Et ipse prægrediens adoravit pronus in terram septies, donec appropinquaret ad fratrem suum.

column2: Then Esau ran to meet his brother, and embraced him: and clasping him fast about the neck, and kissing him, wept.
column4: Currens itaque Esau obviam fratri suo amplexatus est eum; stringensque collum eius osculatus est eum, et fleverunt.
Quam vetus est illa tabula picta?

column2: And lifting up his eyes, he saw the women and their children, and said: What mean these? And do they belong to thee? He answered: They are the children which God hath given to me, thy servant.
column4: Levatisque oculis, vidit mulieres et liberos earum et ait: “Qui sunt isti tibi?” Respondit: “Liberi sunt, quos donavit mihi Deus servo tuo".

column2: Then the handmaids and their children came near and bowed themselves.
column4: Et appropinquantes ancillæ et filii earum incurvati sunt.

column2: Lia also, with her children, came near and bowed down in like manner; and last of all, Joseph and Rachel bowed down.
column4: Accessit quoque Lia cum liberis suis et, cum similiter adorassent, extremi Ioseph et Rachel adoraverunt.

column2: And Esau said: What are the droves that I met? He answered: That I might find favour before my lord.
column4: “Quænam sunt, inquit, istæ turmæ, quas obvias habui?” Respondit: “Ut invenirem gratiam coram domino meo”.

column2: But he said: I have plenty, my brother, keep what is thine for thyself.
column4: At ille: Habeo, ait, plurima, frater mi; sint tua tibi.

column2: And Jacob said: Do not so I beseech thee, but if I have found favour in thy eyes, receive a little present at my hands: for I have seen thy face, as if I should have seen the countenance of God: be gracious to me.
column4: Dixit Iacob: Noli ita, obsecro; sed, si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, accipe munusculum de manibus meis; sic enim vidi faciem tuam quasi viderim vultum Dei, et mihi propitius fuisti.

column2: Take the blessing which I have brought thee, and which God hath given me, who gives all things.
column4: Suscipe, quæso, benedictionem, quæ allata est tibi; quia Deus misertus est mihi, et habeo omnia.

column2: He took it with much ado at his brother's earnest pressing him, and said: Let us go together, and I will accompany thee in thy journey.
column4: Et, cum compelleret illum, suscepit et ait: Gradiamur simul, eroque socius itineris tui.

column2: And Jacob said: My lord, thou knowest that I have with me tender children, and sheep, and kine with young: which if I should cause to be overdriven, in one day all the flocks will die.
column4: Dixit Iacob: Nosti, domine mi, quod parvulos habeam teneros et oves et boves fetas mecum; quas si plus in ambulando fecero laborare vel una die, morientur cuncti greges.

column2: Now when these things were done, the word of the Lord came to Abram by a vision, saying: Fear not, Abram, I am thy protector, and thy reward exceeding great.
column4: His itaque transactis, factus est sermo Domini ad Abram per visionem dicens: Noli timere, Abram! Ego protector tuus sum, et merces tua magna erit nimis.

column2: And Abram said: Lord God, what wilt thou give me? I shall go without children: and the son of the steward of my house is this Damascus Eliezer.
column4: Dixitque Abram: Domine Deus, quid dabis mihi? Ego vadam absque liberis, et heres domus meæ erit Damascenus Eliezer.

column2: And Abram added: But to me thou hast not given seed: and lo my servant born in my house shall be my heir.
column4: Addiditque Abram: En mihi non dedisti semen, et ecce vernaculus meus heres meus erit.

column2: And immediately the word of the Lord came to him, saying : He shall not be thy heir: but he that shall come out of thy bowels, him shalt thou have for thy heir.
column4: Sed ecce sermo Domini factus est ad eum: Non erit hic heres tuus, sed qui egredietur de visceribus tuis, ipsum habebis heredem.

column2: And he brought him forth abroad, and said to him: Look up to heaven and number the stars if thou canst. And he said to him: So shall thy seed be.
column4: Eduxitque eum foras, et ait illi: Suspice cælum, et numera stellas, si potes. Et dixit ei: Sic erit semen tuum.

column2: Abram believed God, and it was reputed to him unto justice.
column4: Credidit Deo, et reputatum est ei ad iustitiam.

column2: And he said to him: I am the Lord who brought thee out from Ur of the Chaldees, to give thee this land, and that thou mightest possess it.
column4: Dixitque ad eum: Ego Dominus, qui eduxi te de Ur Chaldæorum, ut darem tibi terram istam, et possideres eam.

column2: But he said: Lord God, whereby may I know that I shall possess it?
column4: Et ille ait: Domine Deus, unde scire possum quod possessurus sim eam?

column2: And the Lord answered, and said: Take me a cow of three years old, and a she-goat of three years. and a ram of three years, a turtle also, and a pigeon.
column4: Respondens Dominus: Sume, inquit, mihi vitulam triennem et capram trimam et arietem annorum trium, turturem quoque et columbam.

column2: And he took all these, and divided them in the midst, and laid the two pieces of each one against the other: but the birds he divided not.
column4: Qui tollens universa hæc divisit ea per medium et utrasque partes contra se altrinsecus posuit; aves autem non divisit.

column2: And the fowls came down upon the carcasses, and Abram drove them away.
column4: Descenderuntque volucres super cadavera, et abigebat eas Abram.

column2: And it was said unto him: Know thou beforehand that thy seed shall be a stranger in a land not their own, and they shall bring them under bondage, and afflict them four hundred years.
column4: Dictumque est ad eum: Scito prænoscens quod peregrinum futurum sit semen tuum in terra non sua, et subicient eos servituti et affligent quadringentis annis.

column2: But I will judge the nation which they shall serve, and after this they shall come out with great substance.
column4: Verumtamen et gentem, cui servituri sunt, ego iudicabo, et post hæc egredientur cum magna substantia.

column2: And thou shalt go to thy fathers in peace, and be buried in a good old age.
column4: Tu autem ibis ad patres tuos in pace, sepultus in senectute bona.

column2: Tom is getting married next month.
What's the name of this bird?
May it please my lord to go before his servant: and I will follow softly after him, as I shall see my children to be able, until I come to my lord in Seir.
column4: Præcedat dominus meus ante servum suum; et ego sequar paulatim secundum gressum pecorum ante me et secundum gressum parvulorum, donec veniam ad dominum meum in Seir.

column2: Esau answered: I beseech thee, that some of the people, at least, who are with me, may stay to accompany thee in the way. And he said: There is no necessity. I want nothing else but only to find favour, my lord, in thy sight.
column4: Respondit Esau: "Oro te, ut de populo, qui mecum est, saltem socii remaneant viae tuæ". "Non est, inquit, necesse; hoc uno indigeo, ut inveniam gratiam in conspectu domini mei”.

column2: So Esau returned that day, the way that he came, to Seir.
column4: Reversus est itaque illo die Esau itinere suo in Seir.

column2: And Jacob came to Socoth: where having built a house, and pitched tents, he called the name of the place Socoth, that is, Tents.
column4: Et Iacob venit in Succoth, ubi, ædificata sibi domo et fixis tentoriis pro gregibus suis, appellavit nomen loci illius Succoth (id est Tabernacula).

column2: And he passed over to Salem, a city of the Sichemites, which is in the land of Canaan, after he returned from Mesopotamia of Syria: and he dwelt by the town.
column4: Transivitque Iacob incolumis ad urbem Sichem, quæ est in terra Chanaan, cum veniret de Paddanaram; et habitavit iuxta oppidum.

column2: And he bought that part of the field, in which he pitched his tents, of the children of Hemor, the father of Sichem, for a hundred lambs.
column4: Emitque partem agri, in qua fixerat tabernaculum suum, a filiis Hemmor patris Sichem centum argenteis.

column2: And raising an altar there, he invoked upon it the most mighty God of Israel.
column4: Et erexit ibi altare et vocavit illud: Deus est Deus Israel.

column2: And Dina the daughter of Lia went out to see the women of that country.
column4: Egressa est autem Dina filia, quam Lia pepererat Iacob, ut videret filias regionis illius.

column2: And when Sichem the son of Hemor the Hevite, the prince of that land, saw her, he was in love with her: and took her away, and lay with her, ravishing the virgin.
column4: Quam cum vidisset Sichem filius Hemmor Hevæi principis terræ illius, adamavit eam et rapuit; et dormivit cum illa, vi opprimens illam.

column2: But in the fourth generation they shall return hither: for as yet the iniquities of the Amorrhites are not at the full until this present time.
column4: Generatione autem quarta revertentur huc; necdum enim completæ sunt iniquitates Amorhæorum usque ad præsens tempus.

column2: And when the sun was set, there arose a dark mist, and there appeared a smoking furnace, and a lamp of fire passing between those divisions.
column4: Cum ergo occubuisset sol, facta est caligo tenebrosa, et apparuit clibanus fumans et lampas ignis transiens inter divisiones illas.

column2: Now Sarai, the wife of Abram, had brought forth no children: but having a handmaid, an Egyptian, named Agar, she said to her husband: Behold, the Lord hath restrained me from bearing: go in unto my handmaid, it may be I may have children of her at least.
column4: Sarai autem uxor Abram non genuerat ei liberos; sed habens ancillam Aeyptiam nomine Agar, dixit marito suo: Ecce conclusit me Dominus, ne parerem; ingredere ad ancillam meam, si forte saltem ex illa suscipiam filios.

column2: And when he agreed to her request, she took Agar the Egyptian her handmaid, ten years after they first dwelt in the land of Canaan, and gave her to her husband to wife.
column4: Cumque ille acquiesceret deprecanti, tulit Agar ægyptiam ancillam suam post annos decem quam habitare cœperant in terra Chanaan, et dedit eam viro suo uxorem.

column2: And he went in to her. But she perceiving that she was with child, despised her mistress.
column4: Qui ingressus est ad eam. At illa concepisse se videns despexit dominam suam.

column2: And Sarai said to Abram: Thou dost unjustly with me: I gave my handmaid into thy bosom, and she perceiving herself to be with child, despiseth me. The Lord judge between me and thee.
column4: Dixitque Sarai ad Abram: Inique agis contra me; ego dedi ancillam meam in sinum tuum, quæ videns quod conceperit, despectui me habet. Iudicet Dominus inter me et te.

column2: And Abram made answer, and said to her: Behold thy handmaid is in thy own hand, use her as it pleaseth thee. And when Sarai afflicted her, she ran away.
column4: Cui respondens Abram: Ecce, ait, ancilla tua in manu tua est, utere ea ut libet. Affligente igitur eam Sarai, aufugit ab ea.

column2: And the angel of the Lord having found her by a fountain of water in the wilderness, which is in the way to Sur in the desert, he said to her: Agar, handmaid of Sarai, whence comest thou? and whither goest thou?
column4: Cumque invenisset illam angelus Domini iuxta fontem aquæ in deserto, ad fontem in via Sur, dixit: Agar, ancilla Sarai, unde venis et quo vadis?

column2: And she answered: I flee from the face of Sarai, my mistress.
column4: Quæ respondit: A facie Sarai dominæ meæ ego fugio.

column2: And the angel of the Lord said to her: Return to thy mistress, and humble thyself under her hand.
column4: Dixitque ei angelus Domini: Revertere ad dominam tuam et humiliare sub manibus ipsius.

column2: And again he said: I will multiply thy seed exceedingly, and it shall not be numbered for multitude.
column4: Et dixit ei angelus Domini: Multiplicans multiplicabo semen tuum, et non numerabitur præ multitudine.

column2: And again: Behold, said he, thou art with child, and thou shalt bring forth a son: and thou shalt call his name Ismael, because the Lord hath heard thy affliction.
column4: Et dixit ei angelus Domini: "Ecce, concepisti et paries filium vocabisque nomen eius Ismael, eo quod audierit Dominus afflictionem tuam.

column2: He shall be a wild man: his hand will be against all men, and all men's hands against him: and he shall pitch his tents over against all his brethren.
column4: Hic erit homo onagro similis; manus eius contra omnes, et manus omnium contra eum; et e regione universorum fratrum suorum figet tabernacula.

column2: And she called the name of the Lord that spoke unto her: Thou the God who hast seen me. For she said: Verily, here have I seen the hinder parts of him that seeth me.
column4: Vocavit autem nomen Domini, qui loquebatur ad eam: "Tu Deus, qui vidisti me". Dixit enim: "Profecto hic vidi posteriora videntis me".

column2: And Agar brought forth a son to Abram: who called his name Ismael.
column4: Peperitque Agar Abræ filium; qui vocavit nomen filii sui, quem peperat Agar, Ismael.

column2: Abram was four score and six years old when Agar brought him forth Ismael.
column4: Octoginta et sex annorum erat Abram quando peperit ei Agar Ismaelem.

column2: And after he began to be ninety and nine years old, the Lord appeared to him: and said unto him: I am the Almighty God: walk before me, and be perfect.
column4: Postquam Abram nonaginta et novem annorum factus est, apparuit ei Dominus dixitque ad eum: Ego Deus omnipotens, ambula coram me et esto perfectus.

column2: And I will make my covenant between me and thee: and I will multiply thee exceedingly.
column4: Ponamque fœdus meum inter me et te et multiplicabo te vehementer nimis.

column2: Abram fell flat on his face. And God said to him: I am, and my covenant is with thee, and thou shalt be a father of many nations. Neither shall thy name be called any more Abram: but thou shalt be called Abraham: because I have made thee a father of many nations.
column4: Cecidit Abram pronus in faciem. Dixitque ei Deus: Ecce pactum meum tecum. Erisque pater multarum gentium, nec ultra vocabitur nomen tuum Abram, sed Abraham erit nomen tuum, quia patrem multarum gentium constitui te.

column2: And I will make thee increase exceedingly, and I will make nations of thee, and kings shall come out of thee.
column4: Faciamque te crescere vehementissime et ponam te in gentes; regesque ex te egredientur.

column2: And I will establish my covenant between me and thee, and between thy seed after thee in their generations, by a perpetual covenant: to be a God to thee, and to thy seed after thee.
column4: Et statuam pactum meum inter me et te et inter semen tuum post te in generationibus suis fœdere sempiterno, ut sim Deus tuus et seminis tui post te.

column2: An I will give to thee, and to thy seed, the land of thy sojournment, all the land of Canaan, for a perpetual possession, and I will be their God.
column4: Daboque tibi et semini tuo post te terram peregrinationis tuæ, omnem terram Chanaan in possessionem æternam; eroque Deus eorum.

column2: Again God said to Abraham: And thou therefore shalt keep my covenant, and thy seed after thee in their generations.
column4: Dixit iterum Deus ad Abraham: Tu autem pactum meum custodies, et semen tuum post te in generationibus suis.

column2: This is my covenant which you shall observe between me and you, and thy seed after thee: All the male-kind of you shall be circumcised. And you shall circumcise the flesh of your foreskin, that it may be for a sign of the covenant between me and you.
column4: Hoc est pactum meum, quod observabitis, inter me et vos et semen tuum post te. Circumcidetur ex vobis omne masculinum, et circumcidetis carnem præputii vestri, ut sit in signum fœderis inter me et vos.

column2: An infant of eight days old shall be circumcised among you, every manchild in your generations: he that is born in the house, as well as the bought servant, shall be circumcised, and whosoever is not of your stock.
column4: Infans octo dierum circumcidetur in vobis: omne masculinum in generationibus vestris, tam vernaculus quam empticius ex omnibus alienigenis, quicumque non fuerit de stirpe vestra.

column2: The male whose flesh of his foreskin shall not be circumcised, that soul shall be destroyed out of his people: because he hath broken my covenant.
column4: Masculus, cuius præputii caro circumcisa non fuerit, delebitur anima illa de populo suo; pactum meum irritum fecit.

column2: He that is born in the house, as well as the bought servant, shall be circumcised, and my covenant shall be in your flesh for a perpetual covenant.
column4: Circumcidetur vernaculus et empticius, eritque pactum meum in carne vestra in fœdus æternum.

column2: God said also to Abraham: Sarai thy wife thou shalt not call Sarai, but Sara.
column4: Dixit quoque Deus ad Abraham: Sarai uxorem tuam non vocabis nomen eius Sarai, sed Sara erit nomen eius.

column2: And I will bless her, and of her I will give thee a son, whom I will bless, and he shall become nations, and kings of people shall spring from him.
column4: Et benedicam ei; et ex illa quoque dabo tibi filium. Benedicturus sum eam, eritque in nationes; reges populorum orientur ex ea.

column2: Abraham fell upon his face, and lauĝed, saying in his heart: Shall a son, thinkest thou, be born to him that is a hundred years old? and shall Sara that is ninety years old bring forth?
column4: Cecidit Abraham in faciem suam et risit dicens in corde suo: Putasne centenario nascetur filius? Et Sara nonagenaria pariet?

column2: And he said to God: O that Ismael may live before thee.
column4: Dixitque ad Deum: Utinam Ismael vivat coram te.

column2: And God said to Abraham: Sara thy wife shall bear thee a son, and thou shalt call his name Isaac, and I will establish my covenant with him for a perpetual covenant, and with his seed after him.
column4: Et ait Deus: Sara uxor tua pariet tibi filium, vocabisque nomen eius Isaac; et constituam pactum meum illi in fœdus sempiternum et semini eius post eum.

column2: And as for Ismael I have also heard thee. Behold, I will bless him, and increase, and multiply him exceedingly: he shall beget twelve chiefs, and I will make him a great nation.
column4: Super Ismael quoque exaudivi te: ecce benedicam ei et crescere faciam et multiplicabo eum vehementissime; duodecim duces generabit, et faciam illum in gentem magnam.

column2: But my covenant I will establish with Isaac, whom Sara shall bring forth to thee at this time in the next year.
column4: Pactum vero meum statuam ad Isaac, quem pariet tibi Sara tempore isto in anno altero.

column2: And when he had left off speaking with him, God went up from Abraham.
column4: Cumque cessasset loqui cum eo, ascendit Deus ab Abraham.

column2: And Abraham took Ismael his son, and all that were born in his house: and all whom he had bought, every male among the men of his house: and he circumcised the flesh of their foreskin forthwith the very same day, as God had commanded him.
column4: Tulit ergo Abraham Ismael filium suum et omnes vernaculos domus suæ universosque, quos emerat: cunctos mares ex omnibus viris domus suæ; et circumcidit carnem præputii eorum statim in ipsa die, sicut præceperat ei Deus.

column2: Abraham was ninety and nine years old, when he circumcised the flesh of his foreskin, and Ismael his son was full thirteen years old at the time of his circumcision. .
column4: Abraham nonaginta novem erat annorum, quando circumcisus est in carne præputii sui; et Ismael filius eius tredecim annos impleverat tempore circumcisionis suæ.

column2: The self-same day was Abraham circumcised and Ismael his son. And all the men of his house, as well they that were born in his house, as the bought servants and strangers, were circumcised with him.
column4: Eadem die circumcisus est Abraham et Ismael filius eius; et omnes viri domus illius, tam vernaculi, quam empticii ex alienigenis, circumcisi sunt cum eo.

column2: And the Lord appeared to him in the vale of Mambre as he was sitting at the door of his tent, in the very heat of the day.
column4: Apparuit autem ei Dominus iuxta Quercus Mambre sedenti in ostio tabernaculi sui in ipso fervore diei.

column2: And when he had lifted up his eyes, there appeared to him three men standing near to him: and as soon as he saw them, he ran to meet them from the door of his tent, and adored down to the ground.
column4: Cumque elevasset oculos, apparuerunt ei tres viri stantes prope eum. Quos cum vidisset, cucurrit in occursum eorum de ostio tabernaculi ed adoravit in terram.

column2: And he said: Lord, if I have found favour in thy sight, pass not away from thy servant.
column4: Et dixit: Domine mi, si inveni gratiam in oculis tuis, ne transeas servum tuum.

column2: But I will fetch a little water, and wash ye your feet, and rest ye under the tree.
column4: Afferatur pauxillum aquæ, et lavate pedes vestros et requiescite sub arbore.

column2: And I will set a morsel of bread, and strengthen ye your heart, afterwards you shall pass on: for therefore are you come aside to your servant.
column4: Ponamque buccellam panis, et confortate cor vestrum, postea transibitis; idcirco enim declinastis ad servum vestrum.

column2: And they said: Do as thou hast spoken.
column4: Qui dixerunt: Fac ut locutus es.

column2: Abraham made haste into the tent to Sara, and said to her: Make haste, temper together three measures of flour, and make cakes upon the hearth.
column4: Festinavit Abraham in tabernaculum ad Saram dixitque: Accelera, tria sata similæ commisce et fac subcinericios panes.

column2: And he himself ran to the herd, and took from thence a calf, very tender and very good, and gave it to a young man, who made haste and boiled it.
column4: Ipse vero ad armentum cucurrit et tulit inde vitulum tenerrimum et optimum deditque puero; qui festinavit et coxit illum.

column2: He took also butter and milk, and the calf which he had boiled, and set before them: but he stood by them under the tree.
column4: Tulit quoque butyrum et lac et vitulum, quem coxerat, et posuit coram eis. Ipse vero stabat iuxta eos sub arbore; et comederunt.

column2: And when they had eaten, they said to him: Where is Sara thy wife? He answered: Lo she is in the tent.
column4: Dixeruntque ad eum: "Ubi est Sara uxor tua?" Ille respondit: "Ecce in tabernaculo est".

column2: And he said to him: I will return and come to thee at this time, life accompanying, and Sara, thy wife, shall have a son. Which when Sara heard, she laughed behind the door of the tent.
column4: Cui dixit: "Revertens veniam ad te tempore isto, et habebit filium Sara uxor tua". Quo audito, Sara risit ad ostium tabernaculi, quod era post eum.

column2: Now they were both old, and far advanced in years, and it had ceased to be with Sara after the manner of women.
column4: Erant autem ambo senes provectæque ætatis, et desierant Saræ fieri muliebria.

column2: And she laughed secretly, saying: After I am grown old, and my lord is an old man, shall I give myself to pleasure?
column4: Quæ risit occulte dicens: Postquam consenui, et dominus meus vetulus est, voluptas mihi erit?

column2: And the Lord said to Abraham: Why did Sara laugh, saying: Shall I, who am an old woman, bear a child indeed?
column4: Dixit autem Dominus ad Abraham: Quare risit Sara dicens: "Num vere paritura sum anus?"

column2: Is there any thing hard to God? According to appointment I will return to thee at this same time, life accompanying, and Sara shall have a son.
column4: Numquid Domino est quidquam difficile? Revertar ad te hoc eodem tempore, et habebit Sara filium.

column2: Sara denied, saying: I did not laugh: for she was afraid. But the Lord said: Nay; but thou didst laugh.
column4: Negavit Sara dicens: "Non risi", timore perterrita. Ille autem dixit: "Non; sed risisti".

column2: And when the men rose up from thence, they turned their eyes towards Sodom: and Abraham walked with them, bringing them on the way.
column4: Cum ergo surrexissent inde viri, direxerunt oculos contra Sodomam; et Abraham simul gradiebatur deducens eos.

column2: And the Lord said: Can I hide from Abraham what I am about to do, seeing he shall become a great and mighty nation, and in him all the nations of the earth shall be blessed?
column4: Dixitque Dominus: Num celare potero Abraham, quæ gesturus sum, cum futurus sit gentem magnam ac robustissimam, et benedicendæ sint in illo omnes nationes terræ?

column2: For I know that he will command his children, and his household after him, to keep the way of the Lord, and do judgment and justice: that for Abraham's sake, the Lord may bring to effect all the things he hath spoken unto him.
column4: Nam elegi eum, ut præcipiat filiis suis et domui suæ post se, ut custodiant viam Domini et faciant iustitiam et iudicium, ut adducat Dominus super Abraham omnia, quæ locutus est ad eum.

column2: And the Lord said: The cry of Sodom and Gomorrha is multiplied, and their sin is become exceedingly grievous.
column4: Dixit itaque Dominus: Clamor contra Sodomam et Gomorram multiplicatus est, et peccatum eorum aggravatum est nimis.

column2: I will go down and see whether they have done according to the cry that is come to me; or whether it be not so, that I may know.
column4: Descendam et videbo utrum clamorem, qui venit ad me, opere compleverint an non; sciam.

column2: And they turned themselves from thence, and went their way to Sodom: but Abraham as yet stood before the Lord.
column4: Converteruntque se inde viri et abierunt Sodomam; Abraham vero adhuc stabat coram Domino.

column2: And drawing nigh, he said: Wilt thou destroy the just with the wicked?
column4: Et appropinquans ait: Numquid vere perdes iustum cum impio?

column2: If there be fifty just men in the city, shall they perish withal? and wilt thou not spare that place for the sake of the fifty just, if they be therein?
column4: Si forte fuerint quinquaginta iusti in civitate, vere perdes et non parces loco illi propter quinquaginta iustos, si fuerint in eo?

column2: Far be it from thee to do this thing, and to slay the just with the wicked, and for the just to be in like case as the wicked; this is not beseeming thee: thou who judgest all the earth, wilt not make this judgment.
column4: Absit a te, ut rem hanc facias et occidas iustum cum impio, fiatque iustus sicut impius; absit a te. Nonne iudex universæ terræ faciet iudicium?

column2: And the Lord said to him: If I find in Sodom fifty just within the city, I will spare the whole place for their sake.
column4: Dixitque Dominus: Si invenero Sodomæ quinquaginta iustos in medio civitas, dimittam omni loco propter eos.

column2: And Abraham answered, and said: Seeing I have once begun, I will speak to my Lord, whereas I am dust and ashes.
column4: Respondensque Abraham ait: Ecce cœpi loqui ad Dominum meum cum sim pulvis et cinis.

column2: What if there be five less than fifty just persons? wilt thou for five and forty destroy the whole city: And he said: I will not destroy it, if I find five and forty.
column4: Quid, si forte minus quinquaginta iustis quinque fuerint? Delebis propter quinque universam urbem? Et ait: "Non delebo, si invenero ibi quadraginta quinque".

column2: And again he said to him: But if forty be found there, what wilt thou do? He said: I will not destroy it for the sake of forty.
column4: Rursumque locutus est ad eum: "Si forte inventi fuerint ibi quadraginta?" Ait: "Non percutiam propter quadraginta".

column2: Lord, saith he, be not angry, I beseech thee, if I speak: What if thirty shall be found there? He answered: I will not do it, if I find thirty there.
column4: Ne, quæso, inquit, indignetur Dominus meus, si loquar. Si forte ibi inventi fuerint triginta? Ait: "Non faciam, si invenero ibi triginta."

column2: Seeing, saith he, I have once begun, I will speak to my Lord: What if twenty be found there? He said: I will not destroy it for the sake of twenty.
column4: Ecce, ait, cœpi loqui ad Dominum meum. Si forte inventi fuerint ibi viginti? Dixit: "Non interficiam propter viginti".

column2: I beseech thee, saith he, be not angry, Lord, if I speak yet once more: What if ten shall be found there? And he said: I will not destroy it for the sake of ten.
column4: Obsecro, inquit, ne irascatur Dominus meus, si loquar adhuc semel. Si forte inventi fuerint ibi decem? Dixit: "Non delebo propter decem".

column2: And the Lord departed, after he had left speaking to Abraham: and Abraham returned to his place.
column4: Abiit Dominus, postquam cessavit loqui ad Abraham; et ille reversus est in locum suum.

column2: And his soul was fast knit unto her; and whereas she was sad, he comforted her with sweet words.
column4: Et conglutinata est anima eius cum ea, et amavit puellam et locutus est ad cor eius.

column2: And going to Hemor his father, he said: Get me this damsel to wife.
column4: Dixitque ad Hemmor patrem suum: Accipe mihi puellam hanc coniugem.

column2: But when Jacob had heard this, his sons being absent, and employed in feeding the cattle, he held his peace till they came back.
column4: Cum audisset Iacob quod violasset Dinam filiam suam, absentibus filiis et in pastu pecorum occupatis, siluit, donec redirent.

column2: And when Hemor the father of Sichem was come out to speak to Jacob, behold his sons came from the field: and hearing what had passed, they were exceeding angry, because he had done a foul thing in Israel, and committed an unlawful act, in ravishing Jacob's daughter.
column4: Egresso autem Hemmor patre Sichem, ut loqueretur ad Iacob, ecce filii Iacob veniebant de agro, auditoque, quod acciderat, contristati et irati sunt valde, eo quod fœdam rem esset operatus in Israel et, violata filia Iacob, rem illicitam perpetrasset.

column2: And Hemor spoke to them: The soul of my son Sichem has a longing for your daughter: give her him to wife: and let us contract marriages one with another: give us your daughters, and take you our daughters.
column4: Locutus est itaque Hemmor ad eos: Sichem filii mei adhæsit anima filiæ vestræ; date eam illi uxorem, et iungamus vicissim conubia: filias vestras tradite nobis et filias nostras accipite vobis.

column2: And dwell with us: the land is at your command, till, trade, and possess it.
column4: Et habitate nobiscum; terra in potestate vestra est: manete, perambulate et possidete eam.

column2: Sichem also said to her father and to her brethren: Let me find favour in your sight, and whatsoever you shall appoint I will give:
column4: Sed et Sichem ad patrem et ad fratres eius ait: Inveniam gratiam coram vobis et, quæcumque statueritis, dabo.

column2: Raise the dowry, and ask gifts, and I will gladly give what you shall demand: only give me this damsel to wife.
column4: Augete mihi valde dotem et munera; libens tribuam, quod petieritis. Tantum date mihi puellam hanc uxorem.

column2: The sons of Jacob answered Sichem and his father deceitfully, being enraged at the deflowering of their sister: We cannot do what you demand, nor give our sister to one that is uncircumcised; which with us is unlawful and abominable.
column4: Responderunt filii Iacob Sichem et Hemmor patri eius in dolo ob stuprum sororis: Non possumus facere, quod petitis, dare sororem nostram homini incircumciso, opprobrium enim esset nobis.

column2: But in this we may be allied with you, if you will be like us, and all the male sex among you be circumcised:Then will we mutually give and take your daughters, and ours; and we will dwell with you, and will be one people:
column4: In hoc tantum valebimus acquiescere vobis: si esse volueritis similes nostri, circumcidatur in vobis omne masculini sexus; tunc dabimus et accipiemus mutuo filias nostras ac vestras et habitabimus vobiscum erimusque unus populus.

column2: But if you will not be circumcised, we will take our daughter and depart.
column4: Si autem circumcidi nolueritis, tollemus filiam nostram et recedemus.

column2: Their offer pleased Hemor, and Sichem, his son: And the young man made no delay, but forthwith fulfilled what was required: for he loved the damsel exceedingly, and he was the greatest man in all his father's house.
column4: Placuit oblatio eorum Hemmor et Sichem filio eius, nec distulit adulescens quin statim, quod petebatur, expleret; amabat enim filiam Iacob valde, et ipse erat inclitus in omni domo patris sui.

column2: And going into the gate of the city, they spoke to the people: These men are peaceable, and are willing to dwell with us: let them trade in the land, and till it, which being large and wide wanteth men to till it: we shall take their daughters for wives, and we will give them ours.
column4: Ingressique portam urbis, Hemmor et Sichem filius eius locuti sunt ad viros civitatis suæ: Viri isti pacifici sunt erga nos; maneant in terra et perambulent eam, quæ spatiosa et lata est eis; filias eorum accipiemus uxores et nostras illis dabimus.

column2: One thing there is for which so great a good is deferred: We must circumcise every male among us, following the manner of the nation. And their substance, and cattle, and all that they possess, shall be ours; only in this let us condescend, and by dwelling together, we shall make one people.
column4: Tantum in hoc valebunt viri acquiescere nobis, ut maneant nobiscum et efficiamur unus populus, si circumcidamus masculos nostros ritum gentis imitantes; et pecora et substantia et armenta eorum nostra erunt. Tantum in hoc acquiescamus, et habitabunt nobiscum.

column2: And they all agreed, and circumcised all the males.
column4: Assensique sunt omnes, circumcisis cunctis maribus, qui egrediebantur e porta civitatis suæ.

column2: And behold the third day, when the pain of the wound was greatest: two of the sons of Jacob, Simeon and Levi, the brothers of Dina, taking their swords, entered boldly into the city and slew all the men. And they killed also Hemor and Sichem, and took away their sister Dina out of Sichem's house.
column4: Et ecce, die tertio, quando gravissimus vulnerum dolor est, arreptis duo filii Iacob Simeon et Levi fratres Dinæ gladiis, ingressi sunt urbem securi; interfectisque omnibus masculis, Hemmor et Sichem pariter necaverunt, tollentes Dinam de domo Sichem sororem suam.

column2: And when they were gone out, the other sons of Jacob came upon the slain; and plundered the city in revenge of the rape.
column4: Filii Iacob irruerunt super occisos, et depopulati sunt urbem in ultionem stupri.

column2: And they took their sheep, and their herds, and their asses, wasting all they had in their houses and in their fields.
column4: Oves eorum et armenta et asinos cunctaque, quæ in civitate et in agris erant, tulerunt.

column2: And their children and wives they took captive.
column4: Omnes opes eorum, parvulos quoque et uxores duxerunt captivas et diripuerunt omnia, quæ in domibus erant.

column2: And when they had boldly perpetrated these things, Jacob said to Simeon and Levi: You have troubled me, and made me hateful to the Chanaanites and Pherezites, the inhabitants of this land. We are few: they will gather themselves together and kill me; and both I, and my house shall be destroyed.
column4: Iacob autem dixit ad Simeon et Levi: Turbastis me et odiosum fecistis me Chananæis et Pherezæis habitatoribus terræ huius. Nos pauci sumus; illi congregati percutient me, et delebor ego et domus mea.

column2: They answered: Should they abuse our sister as a strumpet?
column4: Responderunt: Numquid ut scorto abuti debuere sorore nostra?

column2: And the two angels came to Sodom in the evening, and Lot was sitting in the gate of the city. And seeing them, he rose up and went to meet them: and worshipped prostrate to the ground. And said: I beseech you, my lords, turn in to the house of your servant, and lodge there: wash your feet, and in the morning you shall go on your way.
column4: Veneruntque duo angeli Sodomam vespere, sedente Lot in foribus civitatis. Qui cum vidisset eos, surrexit et ivit obviam eis adoravitque pronus in terram et dixit: "Obsecro, domini mei, declinate in domum pueri vestri et pernoctate; lavate pedes vestros et mane proficiscemini in viam vestram".

column2: And they said: No, but we will abide in the street.
column4: Qui dixerunt: Minime, sed in platea pernoctabimus.

column2: He pressed them very much to turn in unto him: and when they were come into his house, he made them a feast, and baked unleavened bread, and they ate:
column4: Compulit illos oppido, et diverterunt ad eum. Ingressisque domum illius fecit convivium et coxit azyma, et comederunt.

column2: But before they went to bed, the men of the city beset the house, both young and old, all the people together.
column4: Prius autem quam irent cubitum, viri civitatis, viri Sodomæ, vallaverunt domum a iuvene usque ad senem, omnis populus simul.

column2: And they called Lot, and said to him: Where are the men that came in to thee at night? bring them out hither, that we may know them:
column4: Vocaveruntque Lot et dixerunt ei: Ubi sunt viri, qui introierunt ad te nocte? Educ illos ad nos, ut cognoscamus eos.

column2: Lot went out to them, and shut the door after him, and said: Do not so, I beseech you, my brethren, do not commit this evil.
column4: Egressus ad eos Lot post tergum occludens ostium ait: Nolite, quæso, fratres mei, nolite malum hoc facere.

column2: I have two daughters who, as yet, have not known man; I will bring them out to you, and abuse you them as it shall please you, so that you do no evil to these men, because they are come in under the shadow of my roof.
column4: Ecce, habeo duas filias, quæ necdum cognoverunt virum; educam eas ad vos, et facite eis sicut placuerit vobis, dummodo viris istis nihil faciatis, ideo enim ingressi sunt sub umbra tecti mei.

column2: But they said: Get thee back thither. And again: Thou camest in, said they, as a stranger, was it to be a judge? therefore we will afflict thee more than them. And they pressed very violently upon Lot: and they were even at the point of breaking open the doors.
column4: At illi dixerunt: "Recede illuc". Et rursus: "Unus ingressus est, inquiunt, ut advena et vult iudicare? Te ergo ipsum magis quam hos affligemus". Vimque faciebant Lot vehementissime, iamque prope erat, ut effringerent fores.

column2: And behold the men put out their hand, and drew in Lot unto them, and shut the door.
column4: Et ecce miserunt manum viri et introduxerunt ad se Lot clauseruntque ostium.

column2: And them, that were without, they struck with blindness from the least to the greatest, so that they could not find the door.
column4: Et eos, qui foris erant, percusserunt cæcitate a minimo usque ad maximum, ita ut ostium invenire non possent.

column2: And they said to Lot: Hast thou here any of thine? son in law, or sons, or daughters, all that are thine bring them out of this city: For we will destroy this place, because their cry is grown loud before the Lord, who hath sent us to destroy them.
