column2: And Jacob called his sons, and said to them: Gather yourselves together, that I may tell you the things that shall befall you in the last days.
column4: Vocavit autem Iacob filios suos et ait eis: Congregamini, ut annuntiem, quæ ventura sunt vobis in diebus novissimis.

column2: Gather yourselves together, and hear, O ye sons of Jacob, hearken to Israel, your father:
column4: Congregamini et audite, filii Iacob, audite Israel patrem vestrum!

column2: Ruben, my firstborn, thou art my strength, and the beginning of my sorrow; excelling in gifts, greater in command.
column4: Ruben primogenitus meus, tu fortitudo mea et principium roboris mei; prior in dignitate, maior in robore!

column2: Thou art poured out as water, grow thou not; because thou wentest up to thy father's bed, and didst defile his couch.
column4: Ebulliens sicut aqua non excellas, quia ascendisti cubile patris tui et maculasti stratum meum.

column2: Simeon and Levi brethren: vessels of iniquity waging war.
column4: Simeon et Levi fratres, vasa violentiæ arma eorum.

column2: Let not my soul go into their counsel, nor my glory be in their assembly: because in their fury they slew a man, and in their self-will they undermined a wall.
column4: In consilium eorum ne veniat anima mea, et in cœtu illorum non sit gloria mea; quia in furore suo occiderunt virum et in voluntate sua subnervaverunt tauros.

column2: Cursed be their fury, because it was stubborn: and their wrath, because it was cruel: I will divide them in Jacob, and will scatter them in Israel.
column4: Maledictus furor eorum, quia pertinax, et indignatio eorum, quia dura! Dividam eos in Iacob et dispergam eos in Israel.

column2: Juda, thee shall thy brethren praise: thy hand shall be on the necks of thy enemies; the sons of thy father shall bow down to thee.
column4: Iuda, te laudabunt fratres tui; manus tua in cervicibus inimicorum tuorum; adorabunt te filii patris tui.

column2: Juda is a lion's whelp: to the prey, my son, thou art gone up: resting thou hast couched as a lion, and as a lioness, who shall rouse him?
column4: Catulus leonis Iuda: a præda, fili mi, ascendisti; requiescens accubuit ut leo et quasi leæna; quis suscitabit eum?

column2: I know that Tom is a good teacher.
The sceptre shall not be taken away from Juda, nor a ruler from his thigh, till he come that is to be sent, and he shall be the expectation of nations.
column4: Non auferetur sceptrum de Iuda et baculus ducis de pedibus eius, donec veniat ille, cuius est, et cui erit obœdientia gentium.

column2: Tying his foal to the vineyard, and his ass, O my son, to the vine, he shall wash his robe in wine, and his garment in the blood of the grape.
column4: Ligans ad vineam pullum suum et ad vitem filium asinæ suæ, lavabit in vino stolam suam et in sanguine uvæ pallium suum.

column2: His eyes are more beautiful than wine, and his teeth whiter than milk.
column4: Nigriores sunt oculi eius vino et dentes eius lacte candidiores.

column2: Zabulon shall dwell on the seashore, and in the road of ships, reaching as far as Sidon.
column4: Zabulon in litore maris habitabit et in statione navium, pertingens usque ad Sidonem.

column2: Issachar shall be a strong ass, lying down between the borders.
column4: Issachar asinus fortis, accubans inter caulas.

column2: He saw rest that it was good: and the land that it was excellent: and he bowed his shoulder to carry, and became a servant under tribute.
column4: Vidit requiem quod esset bona, et terram quod optima; et supposuit umerum suum ad portandum factusque est tributis serviens.

column2: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.
column4: In principio creavit Deus caelum et terram.

column2: In the beginning, God created the heavens and the earth.
column4: In principio creavit Deus cælum et terram.

column2: Dan shall judge his people like another tribe in Israel.
column4: Dan iudicabit populum suum sicut una tribuum Israel.

column2: Let Dan be a snake in the way, a serpent in the path, that biteth the horse's heels, that his rider may fall backward.
column4: Fiat Dan coluber in via, cerastes in semita, mordens calcanea equi, ut cadat ascensor eius retro.

column2: I will look for thy salvation, O Lord.
Gad, being girded, shall fight before him: and he himself shall be girded backward.
column4: Gad, latrones aggredientur eum, ipse autem aggredietur calcaneum eorum.

column2: Aser, his bread shall be fat, and he shall yield dainties to kings.
column4: Aser, pinguis panis eius, et præbebit delicias regales.

column2: Nephthali, a hart let loose, and giving words of beauty.
column4: Nephthali cerva emissa, dans cornua pulchra.

column2: Joseph is a growing son, a growing son and comely to behold: the daughters run to and fro upon the wall.
column4: Arbor fructifera Ioseph, arbor fructifera super fontem: rami transcendunt murum.

column2: But they that held darts, provoked him, and quarrelled with him, and envied him.
column4: Sed exasperaverunt eum et iurgati sunt, et adversati sunt illi habentes iacula.

column2: His bow rested upon the strong, and the bands of his arms and his hands were loosed, by the hands of the mighty one of Jacob: thence he came forth a pastor, the stone of Israel.
column4: Et confractus est arcus eorum, et dissoluti sunt nervi brachiorum eorum per manus Potentis Iacob, per nomen Pastoris, Lapidis Israel.

column2: The God of thy father shall be thy helper, and the Almighty shall bless thee with the blessings of heaven above, with the blessings of the deep that lieth beneath, with the blessings of the breasts and of the womb.
column4: Deus patris tui erit adiutor tuus, et Omnipotens benedicet tibi benedictionibus cæli desuper, benedictionibus abyssi iacentis deorsum, benedictionibus uberum et vulvæ.

column2: The blessings of thy father are strengthened with the blessings of his fathers: until the desire of the everlasting hills should come: may they be upon the head of Joseph, and upon the crown of the Nazarite among his brethren.
column4: Benedictiones patris tui confortatæ sunt super benedictiones montium æternorum, desiderium collium antiquorum; fiant in capite Ioseph et in vertice nazaræi inter fratres suos.

column2: Benjamin a ravenous wolf, in the morning shall eat the prey, and in the evening shall divide the spoil.
column4: Beniamin lupus rapax; mane comedet prædam et vespere dividet spolia.

column2: All these are the twelve tribes of Israel: these things their father spoke to them, and he blessed every one with their proper blessings.
column4: Omnes hi in tribubus Israel duodecim. Hæc locutus est eis pater suus benedixitque singulis benedictionibus propriis.

column2: And he charged them, saying: I am now going to be gathered to my people: bury me with my fathers in the double cave, which is in the field of Ephron the Hethite, over against Mambre, in the land of Canaan, which Abraham bought together with the field, of Ephron the Hethite, for a possession to bury in.
column4: Et præcepit eis dicens: Ego congregor ad populum meum; sepelite me cum patribus meis in spelunca Machpela, quæ est in agro Ephron Hetthæi contra Mambre in terra Chanaan, quam emit Abraham cum agro ab Ephron Hetthæo in possessionem sepulcri.

column2: There they buried him, and Sara his wife: there was Isaac buried with Rebecca, his wife: there also Lia doth lie buried.
column4: Ibi sepelierunt eum et Saram uxorem eius, ibi sepultus est Isaac cum Rebecca coniuge sua, ibi et Lia condita iacet.

column2: And when he had ended the commandments, wherewith he instructed his sons, he drew up his feet upon the bed, and died: and he was gathered to his people.
column4: Finitisque mandatis, quibus filios instruebat, collegit pedes suos super lectulum et obiit; appositusque est ad populum suum.

column2: The President desires peace, doesn't he?
And when Joseph saw this, he fell upon his father's face, weeping and kissing him.
column4: Ioseph ruit super faciem patris flens et deosculans eum.

column2: And he commanded his servants, the physicians, to embalm his father.
column4: Præcepitque servis suis medicis, ut aromatibus condirent patrem.

column2: And while they were fulfilling his commands, there passed forty days: for this was the manner with bodies that were embalmed, and Egypt mourned for him seventy days.
column4: Quibus iussa explentibus, transierunt quadraginta dies; iste quippe mos erat cadaverum conditorum. Flevitque eum Aegyptus septuaginta diebus.

column2: And the time of the mourning being expired, Joseph spoke to the family of Pharaoh: If I have found favour in your sight, speak in the ears of Pharaoh. For my father made me swear to him, saying: Behold I die; thou shalt bury me in my sepulchre which I have digged for myself in the land of Canaan. So I will go up and bury my father, and return.
column4: Et, expleto planctus tempore, locutus est Ioseph ad familiam pharaonis: Si inveni gratiam in conspectu vestro, loquimini in auribus pharaonis, eo quod pater meus adiuraverit me dicens: "En morior; in sepulcro meo, quod fodi mihi in terra Chanaan, sepelies me"; ascendam nunc et sepeliam patrem meum ac revertar.

column2: And Pharaoh said to him: Go up and bury thy father according as he made thee swear.
column4: Dixitque ei pharao: Ascende et sepeli patrem tuum, sicut adiuratus es.

column2: So he went up, and there went with him all the ancients of Pharaoh's house, and all the elders of the land of Egypt. And the house of Joseph with his brethren, except their children, and their flocks and herds, which they left in the land of Goshen.
column4: Quo ascendente, ierunt cum eo omnes servi pharaonis, senes domus eius cunctique maiores natu terræ Aegypti, domus Ioseph cum fratribus suis, absque parvulis et gregibus atque armentis, quæ dereliquerant in terra Gessen.

column2: That's going to be my horse.
He had also in his train chariots and horsemen: and it was a great company.
column4: Habuit quoque in comitatu currus et equites; et facta est turba non modica.

column2: And they came to the threshing floor of Atad, which is situated beyond the Jordan: where celebrating the exequies with a great and vehement lamentation, they spent full seven days.
column4: Veneruntque ad Gorenatad (id est Aream rhamni), quæ sita est trans Iordanem; ubi celebrantes exsequias planctu magno atque vehementi impleverunt septem dies.

column2: And when the inhabitants of Canaan saw this, they said: This is a great mourning to the Egyptians. And therefore the name of that place was called, The mourning of Egypt.
column4: Quod cum vidissent habitatores terræ Chanaan, dixerunt: “Planctus magnus est iste Aegyptiis”; et idcirco vocatum est nomen loci illius Abelmesraim (id est Planctus Aegypti).

column2: So the sons of Jacob did as he had commanded them. And carrying him into the land of Canaan, they buried him in the double cave, which Abraham had bought together with the field for a possession of a burying place, of Ehpron, the Hethite, over against Mambre.
column4: Fecerunt ergo filii Iacob, sicut præceperat eis; et portantes eum in terram Chanaan sepelierunt eum in spelunca Machpela, quam emerat Abraham cum agro in possessionem sepulcri ab Ephron Hetthæo contra faciem Mambre.

column2: And Joseph returned into Egypt with his brethren, and all that were in his company, after he had buried his father.
column4: Reversusque est Ioseph in Aegyptum cum fratribus suis et omni comitatu, sepulto patre.

column2: Now he being dead, his brethren were afraid, and talked one with another: Lest perhaps he should remember the wrong he suffered, and requite us all the evil that we did to him.
column4: Quo mortuo, timentes fratres eius et mutuo colloquentes: Ne forte memor sit iniuriæ, quam passus est, et reddat nobis omne malum, quod fecimus.

column2: And they sent a message to him, saying: Thy father commanded us before he died, that we should say thus much to thee from him: I beseech thee to forget the wickedness of thy brethren, and the sin and malice they practised against thee.
column4: Mandaverunt ei dicentes: Pater tuus præcepit nobis, antequam moreretur, ut hæc tibi verbis illius diceremus: "Obsecro, ut obliviscaris sceleris fratrum tuorum et peccati atque malitiæ, quam exercuerunt in te".

column2: We also pray thee, to forgive the servants of the God of thy father this wickedness. And when Joseph heard this, he wept.
column4: Nos quoque oramus, ut servis Dei patris tui dimittas iniquitatem hanc. Quibus auditis, flevit Ioseph.

column2: And his brethren came to him; and worshipping prostrate on the ground, they said: We are thy servants.
column4: Veneruntque ad eum fratres sui et proni coram eo dixerunt: Servi tui sumus.

column2: And he answered them: Fear not: can we resist the will of God?
column4: Quibus ille respondit: Nolite timere. Num Dei possumus resistere voluntati?

column2: You thought evil against me: but God turned it into good, that he might exalt me, as at present you see, and might save many people.
column4: Vos cogitastis de me malum; sed Deus vertit illud in bonum, ut exaltaret me, sicut in præsentiarum cernitis, et salvos faceret multos populos.

column2: Fear not: I will feed you and your children.
column4: Nolite timere: ego pascam vos et parvulos vestros.

column2: And he comforted them, and spoke gently and mildly.
column4: Consolatusque est eos et blande ac leniter est locutus.

column2: And Joseph said unto them, Fear not: for am I in the place of God?
column4: Quibus ille respondit: Nolite timere. Num Dei possumus resistere voluntati?

column2: And he dwelt in Egypt with all his father's house; and lived a hundred and ten years.
column4: Et habitavit in Aegypto cum omni domo patris sui; vixitque centum decem annis.

column2: And he saw the children of Ephraim to the third generation. The children also of Machir, the sons of Manasses, were born on Joseph's knees.
column4: Et vidit Ephraim filios usque ad tertiam generationem; filii quoque Machir filii Manasse nati sunt in genibus Ioseph.

column2: After which he told his brethren: God will visit you after my death, and will make you go up out of this land, to the land which he swore to Abraham, Isaac, and Jacob.
column4: Quibus transactis, locutus est fratribus suis: Post mortem meam Deus visitabit vos et ascendere vos faciet de terra ista ad terram, quam iuravit Abraham, Isaac et Iacob.

column2: And he made them swear to him, saying: God will visit you, carry my bones with you out of this place.
column4: Cumque adiurasset eos atque dixisset: “Deus visitabit vos; asportate ossa mea vobiscum de loco isto”.

column2: And he died, being a hundred and ten years old. And being embalmed, he was laid in a coffin in Egypt.
column4: Mortuus est, expletis centum decem vitæ suæ annis. Et conditus aromatibus repositus est in loculo in Aegypto.

column2: And the earth was void and empty, and darkness was upon the face of the deep; and the spirit of God moved over the waters.
column4: Terra autem erat inanis et vacua, et tenebræ super faciem abyssi, et spiritus Dei ferebatur super aquas.

column2: And God saw the light that it was good; and he divided the light from the darkness.
column4: Et vidit Deus lucem quod esset bona et divisit Deus lucem ac tenebras.

column2: And he called the light Day, and the darkness Night; and there was evening and morning one day.
column4: Appellavitque Deus lucem Diem et tenebras Noctem. Factumque est vespere et mane, dies unus.

column2: And God said: Let there be a firmament made amidst the waters: and let it divide the waters from the waters.
column4: Dixit quoque Deus: Fiat firmamentum in medio aquarum et dividat aquas ab aquis.

column2: And God made a firmament, and divided the waters that were under the firmament, from those that were above the firmament, and it was so.
column4: Et fecit Deus firmamentum divisitque aquas, quæ erant sub firmamento, ab his, quæ erant super firmamentum. Et factum est ita.

column2: And God called the firmament, Heaven; and the evening and morning were the second day.
column4: Vocavitque Deus firmamentum Cælum. Et factum est vespere et mane, dies secundus.

column2: God also said; Let the waters that are under the heaven be gathered together into one place: and let the dry land appear. And it was so done.
column4: Dixit vero Deus: “Congregentur aquæ, quæ sub cælo sunt, in locum unum, et appareat arida”. Factumque est ita.

column2: And God called the dry land, Earth; and the gathering together of the waters, he called Seas. And God saw that it was good.
column4: Et vocavit Deus aridam Terram congregationesque aquarum appellavit Maria. Et vidit Deus quod esset bonum.

column2: And he said: let the earth bring forth green herb, and such as may seed, and the fruit tree yielding fruit after its kind, which may have seed in itself upon the earth. And it was so done.
column4: Et ait Deus: “Germinet terra herbam virentem et herbam facientem semen et lignum pomiferum faciens fructum iuxta genus suum, cuius semen in semetipso sit super terram”. Et factum est ita.

column2: And the earth brought forth the green herb, and such as yieldeth seed according to its kind, and the tree that beareth fruit, having seed each one according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.
column4: Et protulit terra herbam virentem et herbam afferentem semen iuxta genus suum lignumque faciens fructum, qui habet in semetipso sementem secundum speciem suam. Et vidit Deus quod esset bonum.

column2: And the evening and the morning were the third day.
column4: Et factum est vespere et mane, dies tertius.

column2: And God said: Let there be lights made in the firmament of heaven, to divide the day and the night, and let them be for signs, and for seasons, and for days and years: to shine in the firmament of heaven, and to give light upon the earth, and it was so done.
column4: Dixit autem Deus: “Fiant luminaria in firmamento cæli, ut dividant diem ac noctem et sint in signa et tempora et dies et annos, ut luceant in firmamento cæli et illuminent terram". Et factum est ita.

column2: And God made two great lights: a greater light to rule the day; and a lesser light to rule the night: and the stars.
column4: Fecitque Deus duo magna luminaria: luminare maius, ut præesset diei, et luminare minus, ut præesset nocti, et stellas.

column2: And he set them in the firmament of heaven to shine upon the earth. And to rule the day and the night, and to divide the light and the darkness. And God saw that it was good.
column4: Et posuit eas Deus in firmamento cæli, ut lucerent super terram et præessent diei ac nocti et dividerent lucem ac tenebras. Et vidit Deus quod esset bonum.

column2: And the evening and morning were the fourth day.
column4: Et factum est vespere et mane, dies quartus.

column2: God also said: let the waters bring forth the creeping creature having life, and the fowl that may fly over the earth under the firmament of heaven.
column4: Dixit etiam Deus: Pullulent aquæ reptile animæ viventis, et volatile volet super terram sub firmamento cæli.

column2: And God created the great whales, and every living and moving creature, which the waters brought forth, according to their kinds, and every winged fowl according to its kind. And God saw that it was good.
column4: Creavitque Deus cete grandia et omnem animam viventem atque motabilem, quam pullulant aquæ secundum species suas, et omne volatile secundum genus suum. Et vidit Deus quod esset bonum.

column2: And he blessed them, saying: Increase and multiply, and fill the waters of the sea: and let the birds be multiplied upon the earth.
column4: Benedixitque eis Deus dicens: Crescite et multiplicamini et replete aquas maris, avesque multiplicentur super terram.

column2: And the evening and morning were the fifth day.
column4: Et factum est vespere et mane, dies quintus.

column2: And God said: Let the earth bring forth the living creature in its kind, cattle and creeping things, and beasts of the earth, according to their kinds. And it was so done.
column4: Dixit quoque Deus: “Producat terra animam viventem in genere suo, iumenta et reptilia et bestias terræ secundum species suas”. Factumque est ita.

column2: And God made the beasts of the earth according to their kinds, and cattle, and every thing that creepeth on the earth after its kind. And God saw that it was good.
column4: Et fecit Deus bestias terræ iuxta species suas et iumenta secundum species suas et omne reptile terræ in genere suo. Et vidit Deus quod esset bonum.

column2: And he said: Let us make man to our image and likeness: and let him have dominion over the fishes of the sea, and the fowls of the air, and the beasts, and the whole earth, and every creeping creature that moveth upon the earth.
column4: Et ait Deus: Faciamus hominem ad imaginem et similitudinem nostram; et præsint piscibus maris et volatilibus cæli et bestiis universæque terræ omnique reptili, quod movetur in terra.

column2: And God created man to his own image: to the image of God he created him: male and female he created them.
column4: Et creavit Deus hominem ad imaginem suam; ad imaginem Dei creavit illum; masculum et feminam creavit eos.

column2: And God blessed them, saying: Increase and multiply, and fill the earth, and subdue it, and rule over the fishes of the sea, and the fowls of the air, and all living creatures that move upon the earth.
column4: Benedixitque illis Deus et ait illis Deus: Crescite et multiplicamini et replete terram et subicite eam et dominamini piscibus maris et volatilibus cæli et universis animantibus, quæ moventur super terram.

column2: And God said: Behold I have given you every herb bearing seed upon the earth, and all trees that have in themselves seed of their own kind, to be your meat.
column4: Dixitque Deus: Ecce dedi vobis omnem herbam afferentem semen super terram et universa ligna, quæ habent in semetipsis fructum ligni portantem sementem, ut sint vobis in escam.

column2: And to all beasts of the earth, and to every fowl of the air, and to all that move upon the earth, and wherein there is life, that they may have to feed upon.
column4: Et cunctis animantibus terræ omnique volucri cæli et universis, quæ moventur in terra et in quibus est anima vivens, omnem herbam virentem ad vescendum.

column2: And it was so done. And God saw all the things that he had made, and they were very good. And the evening and morning were the sixth day.
column4: Et factum est ita. Viditque Deus cuncta, quæ fecit, et ecce erant valde bona. Et factum est vespere et mane, dies sextus.

column2: So the heavens and the earth were finished, and all the furniture of them.
column4: Igitur perfecti sunt cæli et terra et omnis exercitus eorum.

column2: And on the seventh day God ended his work which he had made: and he rested on the seventh day from all his work which he had done.
column4: Complevitque Deus die septimo opus suum, quod fecerat, et requievit die septimo ab universo opere, quod patrarat.

column2: And he blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it: because in it he had rested from all his work which God created and made.
column4: Et benedixit Deus diei septimo et sanctificavit illum, quia in ipso requieverat ab omni opere suo, quod creavit Deus, ut faceret.

column2: These are the generations of the heaven and the earth, when they were created, in the day that the Lord God made the heaven and the Earth.
column4: Istæ sunt generationes cæli et terræ, quando creata sunt in die quo fecit Dominus Deus terram et cælum.

column2: And every plant of the field before it sprung up in the earth, and every herb of the ground before it grew: for the Lord God had not rained upon the earth; and there was not a man to till the earth.
column4: Et omne virgultum agri, antequam oriretur in terra, omnisque herba regionis, priusquam germinaret; non enim pluerat Dominus Deus super terram, et homo non erat, qui operaretur humum.

column2: But a spring rose out of the earth, watering all the surface of the earth.
column4: Sed fons ascendebat e terra irrigans universam superficiem terræ. ­ ­

column2: And the Lord God formed man of the slime of the earth: and breathed into his face the breath of life, and man became a living soul.
column4: Tunc formavit Dominus Deus hominem pulverem de humo et inspiravit in nares eius spiraculum vitæ, et factus est homo in animam viventem.

column2: And the Lord God had planted a paradise of pleasure from the beginning: wherein he placed man whom he had formed.
column4: Et plantavit Dominus Deus paradisum in Eden ad orientem, in quo posuit hominem, quem formaverat.

column2: And the Lord God brought forth of the ground all manner of trees, fair to behold, and pleasant to eat of: the tree of life also in the midst of paradise: and the tree of knowledge of good and evil.
column4: Produxitque Dominus Deus de humo omne lignum pulchrum visu et ad vescendum suave, lignum etiam vitæ in medio paradisi lignumque scientiæ boni et mali.

column2: And a river went out of the place of pleasure to water paradise, which from thence is divided into four heads.
column4: Et fluvius egrediebatur ex Eden ad irrigandum paradisum, qui inde dividitur in quattuor capita.

column2: The name of the one is Phison: that is it which compasseth all the land of Hevilath, where gold groweth. And the gold of that land is very good: there is found bdellium, and the onyx stone.
column4: Nomen uni Phison: ipse est, qui circuit omnem terram Hevila, ubi est aurum; et aurum terræ illius optimum est; ibi invenitur bdellium et lapis onychinus.

column2: And the name of the second river is Gehon: the same is it that compasseth all the land of Ethiopia.
column4: Et nomen fluvio secundo Geon: ipse est, qui circuit omnem terram Aethiopiæ.

column2: And the name of the third river is Tigris: the same passeth along by the Assyrians. And the fourth river is Euphrates.
column4: Nomen vero fluminis tertii Tigris: ipse vadit ad orientem Assyriæ. Fluvius autem quartus ipse est Euphrates.

column2: They live on the other side of the river.
And the Lord God took man, and put him into the paradise of pleasure, to dress it, and to keep it.
column4: Tulit ergo Dominus Deus hominem et posuit eum in paradiso Eden, ut operaretur et custodiret illum.

column2: And he commanded him, saying: Of every tree of paradise thou shalt eat: But of the tree of knowledge of good and evil, thou shalt not eat. For in what day soever thou shalt eat of it, thou shalt die the death.
column4: Præcepitque Dominus Deus homini dicens: Ex omni ligno paradisi comede; de ligno autem scientiæ boni et mali ne comedas; in quocumque enim die comederis ex eo, morte morieris.

column2: And the Lord God said: It is not good for man to be alone: let us make him a help like unto himself.
column4: Dixit quoque Dominus Deus: Non est bonum esse hominem solum; faciam ei adiutorium simile sui.

column2: And the Lord God having formed out of the ground all the beasts of the earth, and all the fowls of the air, brought them to Adam to see what he would call them: for whatsoever Adam called any living creature the same is its name.
column4: Formatis igitur Dominus Deus de humo cunctis animantibus agri et universis volatilibus cæli, adduxit ea ad Adam, ut videret quid vocaret ea; omne enim, quod vocavit Adam animæ viventis, ipsum est nomen eius.

column2: And Adam called all the beasts by their names, and all the fowls of the air, and all the cattle of the field: but for Adam there was not found a helper like himself.
column4: Appellavitque Adam nominibus suis cuncta pecora et universa volatilia cæli et omnes bestias agri; Adæ vero non inveniebatur adiutor similis eius.

column2: Then the Lord God cast a deep sleep upon Adam: and when he was fast asleep, he took one of his ribs, and filled up flesh for it.
column4: Immisit ergo Dominus Deus soporem in Adam. Cumque obdormisset, tulit unam de costis eius et replevit carnem pro ea.

column2: And the Lord God built the rib which he took from Adam into a woman: and brought her to Adam.
column4: Et ædificavit Dominus Deus costam, quam tulerat de Adam, in mulierem et adduxit eam ad Adam.

column2: And Adam said: This now is bone of my bones, and flesh of my flesh; she shall be called woman, because she was taken out of man.
column4: Dixitque Adam: Hæc nunc os ex ossibus meis et caro de carne mea! Hæc vocabitur Virago, quoniam de viro sumpta est hæc.

column2: Wherefore a man shall leave father and mother, and shall cleave to his wife: and they shall be two in one flesh.
column4: Quam ob rem relinquet vir patrem suum et matrem et adhærebit uxori suæ; et erunt in carnem unam.

column2: And they were both naked: to wit, Adam and his wife: and were not ashamed.
column4: Erant autem uterque nudi, Adam scilicet et uxor eius, et non erubescebant.

column2: Now the serpent was more subtle than any of the beasts of the earth which the Lord God had made. And he said to the woman: Why hath God commanded you, that you should not eat of every tree of paradise?
column4: Et serpens erat callidior cunctis animantibus agri, quæ fecerat Dominus Deus. Qui dixit ad mulierem: Verene præcepit vobis Deus, ut non comederetis de omni ligno paradisi?

column2: And the woman answered him, saying: Of the fruit of the trees that are in paradise we do eat: But of the fruit of the tree which is in the midst of paradise, God hath commanded us that we should not eat; and that we should not touch it, lest perhaps we die.
column4: Cui respondit mulier: De fructu lignorum, quæ sunt in paradiso, vescimur; de fructu vero ligni, quod est in medio paradisi, præcepit nobis Deus, ne comederemus et ne tangeremus illud, ne moriamur.

column2: And the serpent said to the woman: No, you shall not die the death. For God doth know that in what day soever you shall eat thereof, your eyes shall be opened: and you shall be as Gods, knowing good and evil.
column4: Dixit autem serpens ad mulierem: Nequaquam morte moriemini! Scit enim Deus quod in quocumque die comederitis ex eo, aperientur oculi vestri, et eritis sicut Deus scientes bonum et malum.

column2: And the woman saw that the tree was good to eat, and fair to the eyes, and delightful to behold: and she took of the fruit thereof, and did eat, and gave to her husband, who did eat.
column4: Vidit igitur mulier quod bonum esset lignum ad vescendum et pulchrum oculis et desiderabile esset lignum ad intellegendum; et tulit de fructu illius et comedit deditque etiam viro suo secum, qui comedit.

column2: And the eyes of them both were opened: and when they perceived themselves to be naked, they sewed together fig leaves, and made themselves aprons.
column4: Et aperti sunt oculi amborum. Cumque cognovissent esse se nudos, consuerunt folia ficus et fecerunt sibi perizomata.

column2: And when they heard the voice of the Lord God walking in paradise at the afternoon air, Adam and his wife hid themselves from the face of the Lord God, amidst the trees of paradise.
column4: Et cum audissent vocem Domini Dei deambulantis in paradiso ad auram post meridiem, abscondit se Adam et uxor eius a facie Domini Dei in medio ligni paradisi.

column2: And the Lord God called Adam, and said to him: Where art thou?
column4: Vocavitque Dominus Deus Adam et dixit ei: Ubi es?

column2: And he said: I heard thy voice in paradise; and I was afraid, because I was naked, and I hid myself.
column4: Qui ait: Vocem tuam audivi in paradiso et timui eo quod nudus essem et abscondi me.

column2: And he said to him: And who hath told thee that thou wast naked, but that thou hast eaten of the tree whereof I commanded thee that thou shouldst not eat?
column4: Cui dixit: Quis enim indicavit tibi quod nudus esses, nisi quod ex ligno, de quo tibi præceperam, ne comederes, comedisti?

column2: And Adam said: The woman, whom thou gavest me to be my companion, gave me of the tree, and I did eat.
column4: Dixitque Adam: Mulier, quam dedisti sociam mihi, ipsa dedit mihi de ligno, et comedi.

column2: And the Lord God said to the woman: Why hast thou done this? And she answered: The serpent deceived me, and I did eat.
column4: Et dixit Dominus Deus ad mulierem: “Quid hoc fecisti?” Quæ respondit: “Serpens decepit me, et comedi”.

column2: And the Lord God said to the serpent: Because thou hast done this thing, thou art cursed among all cattle, and beasts of the earth: upon thy breast shalt thou go, and earth shalt thou eat all the days of thy life.
column4: Et ait Dominus Deus ad serpentem: Quia fecisti hoc, maledictus es inter omnia pecora et omnes bestias agri! Super pectus tuum gradieris et pulverem comedes cunctis diebus vitæ tuæ.

column2: I will put enmities between thee and the woman, and thy seed and her seed: she shall crush thy head, and thou shalt lie in wait for her heel.
column4: Inimicitias ponam inter te et mulierem et semen tuum et semen ilius; ipsum conteret caput tuum, et tu conteres calcaneum eius.

column2: To the woman also he said: I will multiply thy sorrows, and thy conceptions: in sorrow shalt thou bring forth children, and thou shalt be under thy husband's power, and he shall have dominion over thee.
column4: Mulieri dixit: Multiplicabo ærumnas tuas et conceptus tuos: in dolore paries filios, et ad virum tuum erit appetitus tuus, ipse autem dominabitur tui.

column2: And to Adam he said: Because thou hast hearkened to the voice of thy wife, and hast eaten of the tree, whereof I commanded thee, that thou shouldst not eat, cursed is the earth in thy work: with labour and toil shalt thou eat thereof all the days of thy life.
column4: Adæ vero dixit: Quia audisti vocem uxoris tuæ et comedisti de ligno, ex quo præceperam tibi, ne comederes, maledicta humus propter te! In laboribus comedes ex ea cunctis diebus vitæ tuæ.

column2: Thorns and thistles shall it bring forth to thee, and thou shalt eat the herbs of the earth.In the sweat of thy face shalt thou eat bread till thou return to the earth out of which thou wast taken: for dust thou art, and into dust thou shalt return.
column4: Spinas et tribulos germinabit tibi, et comedes herbas terræ; in sudore vultus tui vesceris pane, donec revertaris ad humum, de qua sumptus es, quia pulvis es et in pulverem reverteris.

column2: And Adam called the name of his wife Eve: because she was the mother of all the living.
column4: Et vocavit Adam nomen uxoris suæ Eva, eo quod mater esset cunctorum viventium.

column2: And the Lord God made for Adam and his wife garments of skins, and clothed them.
column4: Fecit quoque Dominus Deus Adæ et uxori eius tunicas pelliceas et induit eos.

column2: And he said: Behold Adam is become as one of us, knowing good and evil: now therefore lest perhaps he put forth his hand and take also of the tree of life, and eat, and live for ever.
column4: Et ait Dominus Deus: Ecce homo factus est quasi unus ex nobis, ut sciat bonum et malum; nunc ergo, ne mittat manum suam et sumat etiam de ligno vitæ et comedat et vivat in æternum!

column2: And the Lord God sent him out of the paradise of pleasure, to till the earth from which he was taken.
column4: Emisit eum Dominus Deus de paradiso Eden, ut operaretur humum, de qua sumptus est.

column2: And he cast out Adam: and placed before the paradise of pleasure Cherubim, and a flaming sword, turning every way, to keep the way of the tree of life.
column4: Eiecitque hominem et collocavit ad orientem paradisi Eden cherubim et flammeum gladium atque versatilem ad custodiendam viam ligni vitæ.

column2: And Adam knew Eve his wife; who conceived and brought forth Cain, saying: I have gotten a man through God.
column4: Adam vero cognovit Evam uxorem suam, quæ concepit et peperit Cain dicens: Acquisivi virum per Dominum.

column2: And again she brought forth his brother Abel. And Abel was a shepherd, and Cain a husbandman.
column4: Rursusque peperit fratrem eius Abel. Et fuit Abel pastor ovium et Cain agricola.

column2: And it came to pass after many days, that Cain offered, of the fruits of the earth, gifts to the Lord.
column4: Factum est autem post aliquot dies ut offerret Cain de fructibus agri munus Domino.

column2: Abel also offered of the firstlings of his flock, and of their fat: and the Lord had respect to Abel, and to his offerings.
column4: Abel quoque obtulit de primogenitis gregis sui et de adipibus eorum. Et respexit Dominus ad Abel et ad munus eius.

column2: But to Cain and his offerings he had no respect: and Cain was exceeding angry, and his countenance fell.
column4: Ad Cain vero et ad munus illius non respexit. Iratusque est Cain vehementer, et concidit vultus eius.

column2: And the Lord said to him: Why art thou angry? and why is thy countenance fallen?
column4: Dixitque Dominus ad eum: Quare iratus es, et cur concidit facies tua?

column2: If thou do well, shalt thou not receive? but if ill, shall not sin forthwith be present at the door? but the lust thereof shall be under thee, and thou shalt have dominion over it.
column4: Nonne si bene egeris, vultum attolles? Sin autem male, in foribus peccatum insidiabitur, et ad te erit appetitus eius, tu autem dominaberis illius.

column2: And Cain said to Abel his brother: Let us go forth abroad. And when they were in the field, Cain rose up against his brother Abel, and slew him.
column4: Dixitque Cain ad Abel fratrem suum: “Egrediamur foras”. Cumque essent in agro, consurrexit Cain adversus Abel fratrem suum et interfecit eum.

column2: And the Lord said to Cain: Where is thy brother Abel? And he answered: I know not: am I my brother's keeper?
column4: Et ait Dominus ad Cain: “Ubi est Abel frater tuus?” Qui respondit: “Nescio. Num custos fratris mei sum ego?”

column2: And he said to him: What hast thou done? the voice of thy brother's blood crieth to me from the earth.
column4: Dixitque ad eum: Quid fecisti? Vox sanguinis fratris tui clamat ad me de agro.

column2: Now therefore cursed shalt thou be upon the earth, which hath opened her mouth and received the blood of thy brother at thy hand.
column4: Nunc igitur maledictus eris procul ab agro, qui aperuit os suum et suscepit sanguinem fratris tui de manu tua!

column2: When thou shalt till it, it shall not yield to thee its fruit: a fugitive and a vagabond shalt thou be upon the earth.
column4: Cum operatus fueris eum, amplius non dabit tibi fructus suos; vagus et profugus eris super terram.

column2: And Cain said to the Lord: My iniquity is greater than that I may deserve pardon.
column4: Dixitque Cain ad Dominum: Maior est pœna mea quam ut portem eam.

column2: Behold thou dost cast me out this day from the face of the earth, and from thy face I shall be hid, and I shall be a vagabond and a fugitive on the earth: every one therefore that findeth me, shall kill me.
column4: Ecce eicis me hodie a facie agri, et a facie tua abscondar et ero vagus et profugus in terra; omnis igitur, qui invenerit me, occidet me.

column2: And the Lord said to him: No, it shall not so be: but whosoever shall kill Cain, shall be punished sevenfold. And the Lord set a mark upon Cain, that whosoever found him should not kill him.
column4: Dixitque ei Dominus: “Nequaquam ita fiet, sed omnis qui occiderit Cain, septuplum punietur!” Posuitque Dominus Cain signum, ut non eum interficeret omnis qui invenisset eum.

column2: And Cain said unto the Lord, My punishment is greater than I can bear.
column4: Dixitque Cain ad Dominum: Maior est pœna mea quam ut portem eam.

column2: And Cain went out from the presence of the Lord, and dwelt in the land of Nod, on the east of Eden.
column4: Egressusque Cain a facie Domini habitavit in terra Nod ad orientalem plagam Eden.

column2: And Cain knew his wife, and she conceived, and brought forth Henoch: and he built a city, and called the name thereof by the name of his son Henoch.
column4: Cognovit autem Cain uxorem suam, quæ concepit et peperit Henoch. Et ædificavit civitatem vocavitque nomen eius ex nomine filii sui Henoch.

column2: And Henoch begot Irad, and Irad begot Maviael, and Maviael begot Mathusael, and Mathusael begot Lamech.
column4: Porro Henoch genuit Irad, et Irad genuit Maviael, et Maviael genuit Mathusael, et Mathusael genuit Lamech.

column2: Who took two wives: the name of the one was Ada, and the name of the other Sella.
column4: Qui accepit uxores duas: nomen uni Ada et nomen alteri Sella.

column2: And Ada brought forth Jabel: who was the father of such as dwell in tents, and of herdsmen.
column4: Genuitque Ada Iabel, qui fuit pater habitantium in tentoriis atque pastorum.

column2: We split the loot three ways.
And his brother's name was Jubal: he was the father of them that play upon the harp and the organs.
column4: Et nomen fratris eius Iubal; ipse fuit pater omnium canentium cithara et organo.

column2: Sella also brought forth Tubalcain, who was a hammerer and artificer in every work of brass and iron. And the sister of Tubalcain was Noema.
column4: Sella quoque genuit Tubalcain, qui fuit malleator et faber in cuncta opera æris et ferri. Soror vero Tubalcain Noema.

column2: And Lamech said to his wives Ada and Sella: Hear my voice, ye wives of Lamech, hearken to my speech: for I have slain a man to the wounding of myself, and a stripling to my own bruising.
column4: Dixitque Lamech uxoribus suis: Ada et Sella, audite vocem meam; uxores Lamech, auscultate sermonem meum: occidi virum pro vulnere meo et adulescentulum pro livore meo.

column2: Sevenfold vengeance shall be taken for Cain: but for Lamech seventy times sevenfold.
column4: Septuplum ultio dabitur de Cain, de Lamech vero septuagies septies.

column2: Adam also knew his wife again: and she brought forth a son, and called his name Seth, saying: God hath given me another seed for Abel, whom Cain slew.
column4: Cognovit quoque Adam uxorem suam, et peperit filium vocavitque nomen eius Seth dicens: Posuit mihi Deus semen aliud pro Abel, quem occidit Cain.

column2: But to Seth also was born a son, whom he called Enos: this man began to call upon the name of the Lord.
column4: Sed et Seth natus est filius, quem vocavit Enos. Tunc cœperunt invocare nomen Domini.

column2: And to Seth, to him also there was born a son; and he called his name Enos: then began men to call upon the name of the Lord.
column4: Sed et Seth natus est filius, quem vocavit Enos. Tunc cœperunt invocare nomen Domini.

column2: Are you able to understand Tom?
And the days of Adam, after he begot Seth, were eight hundred years: and he begot sons and daughters. And all the time that Adam lived, came to nine hundred and thirty years, and he died.
column4: Et facti sunt dies Adam, postquam genuit Seth, octingenti anni, genuitque filios et filias. Et factum est omne tempus, quod vixit Adam, anni nongenti triginta, et mortuus est.

column2: And Seth lived a hundred and five years, and begot Enos.
column4: Vixit quoque Seth centum quinque annos et genuit Enos.

column2: And Seth lived after he begot Enos, eight hundred and seven years, and begot sons and daughters.
column4: Vixitque Seth, postquam genuit Enos, octingentis septem annis genuitque filios et filias.

column2: And all the days of Seth were nine hundred and twelve years, and he died.
column4: Et facti sunt omnes dies Seth nongentorum duodecim annorum, et mortuus est.

column2: And Lamech lived a hundred and eighty-two years, and begot a son. And he called his name Noah, saying: This same shall comfort us from the works and labours of our hands on the earth, which the Lord hath cursed.
column4: Vixit autem Lamech centum octoginta duobus annis et genuit filium vocavitque nomen eius Noe dicens: Iste consolabitur nos ab operibus nostris et labore manuum nostrarum in agro, cui maledixit Dominus.

column2: And Lamech lived after he begot Noah, five hundred and ninety-five years, and begot sons and daughters.
column4: Vixitque Lamech, postquam genuit Noe, quingentos nonaginta quinque annos et genuit filios et filias.

column2: And all the days of Lamech came to seven hundred and seventy-seven years, and he died.
column4: Et facti sunt omnes dies Lamech septingenti septuaginta septem anni, et mortuus est.

column2: And Noah, when he was five hundred years old, begot Sem, Cham, and Japheth.
column4: Noe vero, cum quingentorum esset annorum, genuit Sem, Cham et Iapheth.

column2: And after that men began to be multiplied upon the earth, and daughters were born to them, the sons of God seeing the daughters of men, that they were fair, took to themselves wives of all which they chose.
column4: Cumque cœpissent homines multiplicari super terram et filias procreassent, videntes filii Dei filias hominum quod essent pulchræ, acceperunt sibi uxores ex omnibus, quas elegerant.

column2: And it came to pass, when men began to multiply on the face of the Earth, and daughters were born unto them, that the sons of God saw the daughters of men that they were fair; and they took them wives of all which they chose.
column4: Cumque cœpissent homines multiplicari super terram et filias procreassent, videntes filii Dei filias hominum quod essent pulchræ, acceperunt sibi uxores ex omnibus, quas elegerant.

column2: And God said: My spirit shall not remain in man for ever, because he is flesh, and his days shall be a hundred and twenty years.
column4: Dixitque Deus: Non permanebit spiritus meus in homine in æternum, quia caro est; eruntque dies illius centum viginti annorum.

column2: Now giants were upon the earth in those days. For after the sons of God went in to the daughters of men, and they brought forth children, these are the mighty men of old, men of renown.
column4: Gigantes erant super terram in diebus illis et etiam postquam ingressi sunt filii Dei ad filias hominum, illæque eis genuerunt: isti sunt potentes a sæculo viri famosi.

column2: There were giants in the earth in those days; and also after that, when the sons of God came in unto the daughters of men, and they bare children to them, the same became mighty men which were of old, men of renown.
column4: Gigantes erant super terram in diebus illis et etiam postquam ingressi sunt filii Dei ad filias hominum, illæque eis genuerunt: isti sunt potentes a sæculo viri famosi.

column2: And God seeing that the wickedness of men was great on the earth, and that all the thought of their heart was bent upon evil at all times, It repented him that he had made man on the earth.
column4: Videns autem Dominus quod multa malitia hominum esset in terra, et cuncta cogitatio cordis eorum non intenta esset nisi ad malum omni tempore, pænituit Dominum quod hominem fecisset in terra.

column2: And being touched inwardly with sorrow of heart, he said: I will destroy man, whom I have created, from the face of the earth, from man even to beasts, from the creeping thing even to the fowls of the air, for it repenteth me that I have made them.
column4: Et tactus dolore cordis intrinsecus: Delebo, inquit, hominem, quem creavi, a facie terræ, ab homine usque ad pecus, usque ad reptile et usque ad volucres cæli; pænitet enim me fecisse eos.

column2: But Noah found grace before the Lord.
column4: Noe vero invenit gratiam coram Domino.

column2: Noah was a just and perfect man in his generations, he walked with God.
column4: Noe vir iustus atque perfectus fuit in generatione sua; cum Deo ambulavit.

column2: And the earth was corrupted before God, and was filled with iniquity.
column4: Corrupta est autem terra coram Deo et repleta est iniquitate.

column2: And when God had seen that the earth was corrupted (for all flesh had corrupted its way upon the earth), He said to Noah: The end of all flesh is come before me, the earth is filled with iniquity through them, and I will destroy them with the earth.
column4: Cumque vidisset Deus terram esse corruptam ­ omnis quippe caro corruperat viam suam super terram ­dixit ad Noe: Finis universæ carnis venit coram me; repleta est enim terra iniquitate a facie eorum, et ecce ego disperdam eos de terra.

column2: Make thee an ark of timber planks: thou shalt make little rooms in the ark, and thou shalt pitch it within and without.
column4: Fac tibi arcam de lignis cupressinis; mansiunculas in arca facies et bitumine linies eam intrinsecus et extrinsecus.

column2: And thus shalt thou make it. The length of the ark shall be three hundred cubits: the breadth of it fifty cubits, and the height of it thirty cubits.
column4: Et sic facies eam: trecentorum cubitorum erit longitudo arcæ, quinquaginta cubitorum latitudo et triginta cubitorum altitudo illius.

column2: Thou shalt make a window in the ark, and in a cubit shalt thou finish the top of it: and the door of the ark thou shalt set in the side: with lower, middle chambers, and third stories shalt thou make it.
column4: Fenestram in arca facies et cubito consummabis summitatem eius. Ostium autem arcæ pones ex latere; tabulatum inferius, medium et superius facies in ea.

column2: Behold, I will bring the waters of a great flood upon the earth, to destroy all flesh, wherein is the breath of life under heaven. All things that are in the earth shall be consumed.
column4: Ecce ego adducam diluvii aquas super terram, ut interficiam omnem carnem, in qua spiritus vitæ est subter cælum: universa, quæ in terra sunt, consumentur.

column2: And I will establish my covenant with thee, and thou shalt enter into the ark, thou and thy sons, and thy wife, and the wives of thy sons with thee.
column4: Ponamque fœdus meum tecum; et ingredieris arcam tu et filii tui, uxor tua et uxores filiorum tuorum tecum.

column2: And of every living creature of all flesh, thou shalt bring two of a sort into the ark, that they may live with thee: of the male sex, and the female.
column4: Et ex cunctis animantibus universæ carnis bina induces in arcam, ut vivant tecum, masculini sexus et feminini.

column2: Of fowls according to their kind, and of beasts in their kind, and of every thing that creepeth on the earth according to its kind: two of every sort shall go in with thee, that they may live.
column4: De volucribus iuxta genus suum et de iumentis in genere suo et ex omni reptili terræ secundum genus suum: bina de omnibus ingredientur ad te, ut possint vivere.

column2: Thou shalt take unto thee of all food that may be eaten, and thou shalt lay it up with thee: and it shall be food for thee and them.
column4: Tu autem tolle tecum ex omnibus escis, quæ mandi possunt, et comportabis apud te; et erunt tam tibi quam illis in cibum.

column2: And Noah did all things which God commanded him.
column4: Fecit ergo Noe omnia, quæ præceperat illi Deus; sic fecit.

column2: For yet a while, and after seven days, I will rain upon the earth forty days and forty nights: and I will destroy every substance that I have made, from the face of the earth.
column4: Adhuc enim et post dies septem ego pluam super terram quadraginta diebus et quadraginta noctibus et delebo omnem substantiam, quam feci, de superficie terræ.

column2: And Noah was six hundred years old when the waters of the flood overflowed the earth.
column4: Eratque Noe sescentorum annorum, quando diluvii aquæ inundaverunt super terram.

column2: And Noah went in and his sons, his wife and the wives of his sons with him into the ark, because of the waters of the flood.
column4: Et ingressus est Noe et filii eius, uxor eius et uxores filiorum eius cum eo in arcam propter aquas diluvii.

column2: And of beasts clean and unclean, and of fowls, and of every thing that moveth upon the earth, two and two went in to Noah into the ark, male and female, as the Lord had commanded Noah.
column4: De pecoribus mundis et immundis et de volucribus et ex omni, quod movetur super terram, duo et duo ingressa sunt ad Noe in arcam, masculus et femina, sicut præceperat Deus Noe.

column2: And after the seven days were passed, the waters of the flood overflowed the earth.
column4: Cumque transissent septem dies, aquæ diluvii inundaverunt super terram.

column2: In the six hundredth year of the life of Noah, in the second month, in the seventeenth day of the month, all the fountains of the great deep were broken up, and the floodgates of heaven were opened.
column4: Anno sescentesimo vitæ Noe, mense secundo, septimo decimo die mensis rupti sunt omnes fontes abyssi magnæ, et cataractæ cæli apertæ sunt.

column2: And the rain fell upon the earth forty days and forty nights.
column4: Et facta est pluvia super terram quadraginta diebus et quadraginta noctibus.

column2: And the flood was forty days upon the earth: and the waters increased, and lifted up the ark on high from the earth.
column4: Factumque est diluvium quadraginta diebus super terram, et multiplicatæ sunt aquæ et elevaverunt arcam in sublime a terra.

column2: For they overflowed exceedingly: and filled all on the face of the earth: and the ark was carried upon the waters.
column4: Vehementer enim inundaverunt et omnia repleverunt in superficie terræ; porro arca ferebatur super aquas.

column2: And the waters prevailed beyond measure upon the earth: and all the high mountains under the whole heaven were covered.
column4: Et aquæ prævaluerunt nimis super terram, opertique sunt omnes montes excelsi sub universo cælo.

column2: The water was fifteen cubits higher than the mountains which it covered.
column4: Quindecim cubitis altior fuit aqua super montes, quos operuerat.

column2: And all flesh was destroyed that moved upon the earth, both of fowl and of cattle, and of beasts, and of all creeping things that creep upon the earth: and all men. And all things wherein there is the breath of life on the earth, died.
column4: Consumptaque est omnis caro, quæ movebatur super terram, volucrum, pecorum, bestiarum omniumque reptilium, quæ reptant super terram, et universi homines: cuncta, in quibus spiraculum vitæ in terra, mortua sunt.

column2: And he destroyed all the substance that was upon the earth, from man even to beast, and the creeping things and fowls of the air: and they were destroyed from the earth: and Noah only remained, and they that were with him in the ark.
column4: Et delevit omnem substantiam, quæ erat super terram, ab homine usque ad pecus, usque ad reptile et usque ad volucres cæli; et deleta sunt de terra. Remansit autem solus Noe et qui cum eo erant in arca.

column2: And the waters prevailed upon the earth a hundred and fifty days.
column4: Obtinueruntque aquæ terram centum quinquaginta diebus.

column2: I want to study in that school.
I want to know the facts.
And God remembered Noah, and all the living creatures, and all the cattle which were with him in the ark, and brought a wind upon the earth, and the waters were abated.
column4: Recordatus autem Deus Noe cunctorumque animantium et omnium iumentorum, quæ erant cum eo in arca, adduxit spiritum super terram, et imminutæ sunt aquæ.

column2: The fountains also of the deep, and the floodgates of heaven, were shut up, and the rain from heaven was restrained.
column4: Et clausi sunt fontes abyssi et cataractæ cæli, et prohibitæ sunt pluviæ de cælo.

column2: And the waters returned from off the earth going and coming: and they began to be abated after a hundred and fifty days. .
column4: Reversæque sunt aquæ de terra euntes et redeuntes et cœperunt minui post centum quinquaginta dies.

column2: And the ark rested in the seventh month, on the seventeenth day of the month, upon the mountains of Armenia.
column4: Requievitque arca mense septimo, decima septima die mensis super montes Ararat.

column2: And the waters were going and decreasing until the tenth month: for in the tenth month, the first day of the month, the tops of the mountains appeared.
column4: At vero aquæ ibant et decrescebant usque ad decimum mensem; decimo enim mense, prima die mensis, apparuerunt cacumina montium.

column2: And after that forty days were passed, Noah opening the window of the ark, which he had made, sent forth a raven, which went forth and did not return, till the waters were dried up upon the earth.
column4: Cumque transissent quadraginta dies, aperiens Noe fenestram arcæ, quam fecerat, dimisit corvum; qui egrediebatur exiens et rediens, donec siccarentur aquæ super terram.

column2: He sent forth also a dove after him, to see if the waters had now ceased upon the face of the earth.
column4: Emisit quoque columbam a se, ut videret si iam cessassent aquæ super faciem terræ.

column2: But she not finding where her foot might rest, returned to him into the ark: for the waters were upon the whole earth: and he put forth his hand, and caught her, and brought her into the ark.
column4: Quæ, cum non invenisset, ubi requiesceret pes eius, reversa est ad eum in arcam; aquæ enim erant super universam terram. Extenditque manum et apprehensam intulit in arcam.

column2: And having waited yet seven other days, he again sent forth the dove out of the ark.
column4: Exspectatis autem ultra septem diebus aliis, rursum dimisit columbam ex arca.

column2: And she came to him in the evening carrying a bough of an olive tree, with green leaves, in her mouth. Noah therefore understood that the waters were ceased upon the earth.
column4: At illa venit ad eum ad vesperam portans ramum olivæ virentibus foliis in ore suo. Intellexit ergo Noe quod cessassent aquæ super terram.

column2: And he stayed yet other seven days: and he sent forth the dove, which returned not any more unto him.
column4: Exspectavitque nihilominus septem alios dies; et emisit columbam, quæ non est reversa ultra ad eum.

column2: Therefore in the six hundredth and first year, the first month, the first day of the month, the waters were lessened upon the earth, and Noah opening the covering of the ark, looked, and saw that the face of the earth was dried.
column4: Igitur sescentesimo primo anno, primo mense, prima die mensis, siccatæ sunt aquæ super terram; et aperiens Noe tectum arcæ, et ecce aspexit viditque quod exsiccata erat superficies terræ.

column2: In the second month, the seven and twentieth day of the month, the earth was dried.
column4: Mense secundo, septima et vicesima die mensis, arefacta est terra.

column2: And God spoke to Noah, saying: Go out of the ark, thou and thy wife, thy sons and the wives of thy sons with thee. All living things that are with thee of all flesh, as well in fowls as in beasts, and all creeping things that creep upon the earth, bring out with thee, and go ye upon the earth: increase and multiply upon it.
column4: Locutus est autem Deus ad Noe dicens: Egredere de arca tu et uxor tua, filii tui et uxores filiorum tuorum tecum. Cuncta animantia, quæ sunt apud te ex omni carne, tam in volatilibus quam in pecoribus et in universis reptilibus, quæ reptant super terram, educ tecum, ut pullulent super terram et crescant et multiplicentur super eam.

column2: So Noah went out, he and his sons: his wife, and the wives of his sons with him.
column4: Egressus est ergo Noe et filii eius, uxor illius et uxores filiorum eius cum eo.

column2: And all living things, and cattle, and creeping things that creep upon the earth, according to their kinds went out of the ark.
column4: Sed et omnia animantia, iumenta, volatilia et reptilia, quæ reptant super terram, secundum genus suum egressa sunt de arca.

column2: And Noah built an altar unto the Lord: and taking of all cattle and fowls that were clean, offered holocausts upon the altar.
column4: Aedificavit autem Noe altare Domino; et tollens de cunctis pecoribus mundis et volucribus mundis obtulit holocausta super altare.

column2: And the Lord smelled a sweet savour, and said: I will no more curse the earth for the sake of man: for the imagination and thought of man's heart are prone to evil from his youth: therefore I will no more destroy every living soul as I have done.
column4: Odoratusque est Dominus odorem suavitatis et locutus est Dominus ad cor suum: Nequaquam ultra maledicam terræ propter homines, quia cogitatio humani cordis in malum prona est ab adulescentia sua. Non igitur ultra percutiam omnem animam viventem, sicut feci.

column2: All the days of the earth, seedtime and harvest, cold and heat, summer and winter, night and day, shall not cease.
column4: Cunctis diebus terræ, sementis et messis, frigus et æstus, æstas et hiems, dies et nox non requiescent.

column2: And God blessed Noah and his sons. And he said to them: Increase, and multiply, and fill the earth.
column4: Benedixitque Deus Noe et filiis eius et dixit ad eos: Crescite et multiplicamini et implete terram.

column2: And let the fear and dread of you be upon all the beasts of the earth, and upon all the fowls of the air, and all that move upon the earth: all the fishes of the sea are delivered into your hand.
column4: Et terror vester ac tremor sit super cuncta animalia terræ et super omnes volucres cæli cum universis, quæ moventur super terram; omnes pisces maris manui vestræ traditi sunt.

column2: And every thing that moveth, and liveth shall be meat for you: even as the green herbs have I delivered them all to you: Saving that flesh with blood you shall not eat.
column4: Omne, quod movetur et vivit, erit vobis in cibum; quasi holera virentia tradidi vobis omnia, excepto quod carnem cum anima, quæ est in sanguine, non comedetis.

column2: For I will require the blood of your lives at the hand of every beast, and at the hand of man, at the hand of every man, and of his brother, will I require the life of man.
column4: Sanguinem enim animarum vestrarum requiram de manu cunctarum bestiarum; et de manu hominis, de manu viri fratris eius requiram animam hominis.

column2: Whosoever shall shed man's blood, his blood shall be shed: for man was made to the image of God.
column4: Quicumque effuderit humanum sanguinem, per hominem fundetur sanguis illius; ad imaginem quippe Dei factus est homo.

column2: But increase you and multiply, and go upon the earth and fill it.
column4: Vos autem crescite et multiplicamini et pullulate super terram et dominamini ei.

column2: Thus also said God to Noah, and to his sons with him: Behold I will establish my covenant with you, and with your seed after you: And with every living soul that is with you, as well in all birds, as in cattle and beasts of the earth, that are come forth out of the ark, and in all the beasts of the earth.
column4: Hæc quoque dixit Deus ad Noe et ad filios eius cum eo: Ecce ego statuam pactum meum vobiscum et cum semine vestro post vos et ad omnem animam viventem, quæ est vobiscum tam in volucribus quam in iumentis et in omnibus bestiis terræ, quæ sunt vobiscum, cunctis, quæ egressa sunt de arca, universis bestiis terræ.

column2: I will establish my covenant with you, and all flesh shall be no more destroyed with the waters of a flood, neither shall there be from henceforth a flood to waste the earth.
column4: Statuam pactum meum vobiscum; et nequaquam ultra interficietur omnis caro aquis diluvii, neque erit deinceps diluvium dissipans terram.

column2: And God said: This is the sign of the covenant which I give between me and you, and to every living soul that is with you, for perpetual generations. I will set my bow in the clouds, and it shall be the sign of a covenant between me and the earth.
column4: Dixitque Deus: Hoc signum fœderis, quod do inter me et vos et ad omnem animam viventem, quæ est vobiscum, in generationes sempiternas: arcum meum ponam in nubibus, et erit signum fœderis inter me et inter terram.

column2: And when I shall cover the sky with clouds, my bow shall appear in the clouds: And I will remember my covenant with you, and with every living soul that beareth flesh: and there shall no more be waters of a flood to destroy all flesh.
column4: Cumque obduxero nubibus cælum, apparebit arcus meus in nubibus, et recordabor fœderis mei vobiscum et cum omni anima vivente, quæ carnem vegetat; et non erunt ultra aquæ diluvii ad delendum universam carnem.

column2: And the bow shall be in the clouds, and I shall see it, and shall remember the everlasting covenant, that was made between God and every living soul of all flesh which is upon the earth.
column4: Eritque arcus in nubibus, et videbo illum et recordabor fœderis sempiterni, quod pactum est inter Deum et omnem animam viventem universæ carnis, quæ est super terram.

column2: And God said to Noah: This shall be the sign of the covenant, which I have established, between me and all flesh upon the earth.
column4: Dixitque Deus ad Noe: Hoc erit signum fœderis, quod constitui inter me et omnem carnem super terram.

column2: And the sons of Noah, who came out of the ark, were Shem, Ham, and Japheth: and Ham is the father of Canaan.
column4: Erant ergo filii Noe, qui egressi sunt de arca, Sem, Cham et Iapheth. Porro Cham ipse est pater Chanaan.

column2: These three are the sons of Noah: and from these was all mankind spread over the whole earth.
column4: Tres isti filii sunt Noe, et ab his disseminatum est omne hominum genus super universam terram.

column2: And Noah a husbandman began to till the ground, and planted a vineyard. And drinking of the wine was made drunk, and was uncovered in his tent.
column4: Cœpitque Noe agricola plantare vineam; bibensque vinum inebriatus est et nudatus in tabernaculo suo.

column2: And Ham, the father of Canaan, saw the nakedness of his father, and told his two brethren without.
column4: Quod cum vidisset Cham pater Chanaan, verenda scilicet patris sui esse nudata, nuntiavit duobus fratribus suis foras.

column2: But Shem and Japheth put a cloak upon their shoulders, and going backward, covered the nakedness of their father: and their faces were turned away, and they saw not their father's nakedness.
column4: At vero Sem et Iapheth pallium imposuerunt umeris suis et incedentes retrorsum operuerunt verecunda patris sui, faciesque eorum aversæ erant, et patris virilia non viderunt.

column2: And Noah awaking from the wine, when he had learned what his younger son had done to him, he said: Cursed be Canaan, a servant of servants shall he be unto his brethren.
column4: Evigilans autem Noe ex vino, cum didicisset, quæ fecerat ei filius suus minor, ait: Maledictus Chanaan! Servus servorum erit fratribus suis.

column2: And he said: Blessed be the Lord God of Shem, be Canaan his servant.
column4: Dixitque: Benedictus Dominus Deus Sem! Sitque Chanaan servus eius.

column2: May God enlarge Japheth, and may he dwell in the tents of Shem, and Canaan be his servant.
column4: Dilatet Deus Iapheth, et habitet in tabernaculis Sem, sitque Chanaan servus eius.

column2: And Noah lived after the flood three hundred and fifty years. And all his days were in the whole nine hundred and fifty years: and he died.
column4: Vixit autem Noe post diluvium trecentis quinquaginta annis. Et impleti sunt omnes dies eius nongentorum quinquaginta annorum, et mortuus est.

column2: These are the names of the children of Israel, that went into Egypt with Jacob: they went in every man with his household: Ruben, Simeon, Levi, Judah, Issachar, Zabulon, and Benjamin, Dan, and Nephthali, Gad and Asher.
column4: Hæc sunt nomina filiorum Israel, qui ingressi sunt Aegyptum cum Iacob; singuli cum domibus suis introierunt: Ruben, Simeon, Levi, Iuda, Issachar, Zabulon et Beniamin, Dan et Nephthali, Gad et Aser.

column2: And Avram took his wife Sarai and his nephew Lot, and all their possessions that they had acquired, and all the people who they had acquired in Haran, and they left to go to the land of Canaan, and they came into the land of Canaan.
column4: Tulitque Sarai uxorem suam et Lot filium fratris sui universamque substantiam, quam acquisiverant, et animas, quas fecerant in Charran, et egressi sunt, ut irent in terram Chanaan; et venerunt in terram Chanaan.

column2: And all the souls that came out of Jacob's thigh, were seventy: but Joseph was in Egypt.
column4: Erant igitur omnes animæ eorum, qui egressi sunt de femore Iacob, septuaginta; Ioseph autem in Aegypto erat.

column2: After he was dead, and all his brethren, and all that generation, the children of Israel increased, and sprung up into multitudes, and growing exceedingly strong they filled the land.
column4: Quo mortuo et universis fratribus eius omnique cognatione illa, filii Israel creverunt et pullulantes multiplicati sunt ac roborati nimis impleverunt terram.

column2: In the meantime there arose a new king over Egypt, that knew not Joseph. And he said to his people: Behold the people of the children of Israel are numerous and stronger than we. Come let us wisely oppress them, lest they multiply: and if any war shall rise against us, join with our enemies, and having overcome us, depart out of the land.
column4: Surrexit interea rex novus super Aegyptum, qui ignorabat Ioseph; et ait ad populum suum: Ecce, populus filiorum Israel multus et fortior nobis est; venite, prudenter agamus cum eo, ne forte multiplicetur et, si ingruerit contra nos bellum, addatur inimicis nostris, expugnatisque nobis, egrediatur de terra.

column2: Therefore he set over them masters of the works, to afflict them with burdens: and they built for Pharaoh cities of tabernacles, Phithom, and Ramesses.
column4: Præposuit itaque eis magistros operum, ut affligerent eos oneribus; ædificaveruntque urbes promptuarias pharaoni, Phithom et Ramesses.

column2: But the more they oppressed them, the more they were multiplied and increased.
column4: Quantoque opprimebant eos, tanto magis multiplicabantur et crescebant.

column2: And the Egyptians hated the children of Israel, and afflicted them and mocked them. And they made their life bitter with hard works in clay and brick, and with all manner of service, wherewith they were overcharged in the works of the earth.
column4: Formidaveruntque filios Israel Aegyptii et in servitutem redegerunt eos atque ad amaritudinem perducebant vitam eorum operibus duris luti et lateris omnique famulatu, quo in terræ operibus premebantur.

column2: And the king of Egypt spoke to the midwives of the Hebrews: of whom one was called Sephora, the other Phua, commanding them: When you shall do the office of midwives to the Hebrew women, and the time of delivery is come: if it be a man child, kill it: if a woman, keep it alive.
column4: Dixit autem rex Aegypti obstetricibus Hebræorum, quarum una vocabatur Sephra, altera Phua, præcipiens eis: Quando obstetricabitis Hebræas, et partus tempus advenerit, si masculus fuerit, interficite eum; si femina, reservate.

column2: But the midwives feared God, and did not do as the king of Egypt had commanded, but saved the men children.
column4: Timuerunt autem obstetrices Deum et non fecerunt iuxta præceptum regis Aegypti, sed conservabant mares.

column2: And the king called for them and said: What is it that you meant to do, that you would save the men children?
column4: Quibus ad se accersitis rex ait: Quidnam est hoc, quod facere voluistis, ut pueros servaretis?

column2: They answered: The Hebrew women are not as the Egyptian women: for they themselves are skilful in the office of a midwife; and they are delivered before we come to them.
column4: Quæ responderunt: Non sunt Hebrææ sicut Aegyptiæ mulieres; ipsæ enim robustæ sunt et, priusquam veniamus ad eas, pariunt.

column2: Therefore God dealt well with the midwives: and the people multiplied and grew exceedingly strong. And because the midwives feared God, he built them houses.
column4: Bene ergo fecit Deus obstetricibus, et crevit populus confortatusque est nimis; et, quia timuerunt obstetrices Deum, ædificavit illis domos.

column2: Pharaoh therefore charged all his people, saying: Whatsoever shall be born of the male sex, ye shall cast into the river: whatsoever of the female, ye shall save alive.
column4: Præcepit ergo pharao omni populo suo dicens: Quidquid masculini sexus natum fuerit, in flumen proicite; quidquid feminei, reservate.

column2: After this there went a man of the house of Levi; and took a wife of his own kindred. And she conceived, and bore a son: and seeing him a goodly child, hid him three months.
column4: Egressus est vir de domo Levi et accepit uxorem stirpis suæ; quæ concepit et peperit filium et videns eum elegantem abscondit tribus mensibus.

column2: And when she could hide him no longer, she took a basket made of bulrushes, and daubed it with slime and pitch: and put the little babe therein, and laid him in the sedges by the river's brink, his sister standing afar off, and taking notice what would be done.
column4: Cumque iam celare non posset, sumpsit fiscellam scirpeam et linivit eam bitumine ac pice; posuitque intus infantulum et exposuit eum in carecto ripæ fluminis, stante procul sorore eius et considerante eventum rei.

column2: And behold the daughter of Pharaoh came down to wash herself in the river: and her maids walked by the river's brink.
column4: Ecce autem descendebat filia pharaonis, ut lavaretur in flumine, et puellæ eius gradiebantur per crepidinem alvei

column2: Bear: "It is a happy meeting, dear Leo, for I have not seen you in six whole months."
column4: Ursus: "Sit felix occursus, optime Leo, nam totos sex menses te non vidi."

column2: And when she saw the basket in the sedges she sent one of her maids for it: and when it was brought, she opened it, and seeing within it an infant crying, having compassion on it, she said: This is one of the babes of the Hebrews.
column4: Quæ cum vidisset fiscellam in papyrione, misit unam e famulabus suis; et allatam aperiens cernensque in ea parvulum vagientem, miserta eius ait: De infantibus Hebræorum est hic.

column2: And the child's sister said to her: Shall I go, and call to thee a Hebrew woman, to nurse the babe?
column4: Cui soror pueri: Vis, inquit, ut vadam et vocem tibi mulierem Hebræam, quæ nutrire possit tibi infantulum?

column2: And Pharaoh's daughter said to her, Go. And the maid went and called the child's mother.
column4: Respondit: “Vade”. Perrexit puella et vocavit matrem infantis.

column2: And Pharaoh's daughter said unto her, Take this child away, and nurse it for me, and I will give thee thy wages. And the woman took the child, and nursed it.
column4: Ad quam locuta filia pharaonis: “Accipe, ait, puerum istum et nutri mihi; ego dabo tibi mercedem tuam”. Suscepit mulier et nutrivit puerum.

column2: And when he was grown up, she delivered him to Pharaoh's daughter. And she adopted him for a son, and called him Moses, saying: Because I took him out of the water.
column4: Adultumque tradidit filiæ pharaonis. Quem illa adoptavit in locum filii vocavitque nomen eius Moysen dicens: “Quia de aqua tuli eum”.

column2: In those days, after Moses was grown up, he went out to his brethren: and saw their affliction, and an Egyptian striking one of the Hebrews, his brethren.
column4: In diebus illis, postquam creverat, Moyses egressus est ad fratres suos; viditque afflictionem eorum et virum Aegyptium percutientem quendam de Hebræis fratribus suis.

column2: And when he had looked about this way and that way, and saw no one there, he slew the Egyptian and hid him in the sand.
column4: Cumque circumspexisset huc atque illuc et nullum adesse vidisset, percussum Aegyptium abscondit sabulo.

column2: And going out the next day, he saw two Hebrews quarrelling: and he said to him that did the wrong: Why strikest thou thy neighbour?
column4: Et egressus die altero conspexit duos Hebræos rixantes dixitque ei, qui faciebat iniuriam: Quare percutis proximum tuum?

column2: But he answered: Who hath appointed thee prince and judge over us? wilt thou kill me, as thou didst yesterday kill the Egyptian? Moses feared, and said: How is this come to be known?
column4: Qui respondit: “Quis te constituit principem et iudicem super nos? Num occidere me tu vis, sicut occidisti Aegyptium?” Timuit Moyses et ait: “Quomodo palam factum est verbum istud?”

column2: And Pharaoh heard of this word, and sought to kill Moses: but he fled from his sight, and abode in the land of Madian, and he sat down by a well.
column4: Audivitque pharao sermonem hunc et quærebat occidere Moysen. Qui fugiens de conspectu eius moratus est in terra Madian; venit ergo in terram Madian et sedit iuxta puteum.

column2: And the shepherds came and drove them away: and Moses arose, and defending the maids, watered their sheep.
column4: Supervenere pastores et eiecerunt eas: surrexitque Moyses et, defensis puellis, adaquavit oves earum.

column2: And when they returned to Raguel their father, he said to them: Why are ye come sooner than usual?
column4: Quæ cum revertissent ad Raguel patrem suum, dixit ad eas: Cur velocius venistis solito?

column2: They answered: A man of Egypt delivered us from the hands of the shepherds: and he drew water also with us, and gave the sheep to drink.
column4: Responderunt: Vir Aegyptius liberavit nos de manu pastorum; insuper et hausit aquam nobis potumque dedit ovibus.

column2: But he said: Where is he? why have you let the man go? call him that he may eat bread.
column4: At ille: “Ubi est?”, inquit. “Quare dimisistis hominem? Vocate eum, ut comedat panem”.

column2: And Moses was content to dwell with the man. And he took Sephora his daughter to wife.
column4: Consensit ergo Moyses habitare cum eo accepitque Sephoram filiam eius uxorem.

column2: And she bore him a son, whom he called Gersam, saying: I have been a stranger in a foreign country.
column4: Quæ peperit ei filium, quem vocavit Gersam dicens: Advena sum in terra aliena.

column2: Ruth said, "Don't urge me to leave you, and to return from following you, for where you go, I will go; and where you stay, I will stay. Your people will be my people, and your God my God. Where you die, I will die, and there I will be buried. May God do so to me, and more also, if anything but death parts you and me."
column4: Quæ respondit: Noli instare mihi, ut relinquam te et abeam; quocumque perrexeris, pergam; ubi morata fueris, et ego pariter morabor: populus tuus populus meus et Deus tuus Deus meus. Quæ te morientem terra susceperit, in ea moriar ibique locum accipiam sepulturæ. Hæc mihi faciat Dominus et hæc addat, si non sola mors me et te separaverit.

column2: A certain man of Bethlehem Judah went to live in the country of Moab with his wife and his two sons.
column4: Abiitque homo de Bethlehem Iudæ, ut peregrinaretur in regione Moabitide cum uxore sua ac duobus liberis.

column2: I wasn't married at that time.
I wasn't married at that time.
He was afraid of the dog.
After she was returned to her mother in law, Noemi said to her: My daughter, I will seek rest for thee, and will provide that it may be well with thee.
column4: Et dixit ad eam Noemi socrus sua: Filia mea, quæram tibi requiem et providebo, ut bene sit tibi.

column2: This Boaz, with whose maids thou wast joined in the field, is our near kinsman, and behold this night he winnoweth barley in the threshingfloor.
column4: Booz propinquus noster, cuius puellis in agro iuncta eras, ecce ipse hac nocte aream hordei ventilat.

column2: Wash thyself therefore and anoint thee, and put on thy best garments, and go down to the barnfloor: but let not the man see thee, till he shall have done eating and drinking.
column4: Lavare igitur, ungere et induere pallio tuo ac descende in aream; non te videat homo, donec esum potumque finierit.

column2: And when he shall go to sleep, mark the place wherein he sleepeth: and thou shalt go in, and lift up the clothes wherewith he is covered towards his feet, and shalt lay thyself down there: and he will tell thee what thou must do.
column4: Quando autem ierit ad dormiendum, nota locum, in quo dormiat; veniesque et discooperies pallium, quo operitur a parte pedum, et ibi iacebis. Ipse autem dicet tibi quid agere debeas.

column2: She answered: Whatsoever thou shalt command, I will do.
And she went down to the barnfloor, and did all that her mother in law had bid her.
column4: Descenditque in aream et fecit omnia, quæ sibi imperaverat socrus.

column2: And when Boaz had eaten, and drunk, and was merry, he went to sleep by the heap of sheaves, and she came softly, and uncovering his feet, laid herself down.
