column4: Et erit quasi signum in manu tua et quasi monumentum inter oculos tuos, ut lex Domini semper sit in ore tuo; in manu enim forti eduxit te Dominus de Aegypto.

column2: Thou shalt keep this observance at the set time from days to days.
column4: Custodies huiuscemodi cultum statuto tempore a diebus in dies.

column2: And when the Lord shall have brought thee into the land of the Canaanite, as he swore to thee and thy fathers, and shall give it thee: Thou shalt set apart all that openeth the womb for the Lord, and all that is first brought forth of thy cattle: whatsoever thou shalt have of the male sex, thou shalt consecrate to the Lord.
column4: Cumque introduxerit te Dominus in terram Chananæi, sicut iuravit tibi et patribus tuis, et dederit tibi eam, separabis omne, quod aperit vulvam, Domino et quod primitivum est in pecoribus tuis; quidquid habueris masculini sexus, consecrabis Domino.

column2: The firstborn of an ass thou shalt change for a sheep: and if thou do not redeem it, thou shalt kill it. And every firstborn of men thou shalt redeem with a price.
column4: Primogenitum asini mutabis ove; quod, si non redemeris, interficies. Omne autem primogenitum hominis de filiis tuis pretio redimes.

column2: And when thy son shall ask thee to morrow, saying: What is this? thou shalt answer him: With a strong hand did the Lord bring us forth out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage. For when Pharaoh was hardened, and would not let us go, the Lord slew every firstborn in the land of Egypt, from the firstborn of man to the firstborn of beasts: therefore I sacrifice to the Lord all that openeth the womb of the male sex, and all the firstborn of my sons I redeem.
column4: Cumque interrogaverit te filius tuus cras dicens: "Quid est hoc?", respondebis ei: "In manu forti eduxit nos Dominus de Aegypto, de domo servitutis. Nam, cum induratus esset pharao et nollet nos dimittere, occidit Dominus omne primogenitum in terra Aegypti, a primogenito hominis usque ad primogenitum iumentorum; idcirco immolo Domino omne, quod aperit vulvam, masculini sexus, et omnia primogenita filiorum meorum redimo".

column2: And it shall be as a sign in thy hand, and as a thing hung between thy eyes, for a remembrance: because the Lord hath brought us forth out of Egypt by a strong hand.
column4: Erit igitur quasi signum in manu tua et quasi appensum quid ob recordationem inter oculos tuos, eo quod in manu forti eduxit nos Dominus de Aegypto.

column2: And when Pharaoh had sent out the people, the Lord led them not by the way of the land of the Philistines, which is near; thinking lest perhaps they would repent, if they should see wars arise against them, and would return into Egypt.But he led them about by the way of the desert, which is by the Red Sea: and the children of Israel went up armed out of the land of Egypt.
column4: Igitur cum emisisset pharao populum, non eos duxit Deus per viam terræ Philisthim, quæ vicina est, reputans ne forte pæniteret populum, si vidisset adversum se bella consurgere, et reverteretur in Aegyptum, sed circumduxit per viam deserti, quæ est iuxta mare Rubrum. Et armati ascenderunt filii Israel de terra Aegypti.

column2: And Moses took Joseph's bones with him: because he had adjured the children of Israel, saying: God shall visit you, carry out my bones from hence with you.
column4: Tulit quoque Moyses ossa Ioseph secum, eo quod adiurasset filios Israel dicens: Visitabit vos Deus; efferte ossa mea hinc vobiscum.

column2: And marching from Socoth, they encamped in Etham, in the utmost coasts of the wilderness.
column4: Profectique de Succoth castrametati sunt in Etham, in extremis finibus solitudinis.

column2: And the Lord went before them to shew the way, by day in a pillar of a cloud, and by night in a pillar of fire; that he might be the guide of their journey at both times.
column4: Dominus autem præcedebat eos ad ostendendam viam per diem in columna nubis et per noctem in columna ignis, ut dux esset itineris utroque tempore.

column2: There never failed the pillar of the cloud by day, nor the pillar of fire by night, before the people.
column4: Nunquam defuit columna nubis per diem, nec columna ignis per noctem, coram populo.

column2: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying: Speak to the children of Israel: Let them turn and encamp over against Phihahiroth, which is between Magdal and the sea over against Beelsephon: you shall encamp before it upon the sea.
column4: Locutus est autem Dominus ad Moysen dicens: "Loquere filiis Israel: Reversi castrametentur e regione Phihahiroth, quæ est inter Magdolum et mare contra Beelsephon; in conspectu eius castra ponetis super mare."

column2: And Pharaoh will say of the children of Israel: They are straitened in the land, the desert hath shut them in.
column4: Dicturusque est pharao super filiis Israel: Errant in terra, conclusit eos desertum.

column2: And I shall harden his heart and he will pursue you: and I shall be glorified in Pharaoh, and in all his army: and the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord.
column4: Et indurabo cor eius, ac persequetur eos, et glorificabor in pharaone et in omni exercitu eius; scientque Aegyptii quia ego sum Dominus.

column2: And they did so. And it was told the king of the Egyptians that the people was fled: and the heart of Pharaoh and of his servants was changed with regard to the people, and they said: What meant we to do, that we let Israel go from serving us?
column4: Feceruntque ita. Et nuntiatum est regi Aegyptiorum quod fugisset populus; immutatumque est cor pharaonis et servorum eius super populo, et dixerunt: Quid hoc fecimus, ut dimitteremus Israel, ne servirent nobis?

column2: So he made ready his chariot, and took all his people with him. And he took six hundred chosen chariots, and all the chariots that were in Egypt: and the captains of the whole army.
column4: Iunxit ergo currum et omnem populum suum assumpsit secum; tulitque sescentos currus electos et quidquid in Aegypto curruum fuit et bellatores in singulis curribus.

column2: If I were rich, I'd travel.
If I were rich, I'd buy it.
And the Lord hardened the heart of Pharaoh, king of Egypt, and he pursued the children of Israel; but they were gone forth in a mighty hand.
column4: Induravitque Dominus cor pharaonis regis Aegypti, et persecutus est filios Israel; at illi egressi erant in manu excelsa.

column2: And when the Egyptians followed the steps of them who were gone before, they found them encamped at the sea side: all Pharaoh's horse and chariots and the whole army were in Phihahiroth, before Beelsephon.
column4: Cumque persequerentur Aegyptii vestigia præcedentium, reppererunt eos in castris super mare; omnes equi et currus pharaonis, equites et exercitus eius erant in Phihahiroth contra Beelsephon.

column2: And when Pharaoh drew near, the children of Israel lifting up their eyes, saw the Egyptians behind them: and they feared exceedingly, and cried to the Lord. And they said to Moses: Perhaps there were no graves in Egypt, therefore thou hast brought us to die in the wilderness: why wouldst thou do this, to lead us out of Egypt?
column4: Cumque appropinquasset pharao, levantes filii Israel oculos viderunt Aegyptios post se et timuerunt valde clamaveruntque ad Dominum et dixerunt ad Moysen: Forsitan non erant sepulcra in Aegypto? Ideo tulisti nos, ut moreremur in solitudine. Quid hoc fecisti, ut educeres nos ex Aegypto?

column2: Is not this the word that we spoke to thee in Egypt, saying: Depart from us, that we may serve the Egyptians? for it was much better to serve them, than to die in the wilderness.
column4: Nonne iste est sermo, quem loquebamur ad te in Aegypto dicentes: Recede a nobis, ut serviamus Aegyptiis? Multo enim melius erat servire eis quam mori in solitudine.

column2: And Moses said to the people: Fear not: stand, and see the great wonders of the Lord, which he will do this day; for the Egyptians, whom you see now, you shall see no more for ever.
column4: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Nolite timere; state et videte salutem Domini, quam facturus est vobis hodie; Aegyptios enim, quos nunc videtis, nequaquam ultra videbitis usque in sempiternum.

column2: The Lord will fight for you, and you shall hold your peace.
column4: Dominus pugnabit pro vobis, et vos silebitis.

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: Why criest thou to me? Speak to the children of Israel to go forward.
column4: Dixitque Dominus ad Moysen: Quid clamas ad me? Loquere filiis Israel, ut proficiscantur.

column2: But lift thou up thy rod, and stretch forth thy hand over the sea, and divide it: that the children of Israel may go through the midst of the sea on dry ground.
column4: Tu autem eleva virgam tuam et extende manum tuam super mare et divide illud, ut gradiantur filii Israel in medio mari per siccum.

column2: And I will harden the heart of the Egyptians to pursue you: and I will be glorified in Pharaoh, and in all his host, and in his chariots and in his horsemen.
column4: Ego autem indurabo cor Aegyptiorum, ut persequantur eos; et glorificabor in pharaone et in omni exercitu eius, in curribus et in equitibus illius.

column2: And the Egyptians shall know that I am the Lord, when I shall be glorified in Pharaoh, and in his chariots, and in his horsemen.
column4: Et scient Aegyptii quia ego sum Dominus, cum glorificatus fuero in pharaone, in curribus atque in equitibus eius.

column2: And the angel of God, who went before the camp of Israel, removing, went behind them: and together with him the pillar of the cloud, leaving the forepart, stood behind, between the Egyptians' camp and the camp of Israel: and it was a dark cloud, and enlightening the night, so that they could not come at one another all the night.
column4: Tollensque se angelus Dei, qui præcedebat castra Israel, abiit post eos; et cum eo pariter columna nubis, priora dimittens, post tergum. Stetit inter castra Aegyptiorum et castra Israel; et erat nubes tenebrosa et illuminans noctem, ita ut ad se invicem toto noctis tempore accedere non valerent.

column2: And when Moses had stretched forth his hand over the sea, the Lord took it away by a strong and burning wind blowing all the night, and turned it into dry ground: and the water was divided.
column4: Cumque extendisset Moyses manum super mare, reppulit illud Dominus, flante vento vehementi et urente tota nocte, et vertit in siccum; divisaque est aqua.

column2: And the children of Israel went in through the midst of the sea dried up; for the water was as a wall on their right hand and on their left.
column4: Et ingressi sunt filii Israel per medium maris sicci; erat enim aqua quasi murus a dextra eorum et læva.

column2: And the Egyptians pursuing went in after them, and all Pharaoh's horses, his chariots and horsemen, through the midst of the sea.
column4: Persequentesque Aegyptii ingressi sunt post eos, omnis equitatus pharaonis, currus eius et equites per medium maris.

column2: And now the morning watch was come, and behold the Lord looking upon the Egyptian army through the pillar of fire and of the cloud, slew their host.
column4: Iamque advenerat vigilia matutina, et ecce respiciens Dominus super castra Aegyptiorum per columnam ignis et nubis perturbavit exercitum eorum.

column2: And overthrew the wheels of the chariots, and they were carried into the deep. And the Egyptians said: Let us flee from Israel; for the Lord fighteth for them against us.
column4: Et impedivit rotas curruum, ita ut difficile moverentur. Dixerunt ergo Aegyptii: Fugiamus Israelem! Dominus enim pugnat pro eis contra nos.

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: Stretch forth thy hand over the sea, that the waters may come again upon the Egyptians, upon their chariots and horsemen.
column4: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen: Extende manum tuam super mare, ut revertantur aquæ ad Aegyptios super currus et equites eorum.

column2: And when Moses had stretched forth his hand towards the sea, it returned at the first break of day to the former place: and as the Egyptians were fleeing away, the waters came upon them, and the Lord shut them up in the middle of the waves.
column4: Cumque extendisset Moyses manum contra mare, reversum est primo diluculo ad priorem locum; fugientibusque Aegyptiis occurrerunt aquæ, et involvit eos Dominus in mediis fluctibus.

column2: And the waters returned, and covered the chariots and the horsemen of all the army of Pharaoh, who had come into the sea after them, neither did there so much as one of them remain.
column4: Reversæque sunt aquæ et operuerunt currus et equites cuncti exercitus pharaonis, qui sequentes ingressi fuerant mare; ne unus quidem superfuit ex eis.

column2: But the children of Israel marched through the midst of the sea upon dry land, and the waters were to them as a wall on the right hand and on the left.
column4: Filii autem Israel perrexerunt per medium sicci maris, et aquæ eis erant quasi pro muro a dextris et a sinistris.

column2: And the Lord delivered Israel in that day out of the hands of the Egyptians.
column4: Liberavitque Dominus in die illo Israel de manu Aegyptiorum.

column2: And they saw the Egyptians dead upon the sea shore, and the mighty hand that the Lord had used against them: and the people feared the Lord, and they believed the Lord, and Moses his servant.
column4: Et viderunt Aegyptios mortuos super litus maris et manum magnam, quam exercuerat Dominus contra eos; timuitque populus Dominum et crediderunt Domino et Moysi servo eius.

column2: Then Moses and the children of Israel sung this canticle to the Lord, and said: Let us sing to the Lord: for he is gloriously magnified, the horse and the rider he hath thrown into the sea.
column4: Tunc cecinit Moyses et filii Israel carmen hoc Domino, et dixerunt: Cantemus Domino, gloriose enim magnificatus est: equum et ascensorem eius deiecit in mare!

column2: Now we are afraid of the paradise we created.
column4: nunc paradīsum, ā nōbīs creātum, timēmus.

column2: The Lord is my strength and my praise, and he is become salvation to me.
column4: Fortitudo mea et robur meum Dominus, et factus est mihi in salutem.

column2: He is my God, and I will glorify him: the God of my father, and I will exalt him.
column4: Iste Deus meus, et glorificabo eum; Deus patris mei, et exaltabo eum!

column2: The Lord is as a man of war, Almighty is his name.
column4: Dominus quasi vir pugnator; Dominus nomen eius!

column2: Pharaoh's chariots and his army he hath cast into the sea: his chosen captains are drowned in the Red Sea.
column4: Currus pharaonis et exercitum eius proiecit in mare; electi bellatores eius submersi sunt in mari Rubro.

column2: The depths have covered them, they are sunk to the bottom like a stone.
column4: Abyssi operuerunt eos, descenderunt in profundum quasi lapis.

column2: Thy right hand, O Lord, is magnified in strength: thy right hand, O Lord, hath slain the enemy.
column4: Dextera tua, Domine, magnifice in fortitudine, dextera tua, Domine, percussit inimicum.

column2: And in the multitude of thy glory thou hast put down thy adversaries: thou hast sent thy wrath, which hath devoured them like stubble.
column4: Et in multitudine gloriæ tuæ deposuisti adversarios tuos; misisti iram tuam, quæ devoravit eos sicut stipulam.

column2: And with the blast of thy anger the waters were gathered together: the flowing water stood, the depths were gathered together in the midst of the sea.
column4: Et in spiritu furoris tui congregatæ sunt aquæ; stetit ut agger unda fluens, coagulatæ sunt abyssi in medio mari.

column2: The enemy said: I will pursue and overtake, I will divide the spoils, my soul shall have its fill: I will draw my sword, my hand shall slay them.
column4: Dixit inimicus: Persequar, comprehendam, dividam spolia, implebitur anima mea; evaginabo gladium meum, interficiet eos manus mea!

column2: Thy wind blew and the sea covered them: they sunk as lead in the mighty waters.
column4: Flavit spiritus tuus, et operuit eos mare; submersi sunt quasi plumbum in aquis vehementibus.

column2: Who is like to thee, among the gods, O Lord? who is like to thee, glorious in holiness, terrible and praise-worthy, doing wonders?
column4: Quis similis tui in diis, Domine? Quis similis tui, magnificus in sanctitate, terribilis atque laudabilis, faciens mirabilia?

column2: Thou stretchedst forth thy hand, and the earth swallowed them.
column4: Extendisti manum tuam, devoravit eos terra.

column2: In thy mercy thou hast been a leader to the people which thou hast redeemed: and in thy strength thou hast carried them to thy holy habitation.
column4: Dux fuisti in misericordia tua populo, quem redemisti, et portasti eum in fortitudine tua ad habitaculum sanctum tuum.

column2: Nations rose up, and were angry: sorrows took hold on the inhabitants of Philisthiim.
column4: Attenderunt populi et commoti sunt, dolores obtinuerunt habitatores Philisthææ.

column2: Then were the princes of Edom troubled, trembling seized on the stout men of Moab: all the inhabitants of Canaan became stiff.
column4: Tunc conturbati sunt principes Edom, potentes Moab obtinuit tremor, obriguerunt omnes habitatores Chanaan.

column2: Let fear and dread fall upon them, in the greatness of thy arm: let them become immoveable as a stone, until thy people, O Lord, pass by: until this thy people pass by, which thou hast possessed.
column4: Irruit super eos formido et pavor; in magnitudine brachii tui fiunt immobiles quasi lapis, donec pertranseat populus tuus, Domine, donec pertranseat populus tuus iste, quem possedisti.

column2: I know that Tom is a very strong man.
Thou shalt bring them in, and plant them in the mountain of thy inheritance, in thy most firm habitation, which thou hast made, O Lord; thy sanctuary, O Lord, which thy hands have established.
column4: Introduces eos et plantabis in monte hereditatis tuæ, firmissimo habitaculo tuo, quod operatus es, Domine, sanctuario, Domine, quod firmaverunt manus tuæ.

column2: The Lord shall reign for ever and ever.
column4: Dominus regnabit in æternum et ultra!

column2: For Pharaoh went in on horseback with his chariots and horsemen into the sea: and the Lord brought back upon them the waters of the sea: but the children of Israel walked on dry ground in the midst thereof.
column4: Ingressi sunt enim equi pharaonis cum curribus et equitibus eius in mare, et reduxit super eos Dominus aquas maris; filii autem Israel ambulaverunt per siccum in medio eius.

column2: So Mary the prophetess, the sister of Aaron, took a timbrel in her hand: and all the women went forth after her with timbrels and with dances.
column4: Sumpsit ergo Maria prophetissa soror Aaron tympanum in manu sua; egressæque sunt omnes mulieres post eam cum tympanis et choris.

column2: And she began the song to them, saying: Let us sing to the Lord, for he is gloriously magnified, the horse and his rider he hath thrown into the sea.
column4: Quibus præcinebat dicens: Cantemus Domino, gloriose enim magnificatus est: equum et ascensorem eius deiecit in mare!

column2: And Moses brought Israel from the Red Sea, and they went forth into the wilderness of Sur: and they marched three days through the wilderness, and found no water.
column4: Tulit autem Moyses Israel de mari Rubro, et egressi sunt in desertum Sur; ambulaveruntque tribus diebus per solitudinem et non inveniebant aquam.

column2: And they came into Mara, and they could not drink the waters of Mara because they were bitter: whereupon he gave a name also agreeable to the place, calling it Mara, that is, bitterness.
column4: Et venerunt in Mara nec poterant bibere aquas de Mara, eo quod essent amaræ; unde vocatum est nomen eius Mara (id est Amaritudo).

column2: And the people murmured against Moses, saying: What shall we drink?
column4: Et murmuravit populus contra Moysen dicens: Quid bibemus?

column2: But he cried to the Lord, and he shewed him a tree, which when he had cast into the waters, they were turned into sweetness.
column4: At ille clamavit ad Dominum, qui ostendit ei lignum; quod cum misisset in aquas, in dulcedinem versæ sunt.

column2: There he appointed him ordinances, and judgments, and there he proved him, saying: If thou wilt hear the voice of the Lord thy God, and do what is right before him, and obey his commandments, and keep all his precepts, none of the evils that I laid upon Egypt, will I bring upon thee: for I am the Lord thy healer.
column4: Ibi constituit ei præcepta atque iudicia et ibi tentavit eum dicens: Si audieris vocem Domini Dei tui et, quod rectum est coram eo, feceris et obœdieris mandatis eius custodierisque omnia præcepta illius, cunctum languorem, quem posui in Aegypto, non inducam super te: Ego enim Dominus sanator tuus.

column2: And the children of Israel came into Elim, where there were twelve fountains of water, and seventy palm trees: and they encamped by the waters.
column4: Venerunt autem in Elim, ubi erant duodecim fontes aquarum et septuaginta palmæ; et castrametati sunt iuxta aquas.

column2: And they set forward from Elim, and all the multitude of the children of Israel came into the desert of Sin, which is between Elim and Sinai: the fifteenth day of the second month, after they came out of the land of Egypt.
column4: Profectique sunt de Elim, et venit omnis congregatio filiorum Israel in desertum Sin, quod est inter Elim et Sinai, quinto decimo die mensis secundi postquam egressi sunt de terra Aegypti.

column2: And all the congregation of the children of Israel murmured against Moses and Aaron in the wilderness.
column4: Et murmuravit omnis congregatio filiorum Israel contra Moysen et Aaron in solitudine.

column2: And the children of Israel said to them: Would to God we had died by the hand of the Lord in the land of Egypt, when we sat over the fleshpots, and ate bread to the full: Why have you brought us into this desert, that you might destroy all the multitude with famine?
column4: Dixeruntque filii Israel ad eos: Utinam mortui essemus per manum Domini in terra Aegypti, quando sedebamus super ollas carnium et comedebamus panem in saturitate. Cur eduxistis nos in desertum istud, ut occideretis omnem cœtum fame?

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: Behold I will rain bread from heaven for you; let the people go forth, and gather what is sufficient for every day: that I may prove them whether they will walk in my law, or not.
column4: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Ecce ego pluam vobis panes de cælo; egrediatur populus et colligat, quæ sufficiunt per singulos dies, ut tentem eum, utrum ambulet in lege mea an non.

column2: But the sixth day let them provide for to bring in: and let it be double to that they were wont to gather every day.
column4: Die autem sexta parabunt quod intulerint, et duplum erit quam colligere solebant per singulos dies.

column2: And Moses and Aaron said to the children of Israel: In the evening you shall know that the Lord hath brought you forth out of the land of Egypt: And in the morning you shall see the glory of the Lord.
column4: Dixeruntque Moyses et Aaron ad omnes filios Israel: Vespere scietis quod Dominus eduxerit vos de terra Aegypti; et mane videbitis gloriam Domini.

column2: For he hath heard your murmuring against the Lord: but as for us, what are we, that you mutter against us?
column4: Audivit enim murmur vestrum contra Dominum. Nos vero quid sumus, quia mussitatis contra nos?

column2: And Moses said: In the evening the Lord will give you flesh to eat, and in the morning bread to the full: for he hath heard your murmurings, with which you have murmured against him, for what are we? your murmuring is not against us, but against the Lord.
column4: Et ait Moyses: Dabit Dominus vobis vespere carnes edere et mane panes in saturitate, eo quod audierit murmurationes vestras, quibus murmurati estis contra eum. Nos enim quid sumus? Nec contra nos est murmur vestrum, sed contra Dominum.

column2: Moses also said to Aaron: Say to the whole congregation of the children of Israel: Come before the Lord; for he hath heard your murmuring.
column4: Dixitque Moyses ad Aaron: Dic universæ congregationi filiorum Israel: Accedite coram Domino; audivit enim murmur vestrum.

column2: And when Aaron spoke to all the assembly of the children of Israel, they looked towards the wilderness; and behold the glory of the Lord appeared in a cloud.
column4: Cumque loqueretur Aaron ad omnem cœtum filiorum Israel, respexerunt ad solitudinem, et ecce gloria Domini apparuit in nube.

column2: And the Lord spoke to Moses, saying: I have heard the murmuring of the children of Israel, say to them: In the evening you shall eat flesh, and in the morning you shall have your fill of bread; and you shall know that I am the Lord your God.
column4: Locutus est autem Dominus ad Moysen dicens: Audivi murmurationes filiorum Israel. Loquere ad eos: Vespere comedetis carnes et mane saturabimini panibus scietisque quod ego sum Dominus Deus vester.

column2: So it came to pass in the evening, that quails coming up, covered the camp: and in the morning a dew lay round about the camp.
column4: Factum est ergo vespere, et ascendens coturnix operuit castra; mane quoque ros iacuit per circuitum castrorum.

column2: And when it had covered the face of the earth, it appeared in the wilderness small, and as it were beaten with a pestle, like unto the hoar frost on the ground.
column4: Cumque operuisset superficiem deserti, apparuit minutum et squamatum in similitudinem pruinæ super terram.

column2: And when the children of Israel saw it, they said one to another: Manhu! which signifieth: What is this! for they knew not what it was. And Moses said to them: This is the bread which the Lord hath given you to eat.
column4: Quod cum vidissent filii Israel, dixerunt ad invicem: "Manhu?” (quod significat: “Quid est hoc?”). Ignorabant enim quid esset. Quibus ait Moyses: “Iste est panis, quem dedit Dominus vobis ad vescendum."

column2: This is the word that the Lord hath commanded: Let every one gather of it as much as is enough to eat; a gomor for every man, according to the number of your souls that dwell in a tent, so shall you take of it.
column4: Hic est sermo, quem præcepit Dominus: Colligat ex eo unusquisque quantum sufficiat ad vescendum; gomor per singula capita iuxta numerum animarum vestrarum, quæ habitant in tabernaculo, sic tolletis.

column2: And the children of Israel did so: and they gathered, one more, another less.
column4: Feceruntque ita filii Israel; et collegerunt alius plus, alius minus.

column2: And they measured by the measure of a gomor: neither had he more that had gathered more; nor did he find less that had provided less: but every one had gathered, according to what they were able to eat.
column4: Et mensi sunt ad mensuram gomor; nec qui plus collegerat, habuit amplius, nec qui minus paraverat, repperit minus, sed singuli, iuxta id quod edere poterant, congregaverunt.

column2: And Moses said to them: Let no man leave thereof till the morning.
column4: Dixitque Moyses ad eos: Nullus relinquat ex eo in mane.

column2: And they hearkened not to him, but some of them left until the morning, and it began to be full of worms, and it putrified, and Moses was angry with them.
column4: Qui non audierunt eum, sed dimiserunt quidam ex eis usque mane, et scatere cœpit vermibus atque computruit; et iratus est contra eos Moyses.

column2: Now every one of them gathered in the morning, as much as might suffice to eat: and after the sun grew hot, it melted.
column4: Colligebant autem mane singuli, quantum sufficere poterat ad vescendum; cumque incaluisset sol, liquefiebat.

column2: But on the sixth day they gathered twice as much, that is, two gomors every man: and all the rulers of the multitude came, and told Moses.
column4: In die autem sexta collegerunt cibos duplices, id est duo gomor per singulos homines. Venerunt autem omnes principes congregationis et narraverunt Moysi.

column2: And he said to them: This is what the Lord hath spoken: To morrow is the rest of the sabbath sanctified to the Lord. Whatsoever work is to be done, do it; and the meats that are to be dressed, dress them; and whatsoever shall remain, lay it up until the morning.
column4: Qui ait eis: Hoc est quod locutus est Dominus: Requies, sabbatum sanctum Domino cras; quodcumque torrendum est, torrete et, quæ coquenda sunt, coquite; quidquid autem reliquum fuerit, reponite usque in mane.

column2: And they did so as Moses had commanded, and it did not putrify, neither was there worm found in it.
column4: Feceruntque ita, ut præceperat Moyses, et non computruit, neque vermis inventus est in eo.

column2: And Moses said: Eat it to day, because it is the sabbath of the Lord: to day it shall not be found in the field.
column4: Dixitque Moyses: Comedite illud hodie, quia sabbatum est Domino; non invenietur hodie in agro.

column2: Gather it six days; but on the seventh day is the sabbath of the Lord, therefore it shall not be found.
column4: Sex diebus colligite; in die autem septimo sabbatum est Domino, idcirco non invenietur in eo.

column2: And the seventh day came; and some of the people going forth to gather, found none.
column4: Venitque septima dies; et egressi de populo, ut colligerent, non invenerunt.

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: How long will you refuse to keep my commandments, and my law?
column4: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Usquequo non vultis custodire mandata mea et legem meam?

column2: See that the Lord hath given you the sabbath, and for this reason on the sixth day he giveth you a double provision: let each man stay at home, and let none go forth out of his place the seventh day.
column4: Videte quod Dominus dederit vobis sabbatum et propter hoc die sexta tribuit vobis cibos duplices; maneat unusquisque apud semetipsum, nullus egrediatur de loco suo die septimo.

column2: And the people kept the sabbath on the seventh day.
And the house of Israel called the name thereof Manna: and it was like coriander seed, white, and the taste thereof like to flour with honey.
column4: Appellavitque domus Israel nomen eius Man: quod erat quasi semen coriandri album, gustusque eius quasi similæ cum melle.

column2: And Moses said: This is the word which the Lord hath commanded: Fill a gomor of it, and let it be kept unto generations to come hereafter; that they may know the bread, wherewith I fed you in the wilderness when you were brought forth out of the land of Egypt.
column4: Dixit autem Moyses: Iste est sermo, quem præcepit Dominus: "Imple gomor ex eo, et custodiatur in generationes vestras, ut noverint panem, quo alui vos in solitudine, quando educti estis de terra Aegypti".

column2: And Moses said to Aaron: Take a vessel, and put manna into it, as much as a gomor can hold; and lay it up before the Lord, to keep unto your generations.
column4: Dixitque Moyses ad Aaron: Sume vas unum et mitte ibi man, quantum potest capere gomor; et repone coram Domino ad servandum in generationes vestras.

column2: As the Lord commanded Moses. And Aaron put it in the tabernacle to be kept.
column4: Sicut præcepit Dominus Moysi, posuit illud Aaron coram testimonio reservandum.

column2: And the children of Israel ate manna forty years, till they came to a habitable land: with this meat were they fed, until they reached the borders of the land of Canaan.
column4: Filii autem Israel comederunt man quadraginta annis, donec venirent in terram habitabilem; hoc cibo aliti sunt, usquequo tangerent fines terræ Chanaan.

column2: Now a gomor is the tenth part of an ephi.
column4: Gomor autem decima pars est ephi.

column2: Then all the multitude of the children of Israel setting forward from the desert of Sin, by their mansions, according to the word of the Lord, encamped in Raphidim, where there was no water for the people to drink.
column4: Igitur profecta omnis congregatio filiorum Israel de deserto Sin per mansiones suas iuxta sermonem Domini, castrametati sunt in Raphidim, ubi non erat aqua ad bibendum populo.

column2: And they chode with Moses, and said: Give us water, that we may drink. And Moses answered them: Why chide you with me? Wherefore do you tempt the Lord?
column4: Qui iurgatus contra Moysen ait: "Da nobis aquam, ut bibamus”. Quibus respondit Moyses: “Quid iurgamini contra me? Cur tentatis Dominum?”

column2: So the people were thirsty there for want of water, and murmured against Moses, saying: Why didst thou make us go forth out of Egypt, to kill us and our children, and our beasts with thirst?
column4: Sitivit ergo ibi populus præ aquæ penuria et murmuravit contra Moysen dicens: Cur fecisti nos exire de Aegypto, ut occideres nos et liberos nostros ac iumenta siti?

column2: And Moses cried to the Lord, saying: What shall I do to this people? Yet a little more and they will stone me.
column4: Clamavit autem Moyses ad Dominum dicens: Quid faciam populo huic? Adhuc paululum et lapidabunt me.

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: Go before the people, and take with thee of the ancients of Israel: and take in thy hand the rod wherewith thou didst strike the river, and go.
column4: Et ait Dominus ad Moysen: Antecede populum et sume tecum de senioribus Israel, et virgam, qua percussisti fluvium, tolle in manu tua et vade.

column2: Behold I will stand there before thee, upon the rock Horeb, and thou shalt strike the rock, and water shall come out of it that the people may drink. Moses did so before the ancients of Israel.
column4: En ego stabo coram te ibi super petram Horeb; percutiesque petram, et exibit ex ea aqua, ut bibat populus. Fecit Moyses ita coram senioribus Israel.

column2: And he called the name of that place Temptation, because of the chiding of the children of Israel, and for that they tempted the Lord, saying: Is the Lord amongst us or not?
column4: Et vocavit nomen loci illius Massa et Meriba, propter iurgium filiorum Israel et quia tentaverunt Dominum dicentes: Estne Dominus in nobis an non?

column2: And Amalec came, and fought against Israel in Raphidim.
column4: Venit autem Amalec et pugnabat contra Israel in Raphidim.

column2: And Moses said to Josue: Choose out men; and go out and fight against Amalec: tomorrow I will stand on the top of the hill, having the rod of God in my hand.
column4: Dixitque Moyses ad Iosue: Elige nobis viros et egressus pugna contra Amalec; cras ego stabo in vertice collis habens virgam Dei in manu mea.

column2: How do you know I don't know?
Josue did as Moses had spoken, and he fought against Amalec; but Moses, and Aaron, and Hur, went up upon the top of the hill.
column4: Fecit Iosue, ut locutus erat ei Moyses, et pugnavit contra Amalec; Moyses autem et Aaron et Hur ascenderunt super verticem collis.

column2: And when Moses lifted up his hands, Israel overcame; but if he let them down a little, Amalec overcame.
column4: Cumque levaret Moyses manus, vincebat Israel; sin autem remisisset, superabat Amalec.

column2: And Moses's hands were heavy: so they took a stone, and put under him, and he sat on it: and Aaron and Hur stayed up his hands on both sides. And it came to pass, that his hands were not weary until sunset.
column4: Manus autem Moysi erant graves; sumentes igitur lapidem posuerunt subter eum, in quo sedit; Aaron autem et Hur sustentabant manus eius ex utraque parte. Et factum est ut manus eius non lassarentur usque ad occasum solis.

column2: And Josue put Amalec and his people to flight, by the edge of the sword.
column4: Vicitque Iosue Amalec et populum eius in ore gladii.

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: Write this for a memorial in a book, and deliver it to the ears of Josue; for I will destroy the memory of Amalec from under heaven.
column4: Dixit autem Dominus ad Moysen: Scribe hoc ob monumentum in libro et trade auribus Iosue; delebo enim memoriam Amalec sub cælo.

column2: And Moses built an altar; and called the name thereof, The Lord, my exaltation, saying: Because the hand of the throne of the Lord, and the war of the Lord shall be against Amalec, from generation to generation.
column4: Aedificavitque Moyses altare et vocavit nomen eius Dominus Nissi (Dominus vexillum meum) dicens: Quia manus contra solium Domini: bellum Domino erit contra Amalec a generatione in generationem.

column2: And when Jethro the priest of Madian, the kinsman of Moses, had heard all the things that God had done to Moses, and to Israel his people, and that the Lord had brought forth Israel out of Egypt:
column4: Cumque audisset Iethro sacerdos Madian socer Moysi omnia, quæ fecerat Deus Moysi et Israel populo suo, eo quod eduxisset Dominus Israel de Aegypto.

column2: He took Sephora, the wife of Moses, whom he had sent back, and her two sons, of whom one was called Gersam: his father saying, I have been a stranger in a foreign country. And the other Eliezer: For the God of my father, said he, is my helper, and hath delivered me from the sword of Pharaoh.
column4: Tulit Sephoram uxorem Moysi, quam remiserat, et duos filios eius, quorum unus vocabatur Gersam, dicente patre: “Advena fui in terra aliena”, alter vero Eliezer: “Deus enim, ait, patris mei adiutor meus, et eruit me de gladio pharaonis”.

column2: And Jethro, the kinsman of Moses, came with his sons, and his wife to Moses into the desert, where he was camped by the mountain of God. And he sent word to Moses, saying: I Jethro, thy kinsman, come to thee, and thy wife, and thy two sons with her.
column4: Venit ergo Iethro socer Moysi et filii eius et uxor eius ad Moysen in desertum, ubi erat castrametatus iuxta montem Dei; et mandavit Moysi dicens: Ego socer tuus Iethro venio ad te et uxor tua et duo filii tui cum ea.

column2: And he went out to meet his kinsman, and worshipped and kissed him: and they saluted one another with words of peace.
column4: Qui egressus in occursum soceri sui adoravit et osculatus est eum, salutaveruntque se mutuo verbis pacificis.

column2: And when he was come into the tent, Moses told his kinsman all that the Lord had done to Pharaoh, and the Egyptians in favour of Israel: and all the labour which had befallen them in the journey, and that the Lord had delivered them.
column4: Cumque intrasset tabernaculum, narravit Moyses socero suo cuncta, quæ fecerat Dominus pharaoni et Aegyptiis propter Israel, universumque laborem, qui accidisset eis in itinere, et quod liberaverat eos Dominus.

column2: And Jethro rejoiced for all the good things that the Lord had done to Israel, because he had delivered them out of the hands of the Egyptians.
column4: Lætatusque est Iethro super omnibus bonis, quæ fecerat Dominus Israel, eo quod eruisset eum de manu Aegyptiorum.

column2: And he said: Blessed is the Lord, who hath delivered his people out of the hand of Egypt.
column4: Et ait: Benedictus Dominus, qui liberavit vos de manu Aegyptiorum et de manu pharaonis.

column2: Now I know, that the Lord is great above all gods; because they dealt proudly against them.
column4: Nunc cognovi quia magnus Dominus super omnes deos, eo quod eruerit populum de manu Aegyptiorum, qui superbe egerunt contra illos.

column2: We're in need of some food.
So Jethro, the kinsman of Moses, offered holocausts and sacrifices to God: and Aaron and all the ancients of Israel came, to eat bread with him before God.
column4: Obtulit ergo Iethro socer Moysi holocausta et hostias Deo; veneruntque Aaron et omnes seniores Israel, ut comederent panem cum eo coram Deo.

column2: And the next day Moses sat to judge the people, who stood by Moses from morning until night.
column4: Altero autem die sedit Moyses, ut iudicaret populum, qui assistebat Moysi de mane usque ad vesperam.

column2: And when his kinsman had seen all things that he did among the people, he said: What is it that thou dost among the people? Why sittest thou alone, and all the people wait from morning till night?
column4: Quod cum vidisset socer eius, omnia scilicet, quæ agebat in populo, ait: Quid est hoc, quod facis in plebe? Cur solus sedes, et omnis populus præstolatur de mane usque ad vesperam?

column2: And Moses answered him: The people come to me to seek the judgment of God.
column4: Cui respondit Moyses: Venit ad me populus quærens sententiam Dei.

column2: And when any controversy falleth out among them, they come to me to judge between them, and to shew the precepts of God, and his laws.
column4: Cumque acciderit eis aliqua disceptatio, veniunt ad me, ut iudicem inter eos et ostendam præcepta Dei et leges eius.

column2: But he said: The thing thou dost is not good. Thou art spent with foolish labour, both thou, and this people that is with thee; the business is above thy strength, thou alone canst not bear it.
column4: At ille: Non bonam, inquit, rem facis. Consumeris et tu et populus iste, qui tecum est. Ultra vires tuas est negotium; solus illud non poteris sustinere.

column2: But hear my words and counsels, and God shall be with thee. Be thou to the people in those things that pertain to God, to bring their words to him, and to shew the people the ceremonies, and the manner of worshipping; and the way wherein they ought to walk, and the work that they ought to do.
column4: Sed audi verba mea atque consilia, et erit Deus tecum: Esto tu populo in his, quæ ad Deum pertinent, ut referas causas ad Deum ostendasque populo præcepta et leges viamque, per quam ingredi debeant, et opus, quod facere debeant.

column2: And provide out of all the people able men, such as fear God, in whom there is truth, and that hate avarice, and appoint of them rulers of thousands, and of hundreds, and of fifties, and of tens.
column4: Provide autem de omni plebe viros strenuos et timentes Deum, in quibus sit veritas, et qui oderint avaritiam, et constitue ex eis tribunos et centuriones et quinquagenarios et decanos.

column2: Who may judge the people at all times: and when any great matter soever shall fall out, let them refer it to thee, and let them judge the lesser matters only: that so it may be lighter for thee, the burden being shared out unto others.
column4: Qui iudicent populum omni tempore. Quidquid autem maius fuerit, referant ad te, et ipsi minora tantummodo iudicent; leviusque sit tibi, partito cum aliis onere.

column2: If thou dost this, thou shalt fulfil the commandment of God, and shalt be able to bear his precepts: and all this people shall return to their places with peace.
column4: Si hoc feceris, implebis imperium Dei et præcepta eius poteris sustentare, et omnis hic populus revertetur ad loca sua cum pace.

column2: And when Moses heard this, he did all things that he had suggested unto him. And choosing able men out of all Israel, he appointed them rulers of the people, rulers over thousands, and over hundreds, and over fifties, and over tens. And they judged the people at all times.
column4: Quibus auditis, Moyses fecit omnia, quæ ille suggesserat; et, electis viris strenuis de cuncto Israel, constituit eos principes populi, tribunos et centuriones et quinquagenarios et decanos, qui iudicabant plebem omni tempore.

column2: And whatsoever was of greater difficulty they referred to him, and they judged the easier cases only.
column4: Quidquid autem gravius erat, referebant ad eum, faciliora tantummodo iudicantes.

column2: And he let his kinsman depart: and he returned and went into his own country.
column4: Dimisitque socerum suum, qui reversus abiit in terram suam.

column2: In the third month of the departure of Israel out of the land of Egypt, on this day they came into the wilderness of Sinai.
column4: Mense tertio egressionis Israel de terra Aegypti, in die hac venerunt in solitudinem Sinai.

column2: For departing out of Raphidim, and coming to the desert of Sinai, they camped in the same place, and there Israel pitched their tents over against the mountain.
column4: Nam profecti de Raphidim et pervenientes usque in desertum Sinai, castrametati sunt in eodem loco, ibique Israel fixit tentoria e regione montis.

column2: And Moses went up to God; and the Lord called unto him from the mountain, and said: Thus shalt thou say to the house of Jacob, and tell the children of Israel: You have seen what I have done to the Egyptians, how I have carried you upon the wings of eagles, and have taken you to myself.
column4: Moyses autem ascendit ad Deum, vocavitque eum Dominus de monte et ait: Hæc dices domui Iacob et annuntiabis filiis Israel: "Vos ipsi vidistis, quæ fecerim Aegyptiis, quomodo portaverim vos super alas aquilarum et adduxerim ad me."

column2: If therefore you will hear my voice, and keep my covenant, you shall be my peculiar possession above all people: for all the earth is mine.
column4: Si ergo audieritis vocem meam et custodieritis pactum meum, eritis mihi in peculium de cunctis populis; mea est enim omnis terra.

column2: And you shall be to me a priestly kingdom, and a holy nation. These are the words thou shalt speak to the children of Israel.
column4: Et vos eritis mihi regnum sacerdotum et gens sancta. Hæc sunt verba, quæ loqueris ad filios Israel.

column2: Moses came; and calling together the elders of the people, he declared all the words which the Lord had commanded.
column4: Venit Moyses et, convocatis maioribus natu populi, exposuit omnes sermones, quos mandaverat Dominus.

column2: And all the people answered together: All that the Lord hath spoken, we will do.
column4: Responditque universus populus simul: Cuncta, quæ locutus est Dominus, faciemus.

column2: And when Moses had related the people's words to the Lord, the Lord said to him: Lo, now will I come to thee in the darkness of a cloud, that the people may hear me speaking to thee, and may believe thee for ever.
column4: Cumque rettulisset Moyses verba populi ad Dominum, ait ei Dominus: Ecce ego veniam ad te in caligine nubis, ut audiat me populus loquentem ad te et tibi quoque credat in perpetuum.

column2: And Moses told the words of the people to the Lord. And he said to him: Go to the people, and sanctify them to day, and to morrow, and let them wash their garments.
column4: Nuntiavit ergo Moyses verba populi ad Dominum, qui dixit ei: Vade ad populum et sanctifica illos hodie et cras; laventque vestimenta sua.

column2: And let them be ready against the third day; for on the third day the Lord will come down in the sight of all the people, upon Mount Sinai.
column4: Et sint parati in diem tertium. In die enim tertio descendet Dominus coram omni plebe super montem Sinai.

column2: And thou shalt appoint certain limits to the people round about, and thou shalt say to them: Take heed ye go not up into the mount, and that ye touch not the borders thereof: every one that toucheth the mount, dying he shall die.
column4: Constituesque terminos populo per circuitum et dices: Cavete, ne ascendatis in montem nec tangatis fines illius; omnis, qui tetigerit montem, morte morietur.

column2: No hands shall touch him, but he shall be stoned to death, or he shall be shot through with arrows: whether it be beast, or man, he shall not live. When the trumpet shall begin to sound, then let them go up into the mount.
column4: Manus non tanget eum, sed lapidibus opprimetur aut confodietur iaculis; sive iumentum fuerit, sive homo, non vivet. Cum cœperit clangere bucina, tunc ascendant in montem.

column2: And Moses came down from the mount to the people, and sanctified them. And when they had washed their garments, he said to them: Be ready against the third day, and come not near your wives.
column4: Descenditque Moyses de monte ad populum et sanctificavit eum; cumque lavissent vestimenta sua, ait ad eos: Estote parati in diem tertium; ne appropinquetis uxoribus vestris.

column2: And now the third day was come, and the morning appeared: and behold thunders began to be heard, and lightning to flash, and a very thick cloud to cover the mount, and the noise of the trumpet sounded exceeding loud; and the people that was in the camp, feared.
column4: Iamque advenerat tertius dies, et mane inclaruerat; et ecce cœperunt audiri tonitrua ac micare fulgura et nubes densissima operire montem, clangorque bucinæ vehementius perstrepebat; et timuit populus, qui erat in castris.

column2: And when Moses had brought them forth to meet God, from the place of the camp, they stood at the bottom of the mount.
column4: Cumque eduxisset eos Moyses in occursum Dei de loco castrorum, steterunt ad radices montis.

column2: And all Mount Sinai was on a smoke: because the Lord was come down upon it in fire, and the smoke arose from it as out of a furnace: and all the mount was terrible.
column4: Totus autem mons Sinai fumabat, eo quod descendisset Dominus super eum in igne, et ascenderet fumus ex eo quasi de fornace. Et tremuit omnis mons vehementer.

column2: And the sound of the trumpet grew by degrees louder and louder, and was drawn out to a greater length: Moses spoke, and God answered him.
column4: Et sonitus bucinæ paulatim crescebat in maius; Moyses loquebatur, et Deus respondebat ei cum voce.

column2: And the Lord came down upon Mount Sinai, in the very top of the mount, and he called Moses unto the top thereof.
column4: Descenditque Dominus super montem Sinai in ipso montis vertice et vocavit Moysen in cacumen eius.

column2: And when he was gone up thither, he said unto him: Go down, and charge the people; lest they should have a mind to pass the limits to see the Lord, and a very great multitude of them should perish.
column4: Quo cum ascendisset, dixit ad eum: Descende et contestare populum, ne velit transcendere terminos ad videndum Dominum, et pereat ex eis plurima multitudo.

column2: Tom is married and lives in Boston.
column4: Thomas maritus est et Bostoni habitat.

column2: The priests also that come to the Lord, let them be sanctified, lest he strike them.
column4: Sacerdotes quoque, qui accedunt ad Dominum, sanctificentur, ne percutiat eos.

column2: And Moses said to the Lord: The people cannot come up to Mount Sinai: for thou didst charge, and command, saying: Set limits about the mount, and sanctify it.
column4: Dixitque Moyses ad Dominum: Non poterit vulgus ascendere in montem Sinai, tu enim testificatus es et iussisti dicens: "Pone terminos circa montem et sanctifica illum".

column2: And the Lord said to him: Go, get thee down; and thou shalt come up, thou and Aaron with thee: but let not the priests and the people pass the limits, nor come up to the Lord, lest he kill them.
column4: Cui ait Dominus: Vade, descende; ascendesque tu et Aaron tecum, sacerdotes autem et populus ne transeant terminos nec ascendant ad Dominum, ne interficiat illos.

column2: And Moses went down to the people and told them all.
column4: Descenditque Moyses ad populum et omnia narravit eis.

column2: And the Lord spoke all these words: I am the Lord thy God, who brought thee out of the land of Egypt, out of the house of bondage.
column4: Locutusque est Deus cunctos sermones hos: Ego sum Dominus Deus tuus, qui eduxi te de terra Aegypti, de domo servitutis.

column2: Thou shalt not have strange gods before me.
column4: Non habebis deos alienos coram me.

column2: Thou shalt not make to thyself a graven thing, nor the likeness of any thing that is in heaven above, or in the earth beneath, nor of those things that are in the waters under the earth.
column4: Non facies tibi sculptile neque omnem similitudinem eorum, quæ sunt in cælo desuper et quæ in terra deorsum et quæ in aquis sub terra.

column2: Thou shalt not adore them, nor serve them: I am the Lord thy God, mighty, jealous, visiting the iniquity of the fathers upon the children, unto the third and fourth generation of them that hate me, and shewing mercy unto thousands to them that love me, and keep my commandments.
column4: Non adorabis ea neque coles, quia ego sum Dominus Deus tuus, Deus zelotes, visitans iniquitatem patrum in filiis in tertiam et quartam generationem eorum, qui oderunt me, et faciens misericordiam in milia his, qui diligunt me et custodiunt præcepta mea.

column2: Thou shalt not take the name of the Lord thy God in vain: for the Lord will not hold him guiltless that shall take the name of the Lord his God in vain.
column4: Non assumes nomen Domini Dei tui in vanum, nec enim habebit insontem Dominus eum, qui assumpserit nomen Domini Dei sui frustra.

column2: Remember that thou keep holy the sabbath day.

Six days shalt thou labour, and shalt do all thy works. But on the seventh day is the sabbath of the Lord thy God: thou shalt do no work on it, thou nor thy son, nor thy daughter, nor thy manservant, nor thy maidservant, nor thy beast, nor the stranger that is within thy gates.
column4: Sex diebus operaberis et facies omnia opera tua; septimus autem dies sabbatum Domino Deo tuo est; non facies omne opus tu et filius tuus et filia tua, servus tuus et ancilla tua, iumentum tuum et advena, qui est intra portas tuas.

column2: For in six days the Lord made heaven and earth, and the sea, and all things that are in them, and rested on the seventh day: therefore the Lord blessed the seventh day, and sanctified it.
column4: Sex enim diebus fecit Dominus cælum et terram et mare et omnia, quæ in eis sunt, et requievit in die septimo; idcirco benedixit Dominus diei sabbati et sanctificavit eum.

column2: Honour thy father and thy mother, that thou mayst be longlived upon the land which the Lord thy God will give thee.
column4: Honora patrem tuum et matrem tuam, ut sis longævus super terram, quam Dominus Deus tuus dabit tibi.

column2: Thou shalt not bear false witness against thy neighbour.
column4: Non loqueris contra proximum tuum falsum testimonium.

column2: Thou shalt not covet thy neighbour's house; neither shalt thou desire his wife, nor his servant, nor his handmaid, nor his ox, nor his ass, nor any thing that is his.
column4: Non concupisces domum proximi tui: non desiderabis uxorem eius, non servum, non ancillam, non bovem, non asinum nec omnia, quæ illius sunt.

column2: And all the people saw the voices and the flames, and the sound of the trumpet, and the mount smoking; and being terrified and struck with fear, they stood afar off, saying to Moses: Speak thou to us, and we will hear: let not the Lord speak to us, lest we die.
column4: Cunctus autem populus videbat voces et lampades et sonitum bucinæ montemque fumantem; et perterriti ac pavore concussi steterunt procul dicentes Moysi: Loquere tu nobis, et audiemus; non loquatur nobis Deus, ne moriamur.

column2: And Moses said to the people: Fear not; for God is come to prove you, and that the dread of him might be in you, and you should not sin.
column4: Et ait Moyses ad populum: Nolite timere; ut enim probaret vos, venit Deus, et ut timor illius esset in vobis, ne peccaretis.

column2: And the people stood afar off. But Moses went to the dark cloud wherein God was.
column4: Stetitque populus de longe; Moyses autem accessit ad caliginem, in qua erat Deus.

column2: And the Lord said to Moses: Thus shalt thou say to the children of Israel: You have seen that I have spoken to you from heaven.
column4: Dixit præterea Dominus ad Moysen: Hæc dices filiis Israel: "Vos vidistis quod de cælo locutus sim vobis."

column2: I hope that I will see him tomorrow.
column4: Spero me cras eum visurum esse.

column2: You shall not make gods of silver, nor shall you make to yourselves gods of gold.
column4: Non facietis præter me deos argenteos nec deos aureos facietis vobis.

column2: You shall make an altar of earth unto me, and you shall offer upon it your holocausts and peace offerings, your sheep and oxen, in every place where the memory of my name shall be: I will come to thee, and will bless thee.
column4: Altare de terra facietis mihi et offeretis super eo holocausta et pacifica vestra, oves vestras et boves; in omni loco, in quo memoriam fecero nominis mei, veniam ad te et benedicam tibi.

column2: And if thou make an altar of stone unto me, thou shalt not build it of hewn stones; for if thou lift up a tool upon it, it shall be defiled.
column4: Quod si altare lapideum feceris mihi, non ædificabis illud de sectis lapidibus; si enim levaveris cultrum super eo, polluetur.

column2: Thou shalt not go up by steps unto my altar, lest thy nakedness be discovered.
column4: Non ascendes per gradus ad altare meum, ne reveletur turpitudo tua.

column2: These are the judgments which thou shalt set before them.
column4: Hæc sunt iudicia, quæ propones eis:

column2: If thou buy a Hebrew servant, six years shall he serve thee; in the seventh he shall go out free for nothing.
column4: Si emeris servum Hebræum, sex annis serviet tibi; in septimo egredietur liber gratis.

column2: With what raiment he came in, with the like let him go out: if having a wife, his wife also shall go out with him.
column4: Si solus intraverit, solus exeat; si habens uxorem, et uxor egredietur simul.

column2: But if his master gave him a wife, and she hath borne sons and daughters; the woman and her children shall be her master's: but he himself shall go out with his raiment.
column4: Sin autem dominus dederit illi uxorem, et pepererit filios et filias, mulier et liberi eius erunt domini sui; ipse vero exibit solus.

column2: And if the servant shall say: I love my master and my wife and children, I will not go out free: His master shall bring him to the gods, and he shall be set to the door and the posts, and he shall bore his ear through with an awl: and he shall be his servant for ever.
column4: Quod si dixerit servus: "Diligo dominum meum et uxorem ac liberos, non egrediar liber", afferet eum dominus ad Deum et applicabit eum ad ostium vel postes perforabitque aurem eius subula; et erit ei servus in sæculum.

column2: If any man sell his daughter to be a servant, she shall not go out as bondwomen are wont to go out.
column4: Si quis vendiderit filiam suam in famulam, non egredietur sicut servi exire consueverunt.

column2: If she displease the eyes of her master to whom she was delivered, he shall let her go: but he shall have no power to sell her to a foreign nation, if he despise her.
column4: Si displicuerit oculis domini sui, cui tradita fuerat, faciat eam redimi; populo autem alieno vendendi non habebit potestatem, quia fraudavit eam.

column2: But if he have betrothed her to his son, he shall deal with her after the manner of daughters.
column4: Sin autem filio suo desponderit eam, iuxta morem filiarum faciet illi.

column2: And if he take another wife for him, he shall provide her a marriage, and raiment, neither shall he refuse the price of her chastity.
column4: Quod si alteram sibi acceperit, cibum et vestimentum et concubitum non negabit.

column2: If he take him another wife; her food, her raiment, and her duty of marriage, shall he not diminish.
column4: Quod si alteram sibi acceperit, cibum et vestimentum et concubitum non negabit.

column2: If he do not these three things, she shall go out free without money.
column4: Si tria ista non fecerit ei, egredietur gratis absque pretio.

column2: He that striketh a man with a will to kill him, shall be put to death.
column4: Qui percusserit hominem, et ille mortuus fuerit, morte moriatur.

column2: But he that did not lie in wait for him, but God delivered him into his hands: I will appoint thee a place to which he must flee.
column4: Qui autem non est insidiatus, sed Deus illum tradidit in manus eius, constituam tibi locum, in quem fugere debeat.

column2: If a man kill his neighbour on set purpose, and by lying in wait for him: thou shalt take him away from my altar that he may die.
column4: Si quis de industria occiderit proximum suum et per insidias, ab altari meo evelles eum, ut moriatur.

column2: He that striketh his father or mother, shall be put to death.
column4: Qui percusserit patrem suum aut matrem, morte moriatur.

column2: He that shall steal a man, and sell him, being convicted of the guilt, shall be put to death.
column4: Qui furatus fuerit hominem sive vendiderit eum sive inventus fuerit in manu eius, morte moriatur.

column2: He that curseth his father or mother, shall die the death.
column4: Qui maledixerit patri suo vel matri, morte moriatur.

column2: If men quarrel, and the one strike his neighbour with a stone, or with his fist, and he die not, but keepeth his bed: If he rise again and walk abroad upon his staff, he that struck him shall be quit, yet so that he make restitution for his work, and for his expenses upon the physicians.
column4: Si rixati fuerint viri, et percusserit alter proximum suum lapide vel pugno, et ille mortuus non fuerit, sed iacuerit in lectulo, si surrexerit et ambulaverit foris super baculum suum, impunitus erit, qui percusserit, ita tamen, ut operas eius deperditas et impensas pro medela restituat.

column2: He that striketh his bondman, or bondwoman, with a rod, and they die under his hands, shall be guilty of the crime.
column4: Qui percusserit servum suum vel ancillam virga, et mortui fuerint in manibus eius, ultioni subiacetur.

column2: But if the party remain alive a day or two, he shall not be subject to the punishment, because it is his money.
column4: Sin autem uno die vel duobus supervixerit, non subiacebit poenae, quia pecunia illius est.

column2: If men quarrel, and one strike a woman with child and she miscarry indeed, but live herself: he shall be answerable for so much damage as the woman's husband shall require, and as arbiters shall award.
column4: Si rixati fuerint viri, et percusserit quis mulierem prægnantem et abortivum quidem fecerit, sed aliud quid adversi non acciderit, subiacebit damno, quantum maritus mulieris expetierit, et arbitri iudicaverint.

column2: But if her death ensue thereupon, he shall render life for life, eye for eye, tooth for tooth, hand for hand, foot for foot, burning for burning, wound for wound, stripe for stripe.
column4: Sin autem quid adversi acciderit, reddet animam pro anima, oculum pro oculo, dentem pro dente, manum pro manu, pedem pro pede, adustionem pro adustione, vulnus pro vulnere, livorem pro livore.

column2: If any man strike the eye of his manservant or maidservant, and leave them but one eye, he shall let them go free for the eye which he put out.
column4: Si percusserit quispiam oculum servi sui aut ancillæ et luscos eos fecerit, dimittet eos liberos pro oculo.

column2: Also if he strike out a tooth of his manservant or maidservant, he shall in like manner make them free.
column4: Dentem quoque si excusserit servo vel ancillæ suæ, dimittet eos liberos pro dente.

column2: If an ox gore a man or a woman, and they die, he shall be stoned: and his flesh shall not be eaten, but the owner of the ox shall be quit.
column4: Si bos cornu percusserit virum aut mulierem, et mortui fuerint, lapidibus obruetur, et non comedentur carnes eius; dominus autem bovis innocens erit.

column2: But if the ox was wont to push with his horn yesterday, and the day before, and they warned his master, and he did not shut him up, and he shall kill a man or a woman: then the ox shall be stoned, and his owner also shall be put to death.
column4: Quod si bos cornupeta fuerit ab heri et nudiustertius, et contestati sunt dominum eius, nec recluserit eum, occideritque virum aut mulierem: et bos lapidibus obruetur, et dominum illius occident.

column2: And if they set a price upon him, he shall give for his life whatsoever is laid upon him.
column4: Quod si pretium ei fuerit impositum, dabit pro anima sua, quidquid fuerit postulatus.

column2: If he have gored a son, or a daughter, he shall fall under the like sentence.
column4: Filium quoque vel filiam si cornu percusserit, simili sententiæ subiacebit.

column2: If he assault a bondman or bondwoman, he shall give thirty sicles of silver to their master, and the ox shall be stoned.
column4: Si servum vel ancillam invaserit, triginta siclos argenti dabit domino; bos vero lapidibus opprimetur.

column2: If a man open a pit, and dig one, and cover it not, and an ox or an ass fall into it, the owner of the pit shall pay the price of the beasts: and that which is dead shall be his own.
column4: Si quis aperuerit cisternam vel foderit et non operuerit eam, cedideritque bos vel asinus in eam, dominus cisternæ reddet pretium iumentorum; quod autem mortuum est, ipsius erit.

column2: If one man's ox gore another man's ox, and he die: they shall sell the live ox, and shall divide the price, and the carcass of that which died they shall part between them.
column4: Si bos alienus bovem alterius vulneraverit, et ille mortuus fuerit, vendent bovem vivum et divident pretium; cadaver autem mortui inter se dispertient.

column2: But if he knew that his ox was wont to push yesterday, and the day before, and his master did not keep him in; he shall pay ox for ox, and shall take the whole carcass.
column4: Sin autem notum erat quod bos cornupeta esset ab heri et nudiustertius, et non custodivit eum dominus suus, reddet bovem pro bove et cadaver integrum accipiet.

column2: If any man steal an ox or a sheep, and kill or sell it: he shall restore five oxen for one ox, and four sheep for one sheep.
column4: Si quis furatus fuerit bovem aut ovem et occiderit vel vendiderit, quinque boves pro uno bove restituet et quattuor oves pro una ove.

column2: If a thief be found breaking open a house or undermining it, and be wounded so as to die: he that slew him shall not be guilty of blood.
column4: Si effringens fur domum sive suffodiens fuerit inventus et, accepto vulnere, mortuus fuerit, percussor non erit reus sanguinis.

column2: But if he did this when the sun is risen, he hath committed murder, and he shall die. If he have not wherewith to make restitution for the theft, he shall be sold.
column4: Quod si orto sole hoc fecerit, erit reus sanguinis. Fur plene restituet. Si non habuerit, quod reddat, venumdabitur pro furto.

column2: If the sun be risen upon him, there shall be blood shed for him; for he should make full restitution; if he have nothing, then he shall be sold for his theft.
column4: Quod si orto sole hoc fecerit, erit reus sanguinis. Fur plene restituet. Si non habuerit, quod reddat, venumdabitur pro furto.

column2: If that which he stole be found with him, alive, either ox, or ass, or sheep: he shall restore double.
column4: Si inventum fuerit apud eum, quod furatus est, vivens sive bos sive asinus sive ovis, duplum restituet.

column2: If any man hurt a field or a vineyard, and put in his beast to feed upon that which is other men's: he shall restore the best of whatsoever he hath in his own field, or in his vineyard, according to the estimation of the damage.
column4: Si quispiam depasci permiserit agrum vel vineam et dimiserit iumentum suum, ut depascatur agrum alienum, restituet plene ex agro suo secundum fruges eius; si autem totum agrum depastum fuerit, quidquid optimum habuerit in agro suo vel in vinea, restituet.

column2: If a fire breaking out light upon thorns, and catch stacks of corn, or corn standing in the fields, he that kindled the fire shall make good the loss.
column4: Si egressus ignis invenerit spinas et comprehenderit acervos frugum sive stantes segetes sive agrum, reddet damnum, qui ignem succenderit.

column2: If a man deliver money, or any vessel unto his friend to keep, and they be stolen away from him that received them: if the thief be found, he shall restore double.
column4: Si quis commendaverit amico pecuniam aut vasa in custodiam, et ab eo, qui susceperat, furto ablata fuerint, si invenitur fur, duplum reddet.

column2: If the thief be not known, the master of the house shall be brought to the gods, and shall swear that he did not lay his hand upon his neighbour's goods.
column4: Si latet fur, dominus domus applicabitur ad Deum et iurabit quod non extenderit manum in rem proximi sui.

column2: To do any fraud, either in ox, or in ass, or sheep, or raiment, or any thing that may bring damage: the cause of both parties shall come to the gods: and if they give judgment, he shall restore double to his neighbour.
column4: In omni causa fraudis tam de bove quam de asino et ove ac vestimento et, quidquid damnum inferre potest, si quis dixerit: “Hoc est!”, ad Deum utriusque causa perveniet, et, quem Deus condemnaverit, duplum restituet proximo suo.

When an English speaker realises that a foreign person they are speaking to doesn't understand one of their sentences, they repeat it, the same way, but louder, as though the person were deaf. At no point does it come to their mind that their vocabulary might be complicated or that their expression might most probably be ambiguous to a foreigner and that they could reword it in a simpler way. The result is that not only does the person still not understand, but they get irritated at being considered deaf.
